questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, increased frequency of micturition, and pain during sex that extends to the vulva and vagina. The pain increases when the bladder is full. Cystoscopy shows fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa as shown in the image below and marked submucosal edema of the bladder. Biopsy reveals mucosal ulceration and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are characteristic of interstitial cystitis or chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

Interstitial cystitis is a rare idiopathic condition that occurs most frequently in women presenting as intermittent severe suprapubic pain, urinary frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria. Hunner ulcers are characteristic ulcers seen in interstitial cystitis. It is characterized by marked submucosal edema of the bladder with mucosal ulceration, seen in the late phase of interstitial cystitis.

Cystoscopic findings show fissures and punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) in the bladder mucosa. Microscopically, mucosal ulceration is covered by fibrin, necrotic material, and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells. The pathologic findings are nonspecific, and the main role of biopsy is to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may mimic interstitial cystitis clinically. Late in the course, transmural fibrosis may appear, leading to a contracted bladder.

Other options:

Option A: Malakoplakia is an inflammatory reaction caused by defects in phagocyte function. It occurs during chronic bacterial infections. On cystoscopy, it appears as soft, yellow, raised mucosal plaques 3-4cm in diameter with large aggregates of foamy macrophages.

Option B: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder or urothelial neoplasms are the most common bladder tumors. Morphological variants include papillary, nodular, or flat lesions. 

Option C: Follicular cystitis is characterized by multiple lymphoid follicles in the bladder mucosa or underlying wall.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency following an assault by his neighbour with a metal rod. The patient was diagnosed to have permanent loss of hearing. Which of the following BNS (IPC) section describes the punishment in this case?
questions.solution:
Permanent hearing loss is considered grievous hurt. BNS Sec 118 (2) (326 IPC) describes punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons.

Grievous hurt is inflicted voluntarily to another person and comprises any of the eight kinds (clauses) enumerated below:

  • Clause 1 — Emasculation.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye. 
  • Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 15 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

Punishment for grievous hurt :

  • BNS Sec 117(2)- previously 325 IPC- Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt –imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
  • BNS Sec 118(2)- previously 326 IPC Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means—life imprisonment or imprisonment of a minimum of one year, extendable up to ten years, and fine.

Related IPC's

BNS Section 115(1)- previously 321 IPC: Voluntarily causing hurt.
BNS Section 117(1)- previously 322 IPC: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt.
BNS Section 115(2)- previously 323 IPC.: Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt: Imprisonment up to one year, or with fine up to one thousand rupees or both.
BNS Section 118(1)- previously 324 IPC.: Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means (3 years imprisonment) or with fine or both.

questions.text: A worker from the shipbuilding industry has developed difficulty in breathing. He has been working there for the past 12 years. Pulmonary function tests reveal a restrictive pattern with a decrease in lung volumes and diffusing capacity. A chest X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of breathlessness with the pulmonary function test revealing the restrictive pattern of the disease and the X-ray showing a holly-leaf appearance is suggestive of asbestosis.

Asbestosis is an occupational disease and is characterized by diffuse interstitial fibrosis of the lung that is related to the intensity and duration of exposure to asbestos. It is seen in people who work in the shipbuilding, processing, construction, and mining industries. At least 10 years of exposure to asbestosis is needed to develop the disease. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

Radiologically it presents as pleural plaques, irregular or linear opacities, and ground-glass appearance particularly present at the lower lung fields. HRCT will show the presence of pleural plaque, subpleural curvilinear lines 5–10 mm in length that appears to be parallel to the pleura. Asbestosis increases the risk of development of mesothelioma.

Other options

Option A- Silicosis is an occupational disease and is caused by exposure to silica. It is seen in people who work in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, and quarrying. It presents as small rounded opacities in the upper lobe. There may be calcification of hilar lymph nodes which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. HRCT will show a characteristic crazy paving pattern.

The below image shows the crazy-paving pattern in silicosis.

 

Option B- Chronic berylliosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to beryllium. It is seen in people who work on processing alloys for high-tech industries. Chest radiography shows nodules along the septal lines.

Option D- Coal workers pneumoconiosis (CWP) is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to coal dust. It is seen in people working in mines. It presents as small opacities in the upper lobe of the lungs. Complicated CWP has nodules ≥1 cm in diameter generally confined to the upper half of the lungs.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and severe muscle pain after exercise. The exercise intolerance worsens after a carbohydrate rich meal. Investigations revealed a hemolytic anemia type of picture. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of worsening of exercise intolerance after a carbohydrate diet with laboratory investigations revealing hemolytic anemia picture is suggestive of Tarui's disease.

The clinical picture of Tarui's disease is similar to McArdle's disease. However, exercise intolerance is more severe and there is no second wind phenomenon in Tarui's disease. The exercise intolerance worsens after a carbohydrate-rich meal in Tauri's disease as there is a deficiency of phosphofructokinase and thus glucose is not metabolized. The ingested glucose prevents lipolysis, thereby depriving muscle of fatty acid and ketone substrates. In McArdle's disease exercise tolerance improves on glucose infusion as glucose can be metabolized unlike in Tauri's disease.

Tarui's disease is a type VII glycogen storage disorder that results due to the deficiency of phosphofructokinase. Phosphofructokinase is a key regulatory enzyme of glycolysis and is necessary for the ATP-dependent conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-diphosphate.

Some cases may present with hereditary nonspherocytic hemolytic anemia as indicated by elevated serum bilirubin and elevated reticulocyte count. Demonstration of defective enzymes in the muscles is required to establish the diagnosis.

There is no specific treatment for Tarui's disease. Strenuous exercise should be avoided to prevent acute episodes of muscle cramps and myoglobinuria. A ketogenic diet helps in clinical improvement.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a left-sided breast lump which she noticed only for the past 6 months but ignored. She has no other complaints. On palpation, the lump is mobile and firm. A mammogram revealed the following findings. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is fibroadenoma. The image shows popcorn calcifications in the breast mammogram which are characteristic of fibroadenoma of the breast.

Fibroadenomas are benign solid tumors composed of stromal and epithelial elements.

Fibroadenomas present as firm masses that are easily movable and may increase in size over several months and wax and wane with the menstrual cycle. They slide easily under the examining fingers and maybe lobulated or smooth. On excision, fibroadenomas are well-encapsulated masses.

On mammography, fibroadenomas show popcorn calcification. However, mammography cannot discriminate between cysts and fibroadenomas. Ultrasonography can be performed to distinguish between fibroadenoma and cysts.

Management includes reassurance of the patient. However, if the patient is bothered by the mass or if the mass continues to grow, it is removed with an open excisional biopsy or via a percutaneous approach.

Giant fibroadenoma is a type of fibroadenoma that attains an unusually large size (typically >5 cm). The term juvenile fibroadenoma refers to a large fibroadenoma that occasionally occurs in adolescents and young adults and histologically is more cellular than the usual fibroadenoma.

Other types of calcifications on a mammogram:

A broken-needle type of calcification is seen in duct ectasia (option A)

 

Egg-shell calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis (option C)

 

Tea-cup calcification is seen in fibrocystic disease (Option D)

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the psychiatric outpatient department complaining of depression and loneliness. History taking reveals that he does not engage in any social activity because he’s afraid of being rejected. Identify the likely personality disorder in this patient:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of avoidant personality disorder, as the patient does not engage in social activities due to fear of being rejected.

Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by extreme sensitivity to rejection leading to socially withdrawn lives, low levels of energy, easy fatigability, lack of enthusiasm, and inability to enjoy life.

Other options:

Option B: Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by unwarranted suspicion, hypersensi­tivity, jealousy, envy, rigidity, excessive self-importance, and a tendency to blame and ascribe evil motives to others.

 Option C: Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by shyness, oversensitivity, seclusive­ ness, avoidance of close or competitive relationships, eccentric­ity, no loss of capacity to recognize reality, daydreaming, and an ability to express hostility and aggression.

 Option D: Antisocial personal­ity disorder covers persons in conflict with society. They are incapable of loyalty, selfish, callous, irresponsible, impulsive, and unable to feel guilt or learn from experience; they have low levels of frustration tolerance and a tendency to blame others.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman can recognize the voices of their college friends while talking over the mobile phone. But she finds it difficult to recognize them, by seeing their faces in the college. Which lobe could the lesion be in this case?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of prosopagnosia, which occurs due to the lesions of the inferior temporal lobe.

Prosopagnosia is an inability to recognize faces. Patients with this abnormality can recognize people by their voices, body language, etc. How­ever, they cannot identify familiar people by seeing their faces. 

In humans, storage and recognition of faces are more strongly represented in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about chemoradiotherapy (CRT) except:

choices.text: Radiotherapy component also acts as radio-sensitizing agent
Chemotherapy mainly helps in reducing distant metastases
Radiotherapy mainly results in disease control locally

questions.solution:
Chemotherapy component of the CRT acts as radio-sensitizing agent.

Chemoradiotherapy (CRT) is the combination of chemotherapy with radiotherapy.

  • CRT can be of two types: concurrent, where both chemotherapy and radiotherapy are given simultaneously; or sequential, where they are given one after the other.
  • The chemotherapy component acts as the radio-sensitizing agent.
  • In various cancers, chemoradiotherapy has shown to be effective as neoadjuvant therapy before the surgery.
  • The radiotherapy mainly results in the local disease control, while the chemotherapy component, mainly helps in reducing the chances of distant metastases.

questions.text: The following are true about confidence interval except:

choices.text: The intervals are smaller with smaller sample size
95% of confidence interval means that 95% of all observed values in population fall within that interval
The width of the interval of the confidence interval will decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size

questions.solution:
The intervals are smaller with smaller sample size is the incorrect statement. The confidence interval is smaller with a larger sample size. Standard error=SD/√ n. So Standard error will reduce when the population size is increased.

A 95% confidence interval means that 95% of all observed values in the population fall within that interval (Option B). It is calculated as follows:

Confidence interval = Mean ± 2 (Standard error) 

The confidence interval can be decreased by decreasing the standard error. Since Standard error = Standard deviation/√ n where n represents the sample size, an increase in sample size will decrease the standard error. But this decrease will be proportional to the square root of the sample size (Option C) as per the formula. Thus in order to reduce the confidence interval into half the sample size must increase fourfold. 

Smaller sample sizes will have larger standard errors and thus, larger confidence intervals. (Option A)

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a 16-year-old female, you notice the following peculiar abnormality of the iris. This is called as
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows the presence of more than one pupil. This is called polycoria.

Option A: The absence of the tissue of the iris, ciliary body, and choroid is known as coloboma of the uveal tract. Coloboma of the iris alone is referred to as incomplete coloboma and is typically seen in the inferonasal quadrant.

Option B: An abnormal eccentrically placed pupil is known as corectopia. The pupil is normally placed slightly nasal to the center.

Option D: The congenital absence of an iris is known as aniridia. Complete absence is referred to as true aniridia and in the presence of a peripheral rim of the iris, it is known as clinical aniridia.

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral nasal obstruction. On anterior rhinoscopy, multiple smooth pale glistening masses are found bilaterally suggestive of ethmoidal polyps. The surgeon plans functional endoscopic sinus surgery to remove them. Which of the following structures shown in the image given below is removed during infundibulotomy?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the ostiomeatal complex in the coronal plane. The structure marked as 1 is the uncinate process which is removed in infundibulotomy.

Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS). FESS is the treatment of choice for ethmoidal polyps, which this patient has.

The structure marked as 2 is the ethmoidal bulla, and is removed in bullectomy.

The structure marked as 3 is the middle turbinate

The structure marked as 4 is the medial wall of the maxillary sinus.

Important steps in FESS:

  1. Uncinectomy or Infundibulotomy
  2. Identification and enlargement of the maxillary ostium
  3. Bullectomy
  4. Penetration of basal lamella and posterior ethmoidal cells
  5. Clearance of frontal recess and frontal sinusotomy
  6. Sphenoidotomy
  7. Nasal packing

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis refractory to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.
  • Epistaxis control by endoscopic cautery.
  • Foreign body removal from the nose or sinus.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A miner with cough, dyspnea on exertion and chest pain was diagnosed with silicotuberculosis. Which of the following is incorrect about his disease?

choices.text: Children of these patients do not get the disease

questions.solution:
The sputum sample is usually negative for AFB (acid-fast bacilli) in patients diagnosed with silicotuberculosis.

Patients with silicosis are particularly susceptible to pulmonary tuberculosis infection, a condition known as silicotuberculosis. Children and women exposed to silicotuberculosis patients do not develop tuberculosis (Option B). Post-mortem examinations done on silicotuberculosis patients fail to prove the existence of tuberculosis.

Silicosis is the most common pneumoconiosis. It occurs in industries such as sandblasting, pottery and ceramics, mining, and construction. It presents as cough, dyspnea, and chest pain and the advanced disease usually affects the total lung capacity (Option C). It affects the upper lobe of the lung and is characterized by dense nodular fibrosis (Option D) which is irreversible. Chest X-ray shows snowstorm appearance in the lung fields while eggshell calcification of the lymph nodes can be seen on a CT.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with cough and hemoptysis. There is a history of loss of weight and appetite. On further evaluation, the patient is diagnosed with bronchogenic carcinoma. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following sign is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A Golden S sign is seen in this patient.

Golden S sign is a radiographical appearance seen in the right upper lobe collapse in bronchogenic carcinoma. Due to the central tumor mass associated with lobar collapse, the fissure will not be able to move as usual and it thus creates a bulge giving an S shape pattern on the radiograph. This S shape appearance is known as the Golden S sign. However, this sign is not specific to bronchogenic carcinoma and can occur in other etiologies involving lymphadenopathy or primary mediastinal tumors.

Below is the radiograph showing the Golden S sign. (The orange circle denotes the central tumor, and the green arrow represents the direction of expansion while inspiration)

Other options:

Option A- Luftsichel sign is seen in upper lobe collapse. It is the overinflation of the superior segment of the ipsilateral lower lobe that occupies between the mediastinum and the medial aspect of the upper lobe which results in paramediastinal translucency. This is usually seen more commonly on the left side.

Below is the radiograph of the Luftsichel sign.

Option B- Westermark sign is seen in chest radiographs of patients with pulmonary embolism, indicating focal oligemia.

Option C- Hampton's hump is a wedge-shaped consolidation in the peripheral area of the lungs that may indicate infarction in pulmonary embolism.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A primigravida mother with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus is in active labor. During the delivery, the baby presented with shoulder dystocia. After a few unsuccessful attempts, the obstetrician decides to replace the fetal head back into the pelvis and deliver the baby by cesarean section. Identify the maneuver performed.
questions.solution:
The procedure performed in the above-mentioned scenario is the Zavanelli maneuver. It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery. It is performed when the initial maneuvers were unsuccessful.

The correct sequence of shoulder dystocia drill is as follows:

  • Call for help and mobilize labor assistants, anesthesia, and pediatric doctors.
  • An attempt at traction is tried followed by episiotomy to afford room posteriorly.
  • 1st line of management - Mc Roberts maneuver (flexion and abduction of thigh) in conjunction with suprapubic pressure application.
  • 2nd line of management - Woods corkscrew maneuver (rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion). Other maneuvers like Rubin's, Gaskin's (all four's position), Hubbard, and Barnum's maneuvers can be attempted too.
  • 3rd line of management - Zavanelli maneuver (replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis) followed by cesarean delivery
  • The last line of management (Not preferred nowadays):
    • Cleidotomy(fracture of the clavicle of the baby) 
    • Symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother)

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or rarely the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively, following the delivery of the head. A positive turtle sign may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum. The incidence of shoulder dystocia increases with increasing birth weight, which can be due to maternal obesity, gestational diabetes, post-term pregnancy, and multiparity.

Mc.Roberts maneuver: Flexing the legs on the abdomen with concurrent suprapubic pressure. This causes straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebrae, rotation of the symphysis pubis toward the maternal head, and a decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination. This tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

Woods corkscrew maneuver: Pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a cork­ screw fashion releases the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

Rubin's maneuver: The fetal shoulders are rocked from side to side by applying force to the maternal abdomen. If this is not successful, the pelvic hand pushes the most easily accessible fetal shoulder toward the anterior surface of the chest, producing a smaller bis acromial diameter. This permits displacement of the anterior shoulder from behind the symphysis.

Gaskin maneuver: (All fours maneuver): The parturient rolls onto her knees and hands and downward traction against the head and neck is applied, with an attempt to free the posterior shoulder.

Zavanelli maneuver: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery.

Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis.

Cleidotomy: Fracture of the clavicle using an instrument to free the anterior shoulder. Usually done for a dead fetus. (shown below)

questions.text: Patients of Neurofibromatosis type 1 present with different extent of clinical features despite the same genetic defect. Which of the following best describes the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Patients presenting with different extents of clinical features despite having the same genetic defect is due to the phenomenon of variable expressivity

Variable expressivity refers to a similar genotype but a varying phenotype. The trait will be present in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is expressed differently among individuals. It is a feature of autosomal dominant disorders. Ex:- varying severity of disease with NF1 mutation (neurofibromatosis).

Other options

Option B: Anticipation refers to an earlier onset of disease in successive generations in a pedigree. It is seen in Huntington's disease, myotonic dystrophy, and fragile X syndrome.

 Option C: Incomplete penetrance refers to variations in penetrance and expressivity of clinical features. Not all individuals who inherit the mutant gene show a mutant phenotype. It is a feature of autosomal dominant disorders.   

Option D: A single mutant gene producing multiple end-organ defects is termed pleiotropism.

For example, in sickle-cell anemia, the point mutation in the gene not only predisposes the red blood cells to hemolysis but can also block the vessels. This leads to splenic fibrosis, organ infarcts, and bone changes. The numerous differing end-organ derangements are all related to the primary defect in hemoglobin synthesis.

questions.text: You are a medical officer actively spearheading the sexually transmitted diseases control program in your block. As part of this, the sexual partners of the diagnosed patients are identified, located, investigated, and treated for the disease. This type of case detection that is employed by your team is  called ___________.
questions.solution:
The method of case detection in control of STDs when the sexual partners of the diagnosed patients are identified, located, tested, and treated is contact tracing.

Methods employed in case of detection of STDs are

  • Screening is done by testing apparently healthy volunteers from the general population. This helps in early detection of disease.
  • Contact tracing refers to identifying and locating sexual partners of diagnosed patients in order to investigate and treat them.
  • Cluster testing is done by asking the patients to name other persons of either sex who are part of the same socio-sexual environment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient was diagnosed to be suffering from systemic mycoses infection. Culture from the lesion at 37°C shows the appearance of the causative organism as given in the below image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the characteristic 'pilot wheel appearance' on culture shown by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. It causes South American blastomycosis/paracoccidioidomycosis.

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It causes paracoccidioidomycosis, a chronic granulomatous disease affecting the lungs, skin, mucosa, and lymph nodes. 

The spores are inhaled which results in a primary pulmonary infection. This is followed by a hematogenous spread to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin, and lymphatics. This leads to ulcerative granulomas of the buccal and nasal mucosa.

On culture at 37 °C, large oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cell are seen This is known as Mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance. On culture at 25-30°C, it is found in the mycelial phase.

Other options:

Option A: Darling's disease (Histoplasmosis) is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. 

Option B: North American blastomycosis (Blastomycosis) is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis.

Option D: Valley Fever (Coccidioidomycosis) is caused by Coccidioides immitis

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A patient with stroke came to your OPD. His neurological examination revealed the following finding. Which of the following is a true statement regarding the examination finding?

choices.text: It is non-rhythmic, non-voluntary muscular contraction
It is due to increased gamma motor neuron activity
It is due to decreased alpha neuron activity
It is a result of lower motor neuron type palsy

questions.solution:
Clonus is due to sustained hyperactivity of alpha and gamma motor neurons.

Clonus is defined as regular, rhythmic, repetitive involuntary (Option A) muscle contractions of the part of a limb (ankle, patella) when abrupt sustained muscle stretch is given. When the clonus is sustained for 5 or more beats, it is considered to abnormal.

Normally during flexion of the ankle, reflex extensor stimulation is inhibited by Renshaw cells. These cells are inhibitory interneurons that receive excitatory input from cortical fibers and lead to the inhibition of alpha and gamma motor neurons. Thus clonus is seen in upper motor neuron-type palsy (Option D) which removes the inhibitory cortical control, allows hyperactivity of alpha (Option C) and gamma neurons , and causes contraction of the ankle flexors and extensors in sequence. Management includes treatment of the underlying cause along with physical therapy.

questions.text:
A pregnant lady was awarded a death sentence for committing murder by the session's court. However, her death sentence was converted to life imprisonment by the High Court. Which of the following sections describes this procedure?

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA

BNSS - BHARATIYA NAGARIK SURAKSHA SANHITA
questions.solution:
BNSS Section 456: Commutation of capital sentence on pregnant woman i.e. If a woman sentenced to death is found to be pregnant, the High Court shall commute the sentence to imprisonment for life.

Other options:

Option A: Section 88 of BNS states that miscarriage induced not for the purpose of saving the life/good of the woman, be punished with imprisonment for 3 years. If the woman is “quick with child” the period is extended for 7 years more.

Option B: Section 94 of BNS – concealment of birth and secret disposal of the fetus are punishable.

Option C: BNSS Section 455 deals with the Commutation of death sentence in case of appeal to the Supreme Court.

questions.text: A patient presented with foreign body sensation, redness, and excessive watering from the right eye for 15 days after a twig brushed against his eye. On examination, an irregularly shaped ulcer with a whitish feathery appearance, and satellite lesions were seen in his right eye. Which among the following is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a fungal ulcer and the most appropriate treatment is amphotericin B drops.

Fungal or mycotic keratitis is commonly caused by Aspergillus, Fusarium, or Candida albicans. They are characteristically seen after injury with vegetative matter like thorns or wooden sticks.

Patients may present with pain, watering, and photophobia, but are usually milder in comparison to a bacterial ulcer. The clinical signs of a fungal ulcer include:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes
  • Dry slough with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

Treatment:

  • Topical drugs
    • Natamycin, voriconazole, and amphotericin B drops are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium.
    • Nystatin is effective against Candida.
  • Systemic antifungal agents such as oral ketoconazole or voriconazole are considered if the ulcers are severe with hypopyon, perforated or in suspected endophthalmitis
  • Surgical treatment:
    • Removal of necrotic material by scraping with a spatula
    • Cauterization with pure carbolic acid or trichloracetic acid
    • Therapeutic keratoplasty 

The image below shows a fungal corneal ulcer with a hypopyon.

questions.text: All of the following intrinsic muscles of the larynx are paired except _____
questions.solution:
All of the following intrinsic muscles of the larynx are paired except the transverse arytenoid. (inter arytenoid)

The larynx contains intrinsic and extrinsic muscles. The intrinsic muscles are localized within the larynx itself, while the extrinsic muscles attach to the larynx and nearby structures. Among the intrinsic muscles,

  • There are four paired muscles:
  1. Thyroarytenoid
  2. Lateral cricoarytenoid
  3. Posterior cricoarytenoid
  4. Cricothyroid.
  • One unpaired muscle- inter arytenoid/ transverse arytenoid.

With the exception of the posterior cricoarytenoid, all intrinsic muscles work together to adduct the vocal folds. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is responsible for the abduction. A unique function of the cricothyroid muscle is its ability to elongate the vocal cords, creating tension and contributing to high-pitched phonation.

The extrinsic muscles of the larynx can be classified into two groups based on their actions:

  •  Elevators: Primary elevators are directly connected to the thyroid cartilage and consist of the stylopharyngeus, salpingopharyngeus, palatopharyngeus, and thyrohyoid muscles. Secondary elevators are indirectly attached to the hyoid bone and include the main mylohyoid muscle, along with the digastric, stylohyoid, and geniohyoid muscles.
  • Depressors: These muscles function to lower the larynx and include the sternohyoid, sternothyroid, and omohyoid muscles.

 

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

questions.text: A first-year medical student during his practical exam was given with 1st rib and asked to name the small projection seen on the medial (inner) border of the 1st rib, which is present between two grooves. Which of the following structure passes through the groove related anteriorly to the tubercle?
questions.solution:
The scalene tubercle is a feature of the 1st rib present as a small projection on the medial (inner) border of the 1st rib and the subclavian vein is present anterior to this tubercle.

Structures passing through the grooves related to the scalene tubercle are

  • Anterior groove - Subclavian vein.
  • Posterior groove - Subclavian artery and lower trunk of brachial plexus. (Option B and C)

Scalenus anterior is attached to the scalene tubercle.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the marked incision shown below?

choices.text: The rectus abdominis muscles are transected
Follows Langer lines of skin tension
Lower incidence of incisional hernias as compared to vertical incisions
Location is 3 cm above the pubic symphysis

questions.solution:
The incision marked is the Pfannenstiel incision where the rectus muscles are not transected. The rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in cesarean delivery.It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Compared to vertical incisions, the Pfannenstiel incision offers superior cosmesis and lower incisional hernia rates.

The Maylard incision (the unmarked incision in the image) differs mainly from the Pfannenstiel in that the bellies of the rectus abdominis muscles are transected horizontally to widen the operating space.

Related Pearl: Transvere and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse incisions:

Advantages-

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Disadvantages-

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring

Vertical incisions:

Advantages-

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages-

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: What are the net number of ATP’s generated in rapaport leubering cycle ?
questions.solution:
The net number of ATPs generated in the Rapaport Luebering cycle(2,3 BPG shunt pathway) is zero. 2 ATPs are generated at the pyruvate kinase step, but that is used up by hexokinase and fructokinase.

Rapaport luebering cycle:

In the erythrocytes. Bisphosphoglycerate mutase converts 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) to 2,3-BPG. Then BPG-phosphatase removes the phosphate group to form 3-phosphoglycerate

Significance of BPG

  • 2,3-BPG binds to hemoglobin and reduces the affinity towards oxygen. So, in the presence of 2,3- BPG, oxyhemoglobin will unload oxygen more easily in tissues.
  • Under hypoxic conditions the 2,3-BPG concentration in the RBC increases, thus favoring the release of oxygen to the tissues even when pO2 is low.
  • The compensatory increase in 2,3-BPG in high altitudes favors oxygen dissociation. BPG affinity is decreased in fetal circulation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man, with no known medical illness, came for a routine medical check-up. His chest radiograph is presented to you. Identify the incorrect statement with respect to the X-ray shown below.

choices.text: The structure marked number 2 is the right ventricular border
The structure marked 1 is the trachea
The structure marked 3 is the left ventricular border
The structure marked 4 is the aortic arch

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is option A because the structure marked as 2 is the right atrial border (not the right ventricular border). The given image is posteroanterior (PA) view of a normal chest x-ray. Structures marked in the X-Ray are as follows:

  1. Trachea
  2. Right atrial border
  3. Left ventricular border
  4. Aortic arch

Chest x-rays can be described as posteroanterior (PA) or anteroposterior (AP) views. This indicates the direction in which the x-ray beam traverses from the patient to the detector.

PA view means that the x-ray beam enters from the posterior aspect of the patient and exits anteriorly to reach the film.

AP view means that the x-ray beam enters the patient from the anterior aspect and exits from the posterior aspect, reaching the film.

A left lateral decubitus view is one taken with the patient’s left side down.

questions.text: A sample of water is being tested to assess whether it is suitable for drinking. The detection of which organism provides definitive proof of faecal contamination?
questions.solution:
The detection of Escherichia coli provides definitive proof of fecal contamination.

The presence of fecal pollution in a water sample suggests that the source may be contaminated with enteric pathogens. Two tests are done in succession to identify the presence of E.coli which provides definite proof of fecal pollution. They are

  • Presumptive coliform count
  • Differential coliform count/ Eijkman test

Presumptive coliform count - The basis of the presumptive coliform test is the inoculation of the water to be tested into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium. These are then incubated and examined after the appropriate period of time. The test is called presumptive because the acid and gas formation observed in the tube may occasionally be due to the presence of some other organism and it has to be confirmed. 

Differential coliform count/ Eijkman test - Following the presumptive test, subcultures are made from all the bottles showing acid and gas to fresh tubes of single-strength Mac Conkey medium pre-warmed to 37°C. These tubes are incubated at 44°C and examined after 24 hours. If Escherichia coli is detected, it is definitive proof of fecal contamination.

Interpretation:

  • The Durham's tubes with the presence of gas are deemed to contain E.Coli.
  • This can be further confirmed by testing for indole production and citrate utilization.

Other options:

Option A- Recent fecal contamination of water is suggested by the presence of enterococcus (fecal streptococci). Fecal streptococci are found in feces in smaller numbers than E.coli. Streptococci are useful for routine control testing after laying new pipelines or repairs in distribution systems and to detect groundwater contamination.

Option C- Clostridium perfringens also occur regularly in feces but in much smaller numbers than E.coli. The spores are capable of surviving in water for a long time, and they usually resist chlorination. The presence of spores of Clostridium perfringens in natural water suggests that fecal contamination has occurred. But in the absence of the coliform group, it suggests that fecal contamination is a long time ago. They can also be used to assess filtration systems.

Option D- Bacteroides species are present in feces but do not play a significant role in testing and sampling for fecal pollution of water.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presents to the hospital with a history of swelling of the legs for the past few months. During the examination, it is noted that the patient has bilateral pitting type of pedal edema, elevated jugular venous pressure, and enlarged liver. Auscultation reveals the presence of a third heart sound. This sound occurs due to

choices.text: Closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Vibrations of the ventricular wall during diastole
Closure of mitral  and tricuspid valves

questions.solution:
Clinical features suggest heart failure which is one of the pathological causes of the third heart sound. The third heart sound is caused by vibrations of the ventricular wall during diastole.

A third heart sound is a weak rumbling sound heard at the beginning of the middle third of diastole. It is best heard with the bell of the stethoscope. It may be normally present in children, adolescents, and young adults. In older adults, it usually indicates systolic heart failure.

Important aspects of other heart sound

First heart sound is caused due to the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves. It is a high-pitched sound best heard with the diaphragm of a stethoscope. The first heart sound due to mitral valve closure is best heard over the apex of the heart, and due to the closure of the tricuspid valve is best heard in the fourth intercostal space in the left sternal border.

The second heart sound is caused by the closure of the aortic (A2) and pulmonary valves (P2). It is a high-pitched sound best heard with the diaphragm of a stethoscope. A2 is best heard in the right second intercostal space, and P2 is best heard in the left second intercostal space. 

Fourth heart sound is caused due to late ventricular filling through active atrial contraction. It is a low-pitched sound, heard best through the bell of the stethoscope. When it originates from the left ventricular, S4 is best heard at the apex with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position at end-expiration. When it originates from the right ventricular, it is heard best at the left lower sternal border. It is seen in ventricular hypertrophy, ischemic heart disease, ventricular aneurysm, etc.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male, a chronic smoker, presented with fever, a painful lump over his left cheek just below the ear, and difficulty in swallowing or talking. The patient also complained of mild testicular pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of painful swelling in the parotid region (parotitis) together with testicular pain (orchitis) are most likely suggestive of mumps.

Mumps is a paramyxoviral disease, which spreads by respiratory droplets.

Patients experience prodromal symptoms followed by parotitis. It develops in 24 hours and is often bilateral. Other salivary glands such as submaxillary and sublingual glands may also be involved, but are less likely than parotid. Patients complain of earaches and difficulty in eating, swallowing, or talking. Epididymo-orchitis is the 2nd common presentation. The testis is painful and tender and may enlarge up to several times its normal size. Other manifestations may include CSF pleocytosis, encephalitis, pancreatitis, and myocarditis.

Diagnosis is made by the detection of viral RNA by reverse-transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) or serology.

Treatment: The disease is self-limiting. Analgesics and application of warm or cold compress over the parotid and testicular swellings may help relieve the symptoms.

Other options:

Option A: Cervical tuberculosis may present as unilateral single or multiple painless lumps, usually in the posterior cervical or supraclavicular area. Night sweats, weakness, cough, and fever may be also seen.

Option B: Diphtheria presents with a sore throat and adherent tonsillar, pharyngeal, or nasal pseudomembranous lesions with low-grade fever. A few patients develop a bull neck. This results from submandibular and paratracheal edema and is associated with foul breath, thick speech, and stridor. Cutaneous diphtheria is characterized by punched-out ulcerative lesions with necrotic slough or a pseudomembrane.

Option D: Lymphomas present with enlarging lymphadenopathy centrally or peripherally depending on the type. They may be associated with B symptoms -fevers, drenching night sweats, and unintentional weight loss.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple itchy lesions as shown below. KOH stain revealed the presence of predominant macroconidia and scanty microconidia. Which of the following conditions is also likely to be associated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and microscopic examination point toward a diagnosis of Microsporum infection.

The given image shows annular lesions with central clearing which is seen in dermatophytosis.

Dermatophytes involve only the superficial cornified layer of skin, sparing the dermis. It should be differentiated from dermatomycosis which is the cutaneous involvement of systemic fungi.

Dermatophytes are of three types:

  • Trichosporum: involves skin, hair, and nails. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum: involves skin and hair. Macroconidia> Microconidia
  • Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails. Only Macroconidia.

The clinical variants of tinea capitis are:

  • Endothrix - It is a non-inflammatory type of tinea in which multiple black dots and fine scaling are present within the areas of alopecia; it is most commonly caused by Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum.
  • Ectothrix - It is a mild inflammatory type of tinea in which single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss are seen. Microsporum audouinii, Microsporum canis, Microsporum equinum, and Microsporum ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.
  • Kerion - It is a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation. It is commonly caused by Trichophyton verrucosum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes.
  • Favus - It is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles. It is caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 30-year-old tourist is on a road trip in the Philippines where he consumes food from the roadside vendors. The next day he develops loose stools and abdominal pain.  Which of the following bacteria and their toxins which act by increasing cGMP, can be implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The heat-stable toxin of Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) acts by increasing cGMP.

Tourist from developed countries visiting endemic areas often suffers from ETEC diarrhea, a condition known as Traveller's diarrhea.

Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is the most common cause of Traveller’s Diarrhoea. Colonization factor antigens promote adherence of ETEC to epithelial cells of the small bowel.

Some strains of ETEC produce a heat-labile enterotoxin. It attaches to the GM1 ganglioside in the apical membrane of enterocytes and activates adenylyl cyclase. This markedly increases the local concentration of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). This result is intense and prolonged hypersecretion of water and chlorides and inhibition of the reabsorption of sodium.

Some strains of ETEC produce the heat-stable enterotoxin which activates guanylyl cyclase in enteric epithelial cells and increases cGMP. This increases fluid secretion.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A 20-year-old nulligravida presented with right flank pain. MRI evaluation revealed a solid, enhancing  5×13×7 cm right ovarian mass. Salpingo-oophorectomy was successfully done and microscopic examination of the tumor cells showed a close resemblance to primordial germ cells. It was also noticed that the tumor appeared histologically identical to a testicular seminoma. Which of the following is not secreted by this tumor?
questions.solution:
An ovarian tumor in a young woman which consists of primordial germ cells and is histologically similar to seminoma suggests a diagnosis of an ovarian dysgerminoma. It does not secrete sex hormones.

Dysgerminoma usually arises in young women or in children, with an average incidence at the age of 20. It is the most common malignant germ cell tumour diagnosed during pregnancy.

The tumor is neutral and does not secrete either male or female sex hormones. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and β-hCG. Serum LDH and the isoenzymes LDH-1 and LDH-2 may be used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.

Dysgerminomas are primitive neoplasms that do not have the potential for further differentiation. They are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement (15-20%).

Microscopically, there is a monotonous proliferation of large, rounded, polyhedral clear cells that are rich in cytoplasmic glycogen and contain uniform central nuclei with one or a few prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells are histologically identical to the seminoma of the testis. The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma. 

Treatment involves fertility-sparing surgery with unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient with multiple ill-defined hypopigmented patches over the face and hands presents to a medical camp. Examination reveals associated sensory loss, loss of hair growth, and sweating in that area. A Lepromin test was performed. Which of the following is not the purpose of the test?

choices.text: To classify the lesions in patients
To indicate prior contact with the causative organism
To assess the prognosis and response to treatment
To assess the resistance of individuals to the disease

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing hypopigmented patches with associated sensory loss, loss of hair growth and sweating in the area is suggestive of leprosy, for which the lepromin test is performed, as shown in the image given. The test does not indicate prior contact with the lepra bacilli.

The lepromin test is a prognostic test used in the classification of Leprosy. It has no diagnostic purpose.

  • It involves performing an intradermal injection of the lepromin antigen (synthesized from M. leprae) on the flexor surface of the forearm.
  • It is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity and is the only method for studying immunity in leprosy. 
  • A positive test indicates good cell-mediated immunity and towards the tuberculoid side of the spectrum
  • A negative test indicates poor cell-mediated immunity and towards the lepromatous side of the spectrum.

The antigens used in the lepromin test are

  • Lepromin A (from armadillo-derived lepra bacilli)
  • Dharmendra antigen

First is the early reaction of Fernandez, which consists of erythema and induration developing in 24-48 hours and usually remaining for 3-5 days; it is usually poorly defined and carries less significance.

The second and more meaningful result is the late reaction of Mitsuda, starting at 1-2 weeks (7-10 days), reaching a peak in three or four weeks, and gradually subsiding over the next few weeks. At the end of 21 days, if there is a nodule more than 5 mm in diameter, the reaction is said to be positive. 

The lepromin test is not used to diagnose leprosy, nor does it indicate prior contact with the lepra bacillus.

The test is used for the following purposes: 

  • To classify the lesions of leprosy patients. The lepromin test is positive in tuberculoid, negative in lepromatous, and variable in dimorphous and indeterminate types of disease.
  • To assess the prognosis and response to treatment. A positive reaction indicates a good prognosis while a negative reaction reflects a bad prognosis. If a patient converts to lepromin-positive during treatment, it is evidence of improvement.
  • To assess the resistance of individuals to leprosy. Lepromin-positive persons are recruited for work in leprosaria as lepromin-negative persons are more prone to develop the disease
  • To verify the identity of candidate lepra bacilli. Cultivable AFB diagnosed to be lepra bacilli should give matching results when tested in parallel with standard lepromin.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old lady comes for a routine check-up at 34 weeks of gestation when her blood pressure is found to be 170/118 mmHg. Her urine analysis shows proteinuria 3+. Which of the following statements are true about the management of this situation?
  1. Oral Captopril can be used as a second-line drug.
  2. Labetalol is safe in asthmatics and cardiac failure patients.
  3. The maximum dose of labetalol that can be given is 300 mg.
  4. Intravenous labetalol is the drug of choice.
  5. Sodium nitroprusside is the first-line drug.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe pre-eclampsia with hypertensive crisis (BP>160/110 mmHg). Intravenous Labetalol is the drug of choice for controlling blood pressure in severe pre-eclampsia and the maximum dose that can be given is 300 mg. Therefore, options 3 and 4 are correct.

Hydralazine 10 mins 5 mg IV every 30 mins  30 mg IV 10 mg/hr
Nifedipine 10 mins  10-20 mg oral, can be repeated in 30 mins  240 mg/24 hours  4-6 hour intervals

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor and is hence contraindicated in pregnancy.

Labetalol is avoided in women having asthma or cardiac failure.

Sodium nitroprusside is only given after treatment with other drugs has failed.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with gall bladder carcinoma was posted for radical cholecystectomy. Which of the following segments of the liver would be removed in him?
questions.solution:
Segments IVb and V of the liver are removed during radical cholecystectomy.

Cantlie’s line or main portal fissure extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein. The liver has 3 major fissures and 3 minor fissures.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage.

The left lobe is composed of the left lateral segment (Couinaud’s segments II and III) and the left medial segment (segment IV). The right lobe is composed of segments V, VI, VII, and VIII, with segments V and VIII making up the right anterior lobe and segments VI and VII making up the right posterior lobe.

Segment I corresponds to the caudate lobe of the liver and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver. Segment IV is divided into segments IVa and IVb. The gallbladder fossa is related to segments V and IVb and is hence removed in radical cholecystectomy.

Gallbladder carcinoma is a rare malignancy that is seen in the elderly. 

Gallbladder carcinoma is indistinguishable from cholecystitis or cholelithiasis. It is usually diagnosed when patients undergo cholecystectomy for gallstones. Its clinical features include right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Jaundice, palpable mass, and anorexia are late features. CA 19-9 is elevated in the carcinoma gallbladder and is used for monitoring.

The preoperative diagnosis is often made on ultrasonography and followed up by a CT scan or MRI/ Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography. A percutaneous biopsy under radiological guidance is done for pathological examination. PET scanning helps in detecting metastatic disease. In select cases, a laparoscopic examination is useful in staging the disease. Laparoscopy can also detect peritoneal or liver metastases. The most important prognostic factor is the depth of invasion (T-stage)

Radical en bloc resection is done which includes the gallbladder, wedge hepatectomy (2 cm of the liver in the gallbladder bed or segments IVb and V if there is concomitant liver infiltration), or extended hepatectomy and bile duct resection if the bile duct is involved or the cystic duct margin is positive on intraoperative frozen section.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions may have the following ascitic fluid findings - Serum ascites albumin gradient  (SAAG) > 1.1g/dL and ascitic protein <2.5 g/dL?
questions.solution:
Cirrhosis is characterized by SAAG >1.1 and ascitic protein < 2.5 g/dL.

Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG):

  • Calculated by subtracting the ascitic albumin concentration from the serum albumin level.
  • Reflects the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids
  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

Ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology, in cases with high SAAG (≥1.1):

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites. eg. cardiac ascites
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. cirrhosis

The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is the most reli­able method to differentiate causes of ascites due to portal hyper­tension from those not due to portal hypertension.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman who was treated for COVID-19 one month back now presents with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose and suppuration of the left eye. Culture of discharge on Sabouraud agar would reveal colonies showing:

choices.text: Broad hyphae with acute angle branching
Septate hyphae with acute angle branching

questions.solution:
Microscopy showing broad aseptate hyphae with irregular branching is suggestive of Mucor.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus oryzae (most prevalent), mucor, and lichtheimia. It is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The common clinical form is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis in which there is an invasion of the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. The blackish discoloration is due to arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis can be made by staining them with 10% potassium hydroxide and culture. On Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, they appear as grey-white colonies with a thick cottony, fluffy surface. Under the microscope, they appear as irregularly branched broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores). 

Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis. Surgical debridement and control of underlying predisposing causes should also be done.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady develops pulmonary tuberculosis and is started on antitubercular therapy. She returns 2 months later for a repeat check-up during which her urine pregnancy test turns out to be positive. She regularly takes oral contraceptive pills. Which of the following drugs might be implicated in contraception failure?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is likely implicated in the contraception failure of this patient. It might have increased the metabolism of OCPs and decreased its concentration needed for maintaining contraception.

Rifampicin is a potent inducer of cytochrome enzymes CYP3A4, CYP1A2, CYP2C9, CYP2C19. As a result, it hastens the metabolism of its own and multiple other drugs including OCPs, steroids, HIV protease inhibitors, phenytoin which are metabolized by this microsomal enzyme.

A strategy to prevent failure of contraception in this case is, either to use higher estrogen-containing pills or to use other method of contraception.

Amongst rifamycins, the order of drug interactions is given as rifampicin> rifapentine> rifabutin. Hence, rifabutin is used when other drugs are used to decrease the likelihood of drug interactions.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with a history of major depressive disorder is brought to the emergency room. She is in a state of confusion and is found to have dilated pupils, a dry mouth, dry, warm skin, and hypotension. ECG shows prolonged QRS duration. Which of the following medications is responsible for these overdose symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of MDD (major depressive disorder) presents with a prolonged duration of QRS on ECG along with signs of anticholinergic toxicity like dry mouth, dry skin, mydriasis, and hypotension. The patient has most likely overdosed on imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) used in MDD treatment.

Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that antagonizes the serotonin and norepinephrine transporters responsible for the reuptake of these neurotransmitters in the neuron. They also block other receptors which is responsible for their adverse effects. When taken in sufficiently large quantities, TCAs exert their adverse effects by:

  • antimuscarinic actions- confusion, blurred vision, dry mouth, tachycardia, constipation, difficulty urinating
  • anti-alpha1 adrenergic actions- orthostatic hypotension
  • anti-histaminic actions- sedation

They also have effects similar to quinidine as reflected in the QRS prolongation of this patient's ECG. 

Other options:

Option A - Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor that is used to treat MDD resistant to first and second-line antidepressants. It acts to prevent the degradation of serotonin and norepinephrine. The common adverse effect associated with this is a hypertensive crisis as seen with ingestion of tyramine-rich foods (cheeses). Inhibition of gastrointestinal MAO reduces the degradation of tyramine which then enters the systemic circulation and promotes catecholamine release. Other side effects are weight gain, sexual dysfunction, and suicidal thoughts.

Option B - Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor. The SSRIs generally do not have any anti-muscarinic adverse effects. They also don't block the alpha-adrenergic receptors. Adverse effects of SSRIs include gastrointestinal disturbances, sexual dysfunction, and serotonin syndrome. 

Option D - Aripiprazole is a second-generation antipsychotic drug. While antipsychotics are associated with antimuscarinic adverse effects, second-generation drugs have limited anticholinergic toxicity. Adverse effects include extrapyramidal symptoms and hypoprolactinemia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male patient presented with macular lesions on the trunk as shown in the image. On stroking a macular lesion with a blunt object, there is erythema around the reddish-brown macules. Which of the following diseases would you suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The skin reaction depicted above is Darier’s sign, which is seen in cutaneous mastocytosis.

Cutaneous mastocytosis, the most common among them being urticaria pigmentosa, presents with hyperpigmented macules. The lesions have numerous mast cells. Darier's sign is the development of urticarial halo and erythema around the reddish-brown macules after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. It is caused by the release of histamine due to degranulation of the mast cells. However, Darier's sign is not highly specific to mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia of neonates.

Note: Pseudo-Darier’s sign is seen in congenital smooth muscle hamartoma, and piloerection of the muscle is responsible for the sign.

Mastocytosis is an acquired condition where there is a massive increase in the number of mast cells in the skin and other tissues. They are further classified by WHO as:

  • Cutaneous mastocytosis
    • Maculopapular cutaneous mastocytosis or urticaria pigmentosa (most common)
    • Mastocytoma
    • Diffuse cutaneous mastocytosis
  • Systemic mastocytosis

Histopathology of skin lesions in urticaria pigmentosa shows mast cell infiltrates predominantly around blood vessels and skin appendages in the papillary dermis. Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin (H&E)–stained sections. Special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to visualize their granules. Stains for mast cells:

  • Toluidine blue
  • Giemsa
  • Tryptase
  • Leder stain (Chloracetate esterase)
  • CD 117

The image below shows mast cells stained with toluidine blue.

 

Urticaria pigmentosa is common in 20-40 years age group and is characterized by numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques or nodules. They are in symmetrical distribution anywhere on the body except the palms and soles and seen maximum on the trunk and thighs. The lesions are positive for Darier's sign.

Treatment: Second-generation antihistaminics like cetirizine, fexofenadine, etc are the mainstay treatment. Other therapies include topical corticosteroids and photochemotherapy.

Other options: 

Option B: Cholinergic urticaria appears when the person is sweating after exercise or when the core body temperature is elevated and the patient develops pinpoint wheals. This is mediated by acetylcholine released by the sympathetic fibres of the eccrine sweat glands.

Option C: Chronic idiopathic urticaria: Urticaria with nonspecific etiology, lasting for more than 6 weeks.

Option D: Allergic contact dermatitis: Allergic contact dermatitis is defined as an eczematous reaction that occurs as an immunological response following exposure to a substance to which the immune system has previously been sensitized. Patch testing can confirm the specific allergen involved. Long-term treatment of allergic contact dermatitis involves avoidance of the allergen.

questions.text: A patient treated with an alkylating agent A, for the treatment of steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome. This drug A is also used as part of the regime for treating NHL. He now starts passing blood in the urine. A drug B, is used for treating the ‘Bloody urine’. All of the following statements are correct regarding the drugs A&B except?

choices.text: Blood in urine is due to acrolein produced by metabolism of drug A
Both drugs A & B can be administered oral or IV
Hemorrhagic myocardial necrosis can be caused by high dose therapy with drug A
Fluid restriction is advised during high dose treatment with drug A to reduce side effects

questions.solution:
Drug A is cyclophosphamide and Drug B is MESNA. Vigorous intravenous hydration, not fluid restriction is advised during high-dose treatment with cyclophosphamide to reduce hemorrhagic cystitis.

Cyclophosphamide is used for the treatment of steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome and is also used as part of the regime for treating NHL. Both cyclophosphamide and MESNA can be administered orally as well as intravenously. MESNA is used to treat hemorrhagic cystitis caused by cyclophosphamide metabolite acrolein.

Hemorrhagic myocardial necrosis may occur after high-dose therapy with total doses greater than 200 mg/kg.

Mesna Dosing - 60% of drug

questions.text: What percentage of drug given will be left in the body after 4 half-lives, If the drug is eliminated by first order kinetics?
questions.solution:
The percentage of drug given that will be left in the body if the drug is eliminated by first-order kinetics after 4 half-lives is 6.25%.

The half-life (T1/2) is the time it takes for the plasma concentration of the drug to be reduced by 50%. In first-order kinetics, the rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional to the drug concentration. The half-life of the drug remains constant in first-order kinetics. The rate of clearance is also constant.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with cyanosis. On auscultation, quadruple​ rhythm and holosystolic murmur were heard. ECG showed prominent p waves and right bundle-branch block. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Ebstein anomaly.

A quadruple rhythm (S3 and S4) associated with holosystolic murmur due to tricuspid regurgitation, ECG findings suggestive of right atrial hypertrophy (prominent p waves), and right ventricular conduction defects are seen in Ebstein's anomaly. Ebstein's anomaly is a rare congenital heart defect that is caused by downward displacement posterior and septal leaflets of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle.

As a result of the abnormal attachment, the right ventricle is divided into two parts. The part which is above the tricuspid valve is thinned out and is called atrialized ventricle. The abnormal tricuspid valve is responsible for tricuspid regurgitation and obstruction to the forward flow leading to an enlarged right atrium. Increased volume of blood in the right atrium causes right to left shunt through foramen ovale or associated ASD leading to cyanosis.

On auscultation, a holosystolic murmur is heard over the left anterior chest due to tricuspid regurgitation, and gallop rhythm (additional S3 and/or S4 sounds) is usually heard along the left sternal border. In some cases, a diastolic murmur resembling pericardial friction rub may be heard.

Other options:

  • ASD or atrial septal defect is an acyanotic heart disease
  • WPW syndrome may accompany Ebstein's anomaly, however, the condition is also associated with supraventricular tachycardia.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot- Right bundle branch block is not a part of the disease pathology. But it can be acquired after surgery (esp. Partial right ventriculotomy) done for the repair of TOF.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of hypopigmentation of the skin. On examination, there was hypopigmentation of the iris. Investigations reveal neutropenia. A peripheral smear was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows giant inclusions in polymorphonuclear neutrophils, which along with oculocutaneous albinism, and neutropenia is suggestive of Chediak-Higashi syndrome. 

It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to loss-of-function mutation of the LYST gene encoding a protein known as lysosomal trafficking regulator. There is a defective fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes, resulting in defective phagocyte function and susceptibility to infections.

Clinical features occur due to defective transport of cell products. These include:

  • Significant pyogenic infections
  • Albinism (due to abnormalities of melanocytes)
  • Neurological abnormalities
    • Progressive intellectual decline
    • Cranial nerve palsies
    • Decreased deep tendon reflexes
    • Tremor
    • Abnormal gait (nerve cell dysfunction),
  • Bleeding (due to platelet dysfunction).

Peroxidase‐positive giant inclusions are seen in leukocytes. The only curative treatment available for Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is bone marrow transplantation.

Other options

Option A: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency results in the failure of leukocyte adhesion to endothelium, preventing the cells from migrating into tissues. This results in recurrent bacterial infections.

Option B: Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in phagocytes oxidase which is required for the generation of superoxide. Its defect results in recurrent infections with catalase-positive microbes.

Option C: Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in early death.
