questions.text: Your friend is planning a trip to the mountains but is concerned because of her history of severe nausea and vomiting while traveling anywhere. Which of the following drugs would be the least effective in managing her condition?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ondansetron is the least effective in managing motion sickness.

Ondansetron is a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT and does not suppress vomiting caused by motion sickness. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. 

Drugs used in the treatment of motion sickness are:

  • Anticholinergic agents (muscarinic receptor antagonists) such as scopolamine (hyoscine) and dicyclomine.
  • Antihistamines (H1 antagonists) are primarily used for treating motion sickness and postoperative emesis.  

Scopolamine transdermal patches should be given prophylactically as it is less effective once symptoms start. It is applied behind the ear at least 4-12 hours before an anticipated exposure to motion. Dry mouth and sedation are common side effects.

First-generation antihistamines such as promethazine, dimenhydrinate, chlorpheniramine, diphenhydramine, cyclizine, and meclizine are effective in controlling nausea and vomiting in motion sickness. Sedation is a common side effect of these drugs. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine and fexofenadine are ineffective in the treatment of motion sickness.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient has undergone cataract surgery in his right eye 2 years back. Initially, after the surgery, his vision was good but started experiencing a progressive diminution in his vision for the past 3 months. Examination of his right eye is shown below. Which of the following laser is used in managing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image are suggestive of a posterior capsular opacification (PCO). It is managed by Nd: YAG laser capsulotomy.

PCO, also called 'after' or 'secondary' cataracts, is the opacification that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. This happens because, some amount of lens particles are left in situ during surgery, which proliferates and gets opacified, resulting in the formation of an after-cataract. If the newly formed fibers are enclosed between the two layers of the lens, a dense ring is formed behind the iris. This is named 'the ring of Sommerring'.Instead, if the cells proliferate to form large-balloon-like cells, filling the pupillary aperture, they are called Elschnig pearls.

Management of after-cataract:

Management of an after-cataract depends upon its thickness. A thin one can be cleared by Nd: YAG capsulotomy. The thicker ones are managed by, cutting with a Ziegler knife and the cut fragments are aspirated by a vitreous cutter.

The given image below shows the presence of a white ring behind the iris with the likely diagnosis being Soemmering’s ring.

 

The below image shows Elschnig’s pearls which are vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells, clustered like soap bubbles along the posterior capsule of the lens.

questions.text: A patient who had a parotid surgery now has complaints of sweating on his face whenever he smells or tastes food. The nerve responsible for this is shown in the image below. Identify the structure marked X in the image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked X in the image is the middle meningeal artery. The nerve marked in the image is the auriculotemporal nerve. The auriculotemporal nerve arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve and encircles the middle meningeal artery at its origin.

Gustatory sweating is known as Frey’s syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly develops after parotid surgery or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule. During the regrowth, an aberrant connection develops between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the sweat glands (great auricular nerve). This results in sweating, warmth and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.

questions.text: Mr. Kumar, a 60-year-old male had pain in the eye and visual disturbances 2 days after undergoing cataract surgery. The image of his eye is given below. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The image shows a picture of inflammation and hypopyon. This, along with the presentation of pain and visual disturbances acutely after cataract surgery suggest that the patient has developed endophthalmitis.

Endophthalmitis:

  • Cardinal features are pain, conjunctival or lid injection, and swelling and decrease in vision.
  • Postoperative endophthalmitis patient classically presents acutely within 7 days after surgery with inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and a hypopyon, due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber and posterior chamber.
  • The intravitreal injection of antibiotics has become the primary method of administration in the treatment of endophthalmitis. Other modalities of treatment include:
    • Topical antibiotic
    • Cycloplegia
    • Oral steroids
    • Pars plana vitrectomy

Toxic anterior segment syndrome is characterized by diffuse limbus-to-limbus corneal edema and anterior segment inflammation. The following points differentiate it from endophthalmitis

  • Vitreous inflammation is rare (vitreous inflammation present in endophthalmitis).
  • No pain/ little pain unless the IOP is very high. (Pain more often indicates endophthalmitis).
  • A fixed, dilated pupil–often with spotty or diffuse areas of iris atrophy. (Not seen in endophthalmitis)
  • Extremely high IOP early in the postoperative period is an unusual finding for endophthalmitis and points toward a diagnosis of TASS.
  • A therapeutic response to topical steroids is clearly present for several days in TASS, unlike in endophthalmitis, where the patient's condition worsens even after the application of topical steroids.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient with a history of maniac disorder with psychotic symptoms was brought to the outpatient department with a history of delusions and hallucinations for the last 3 weeks. His mood has been normal for the same duration. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The concurrent presence of psychotic symptoms together with mania in the past and a three-week episode of psychotic symptoms in the absence of mania is suggestive of schizoaffective disorder.

DSM-5 criteria:

  • An uninterrupted period of illness where there is a major mood episode (depression or mania) concurrent with psychosis that meet the criteria for schizophrenia (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, etc.)
  • Delusions or hallucinations (psychotic symptoms) for at least two weeks in the absence of a major depressive or manic episode during the lifetime course of the illness.
  • Major mood episode is present for the majority of total illness.
  • Not due to intake of substances or another medical condition.

Note: According to DSM-5 guidelines, for a definitive diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder, there have to be two psychotic episodes. One of the psychotic episodes has to be concurrent with a major mood episode (depression or manic).

The other psychotic episode should be for two or more weeks in the absence of a major mood episode. And the major mood episode should dominate the major part of the lifetime course of the illness.

Differential Diagnoses include:

  • Substance-induced disorder
  • Preexisting medical condition-induced disorder
  • Seizure disorder 

Family therapy, cognitive rehabilitation, and social skills training are beneficial. Mood stabilizers like lithium and antidepressants like SSRI - fluoxetine, and sertraline- are used for the management of schizoaffective disorder. Mood stabilizers can be used to manage episodes of mania. ECT can be given in case of intractable mania. Antipsychotics are helpful to manage psychotic symptoms.

Other options:

Option A- Schizophrenia is defined by a group of characterized symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, negative symptoms, determination of social, occupational, and interpersonal functioning, and continuous signs of the disturbances for at least 6 months. 

Option B- Schizophreniform disorder is described as acute psychiatric symptoms as in schizophrenia that were reactive and occurred in persons with relatively normal personalities that last at least 1 month but less than 6 months. 

Option D- Brief psychotic disorder is the sudden onset of psychotic behavior as in schizophrenia lasting for at least 1 day but less than 1 month.

questions.text: An epidemiologist addresses the importance of herd immunity during epidemics at a webinar on Vaccination. However, he points out an exception, saying that herd immunity doesn't protect an individual against ________
questions.solution:
Herd immunity doesn't protect against tetanus.

Herd immunity is a type of immunity that occurs when the vaccination of a portion of the population provides protection to unprotected individuals.

When a high level of herd immunity is maintained, the susceptible population is reduced to a small proportion, thereby eliminating the disease. Herd immunity achieved, especially through immunization for diseases like polio, diphtheria, and measles, goes a long way in helping the elimination of the disease. A large section of the population would be protected from the disease through herd immunity.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old male patient comes to your clinic with complaints of ringing in his ears and difficulty hearing for several months. He is a retired airforce pilot. History is significant for hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Otoscopic examination shows a normal tympanic membrane. Tuning fork tests are performed and an audiogram is requested. Which among the following statement/s are incorrect about this patient's most likely diagnosis?

1- It is caused due to damage to hair cells in the basal turn of cochlea.

2- Inner hair cells are affected before the outer hair cells.

3- Rinne's test will be negative.

4- Weber's test will show no lateralization.

5- Audiogram shows a characteristic acoustic dip at 2000Hz.
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette with a history of occupational exposure to loud noises is suggestive of noise-induced hearing loss. Among the given options, statements 2, 3, and 5 are incorrect. 

Repeated exposure to loud sounds or single exposure to loud sounds such as explosions, gun-shots etcetera, can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. A noise of 90 dB, for 8 hours a day for 5 days per week is the maximum safe limit as recommended by the Ministry of Labour, Govt. of India, Model Rules under Factories Act.

It is bilateral and is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells in the Organ of Corti. It causes damage to hair cells, starting in the basal turn of cochlea. Outer hair cells are affected before the inner hair cells.

Clinically, patients experience slowly progressive hearing loss that affects high frequencies first. They complain of difficulty in hearing in noisy surroundings. High-pitched tinnitus may be present. 

On examination, patients will show signs of bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and the following findings will be present-

  • Rinne's test- To perform Rinne's test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid process. Immediately after the patient stops hearing a tone, the tuning fork is held over the same ear and the patient is asked to report if they hear the tuning fork again. The same test is repeated on the other side. Patients with noise-induced hearing loss will show a positive Rinne's test, meaning the air conduction is better than bone conduction (AC>BC) in both ears.
  • Weber's test- To perform Weber's test, the vibrating tuning fork is then placed on the middle of the forehead and the patient is asked if they hear the sound in the center of their head. In noise-induced hearing loss, Weber's test will show no lateralization, meaning the sound is heard equally on both sides. 

The pure tone audiogram in noise-induced hearing loss will show a characteristic acoustic dip at 4000Hz for both air conduction and bone conduction as shown in the image below. This is referred to as Acoustic Dip or Boiler’s notch

It is irreversible and is managed with hearing aids. 

Related Pearl: Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to a noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of cramping pain on walking. Peripheral vascular disease was suspected. However, his ABPI was normal. What is the next step in the management?

choices.text: Exercise testing followed by ABPI calculation
Reassure the patient and send home
Calculate ABPI of the other limb

questions.solution:
If ABPI is normal in a patient with strong clinical suspicion of peripheral vascular disease then post-exercise ABPI is calculated. A fall in ABPI >20% after exercise is indicative of flow-limiting arterial disease

The ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm. The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery. The brachial systolic pressure in the ipsilateral arm is the denominator.

Interpretation:

  • >0.9 – Normal
  • <0.9 – Claudication
  • <0.5 – Rest pain
  • <0.4 – Imminent necrosis (Critical Limb Ischemia)
  • >1.4 - Calcification of arterial wall

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) - 

PAD presents as intermittent claudication, which is pain that increases with walking and may sometimes present with rest pain. It is generally caused by atherosclerosis but may also be due to trauma. The initial investigation done is an ABPI. Physical exam findings include atrophied skin, pallor on the raising leg (Buerger's test), nail changes, and decreased peripheral pulses.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with intense itching in the ear, pain, and watery discharge with a musty odor. On examination, black-headed filamentous growth was seen resembling wet blotting paper. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario is otomycosis. 

Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the external ear caused commonly by Aspergillus niger, A.fumigatus, or Candida albicans. It is frequently seen in tropical areas and in individuals who use antibiotic drops to treat otitis media/ otitis externa.

Patients present with intense pruritus, discomfort, pain, blocked sensation in the ear, and foul-smelling watery discharge. Otoscopy will show a fungal mass whose appearance depends on the causative organism.

  • Aspergillus niger can be seen as a black-headed, filamentous growth.
  • Aspergillus fumigatus presents as a pale blue or green mass.
  • Candida appears as a white, creamy mass in the ear.

Aural toileting and topical antifungal agents are the primary treatment. Nystatin, clotrimazole, and povidone-iodine are the commonly used antifungals. 2% salicylic acid in alcohol works as a keratolytic to remove the superficial layers of the epidermis along with the fungal mycelia.

Other options:

Option B: Diffuse otitis externa occurs due to bacterial infection of the external ear. It presents as severe pain worsening with jaw movement, discharge of purulent material, and conductive hearing loss. In the chronic phase, meatal skin can undergo scaling and fissuring. 

Option C: Otitis externa hemorrhagica is probably viral in origin. It presents with severe pain and blood-stained discharge due to the rupture of hemorrhagic bullae on the tympanic membrane and meatus.

Option D: Malignant otitis externa occurs due to infection by pseudomonas commonly in diabetics and patients with immunosuppression. Symptoms are similar to otitis externa but examination will reveal granulations in the external auditory canal. It can cause facial nerve paralysis and has a high tendency to spread.

questions.text:
The oral exam of an unvaccinated 7-year-old with fever and sore throat appears as below. Attempts to remove this pseudomembranous substance result in bleeding. A rapid strep test on a throat swab is negative. He has a documented history of allergy to penicillin and cephalosporins. Which of the following statements is/ are true about the anti-microbial drug he should be started on?
  1. It is a prototype drug for the macrolide group.
  2. It should be always administered on empty stomach for better bio-availability. 
  3. Efflux and methylase production mechanisms are chiefly responsible for resistance in the drug. 
  4. It has a therapeutic paradox in the treatment of diabetic gastroparesis.
  5. Its dose needs to be altered in patients with renal failure.
questions.solution:
This is a classic clinical description and oral examination findings of a patient with diphtheria. Diphtheria is principally treated using Penicillin. In the case of penicillin resistance or allergy, erythromycin is the preferred agent. The correct statements are 1, 3, and 4. 

Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic. It is a bacteriostatic agent that inhibits protein synthesis by binding reversibly to 50S ribosomal subunits of sensitive microorganisms.

It is commonly used for the treatment of gram-positive infections. Erythromycin is the drug of choice in diphtheria when a patient is allergic to penicillin. Erythromycin is also used for the treatment of atypical pneumonia. It is given for prophylaxis of endocarditis and rheumatic fever in people with valvular heart disease and allergic to penicillin respectively. Azithromycin is still preferred over erythromycin.

Food and gastric acid both affect erythromycin absorption and bio-availability. Hence, it is always given as an enteric-coated formulation. The drug can be taken both before food and after food, but the latter is preferred. Erythromycin activity is increased to several-fold in an alkaline medium which can be achieved after food when stomach acid is neutralized by food and alkaline chyme begins to form. Dose adjustment is not necessary for patients with renal failure as it is excreted in bile.

It can cross the placenta and affect the fetus and is preferably avoided in pregnancy.  Erythromycin inhibits the CYP450 enzyme system and thus inhibits the metabolism of theophylline, warfarin, cyclosporine, and methylprednisolone, thereby leading to their toxicity. Erythromycin increases serum concentrations of oral digoxin by increasing its bioavailability. 

Erythromycin stimulates GI motility by acting on motilin receptors and causes GI disturbances in the form of diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. This therapeutic paradox has led to Erythromycin's off-label use as a prokinetic agent in the intensive care setting and in patients with diabetic gastroparesis and clearence of bezoars. 

Resistance to Erythromycin:

Resistance to erythromycin is mediated by plasmids. There are three mechanisms involved in the development of resistance. These include:

  1. Active efflux
  2. Production of esterases that hydrolyze macrolide by Enterobacteriaceae. 
  3. Modification of the ribosomal binding site (chromosomal mutation or constitutive methylase production)

Efflux and methylase production mechanisms are chiefly responsible for resistance in the drug. Cross-resistance is also seen with other macrolides. The production of Methylase is responsible for resistance to Streptogramin B and Clindamycin. This is collectively called - MLS type B resistance (Macrolides, Lincosamides, Streptogramin-B).

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman came to the local emergency department with severe headache and stiffness of the neck. The CSF specimen is cloudy. While in the emergency room, an intern performs gram stain of the CSF but by mistake forgets the step in which iodine is added. Assuming that the women has meningitis caused by streptococcus pneumoniae,  how would the bacteria on the intern’s slide appear?

choices.text: No gram stain results would be obtained due to lysis of all cells

questions.solution:
In the above question, the intern forgot to add iodine, i.e., the second step of gram staining. As a result, the purple iodine-dye complex will not form, and the entire crystal violet dye will wash away during the decolorization step. Now when the safranin is added, all the cells will stain red.

The various steps in gram staining are as follows:

  • The crystal violet dye (basic dye) stains all cells purple.
  • The iodine solution (a mordant) is added to form a crystal violet–iodine complex. At the end of this step, all cells continue to appear purple.
  • In the decolorization step, the organic solvent, such as acetone or ethanol, extracts the blue dye complex from the lipid-rich, thin-walled gram-negative bacteria to a greater degree than from the lipid-poor, thick-walled gram-positive bacteria. At the end of this step, the gram-negative organisms appear colorless; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.
  • The red dye safranin (counterstain) stains the decolorized gram-negative cells red/pink; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.

questions.text: An X-ray of a patient with pulmonary hypertension is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows an anomalous draining vein parallel to the right heart border(Scimitar sign) which is suggestive of partial anomalous pulmonary venous return.

Partial anomalous pulmonary venous connection (PAPVC), is a rare congenital cardiovascular condition in which some of the pulmonary veins drain into the systemic circulation rather than in the left atrium.

On chest X-ray, the abnormal vein is rarely identified, except in cases of Scimitar syndrome aka Congenital Venolobar Syndrome which is a type of partial anomalous pulmonary venous return. It is characterized by lung hypoplasia and ipsilateral anomalous systemic venous drainage. An anomalous pulmonary vein, usually on the right, drains into the inferior vena cava, portal vein, coronary sinus, or right atrium.

Most of the patients are asymptomatic but the anomalous venous return constitutes a left-to-right shunt and can lead to pulmonary hypertension.

The easiest way to answer these types of questions would be by ruling out the other options. Here, the other options are conditions whose characteristic X-ray appearance is typically expected to be known.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted with altered sensorium, hydrophobia, and seizures after he was bitten by a stray dog 4 weeks ago. The patient passed away and an autopsy was performed. Identify the layer of the cerebellar cortex in which the pathognomic intracellular inclusion bodies are usually seen.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is that of rabies encephalitis and the pathognomic intracellular inclusion bodies (Negri bodies) are seen in Purkinje cells belonging to the Purkinje cell layer (Layer C).

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers histologically. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer that contains stellate cells and basket cells, and dendrites of Purkinje cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers. It appears pale on H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - contain the cell bodies of the Purkinje cells which are flask-shaped. Characteristics of Purkinje cells:
    • Flask-shaped, evenly spaced cells arranged in a single layer.
    • The only efferents of the cerebellar cortex.
    • A dendrite from the neck of each flask-shaped cell passes upward to the molecular layer and the axon passes down through the granular layer to the white matter.
    • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches from the T are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. It also contains Golgi cells that receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Rabies presents initially with fever and paraesthesia near the bite, following which the patient becomes increasingly anxious, leading to hydrophobia, delusions, and hallucinations. On microscopic examination of the brain, there is neuronal degeneration with inflammation. Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions seen in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. (seen below)

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with a history of swelling over the anterior part of the neck, fatigue, and weight loss for two months. On examination, the mass moves with deglutition. A biopsy from the patient's thyroid gland is shown below. Investigations reveal elevated plasma metanephrines, serum calcium, PTH, and calcitonin. She also gives a history of her mother undergoing surgery for a lump in the neck many years before. Which of the following is likely to result in the above condition?

choices.text: Gain of function mutation in RET
Loss of function mutation in RET
Gain of function mutation in K-RAS
Loss of function mutation in K-RAS

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes the features of MEN 2A syndrome, which includes medullary thyroid carcinoma (The given histopathology picture shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma and family history of thyroid surgery), parathyroid adenoma (elevated serum calcium, PTH, and calcitonin) and pheochromocytoma (elevated plasma metanephrines). The gain of function mutations in RET proto-oncogene occurs in MEN 2A syndrome.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia is characterised by the presence of tumors in two or more endocrine glands. It can be MEN 1, MEN 2A, MEN 2B (MEN 3), or MEN 4.

MEN 1 is associated mainly with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

MEN type 2 comprises groups of disorders caused by gain-of-function mutations of the RET proto-oncogene at chromosomal locus 10q11.2. There are three variants:

  • MEN 2A, also known as MEN 2 (most common type)
  • MEN 2B, also known as MEN 3
  • MTC only

MEN 2A is also known as Sipple's syndrome. It is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid tumors.

MEN 2B is characterised by MTC, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres, and megacolon.

MEN 4 is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and reproductive organ tumors.

Other options

Option B: Loss of function mutation of RET gene leads to Hirschprung disease.

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

questions.text: A dead person was brought for autopsy with suspicion of murder. The police suspected that he was hit on the head after which he was thrown in front of a lorry. On examination, there were multiple fractures on his skull. Which rule is used to determine the sequence of fractures in that skull?
questions.solution:
The sequence of bullet injuries is given by Puppe’s rule.

Puppe’s rule: It is possible to determine the sequence of injuries in skull fractures caused by blunt injuries to the head because the second fracture ends at the point where a break in cohesion is already present. The fracture lines created by every other shot extend only up to the fractured lines produced by the previous shot without continuing over them. Even though this rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, it is of particular importance in gunshot wounds. 

Other options

Option A: Nysten's rule:

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. The basic sequence of the rigor mortis begins from the head down the body, in that order. It disappears in the same order of appearance.

The order of appearance of rigor mortis:

  1. Involuntary muscles: Heart
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

Option C: Durham's rule: An accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

Option D:  Casper's dictum: The ratio of the rate of putrefaction of a dead body in air, water, and buried in the ground is 1:2:8.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with complaints of poor scholastic performance and episodes of sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control. No confusion is reported after regaining consciousness. Episodes are precipitated by hyperventilation. Which of the following drug is preferred in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child presenting with brief lapses of consciousness without loss of postural control, no postictal confusion, and episodes provoked by hyperventilation are suggestive of typical absence seizures. Among the given options, ethosuximide is the first-line agent for the treatment of typical absence seizures

Ethosuximide inhibits the T-type calcium currents in thalamic neurons and thus reduces the absence seizures.

Absence seizures are of two types

Typical absence seizures which are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without loss of postural control. They last for only a few seconds and consciousness returns immediately. It is usually accompanied by subtle motor signs such as rapid blinking of eyelids, chewing movements, or clonic movements of the hands. It is usually described as unexplained daydreaming. EEG reveals a 3Hz spike and slow wave discharges precipitated by hyperventilation. Ethosuximide, valproate and lamotrigine are used in the management.

Atypical absence seizures are characterized by less abrupt onset and cessation, longer duration of lapse in consciousness, and are usually accompanied by obvious motor signs. Valproic acid, lamotrigine, and topiramate are used in the management.

Other options:

Option A- Levetiracetam is used for focal and generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS). 

Option B- Lacosamide is used as an adjuvant in focal seizures.

Option D- Carbamazepine is used in patients with GTCS seizures.

questions.text: A consultant asked a junior resident to assess the ease of endotracheal intubation in a patient to be operated. The findings were similar to the schematic image given below. The resident should grade the oral opening as Mallampati class ___________
questions.solution:
Since the soft palate, the base of the uvula, and the hard palate are seen, this is graded as Mallampati class III.

The Modified Mallampati classification is used to predict difficulty in tracheal intubation. It is based on the size of the base of the tongue. During the assessment, the patient has to be seated, with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruding, and no phonation. In this position, the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate is assessed and assigned a class from I-IV. 

The initial Mallampati classification included only classes I-III. It was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class IV. In addition to classes I-IV, a fifth class also exists called class 0. In this, the epiglottis can be seen when the mouth is opened and the tongue is protruded.

Higher scores indicate poor visibility of these structures due to the presence of a large tongue. Thus, Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati classes III and IV are considered features of a difficult airway.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding Telomerase?

choices.text: It is present in eukaryotes only
It is a RNA dependent DNA polymerase
It is an example for a ribozyme

questions.solution:
Telomerase is not a ribozyme.

Telomeres are the end of chromosomal DNA. Since prokaryotic DNA is circular, it does not have free ends and no telomeres. It is present only in eukaryotes 

Telomeres have TG- rich repeats and usually do not code for any proteins. With every DNA replication during cell division, telomere shortening occurs. Once telomeres are almost negligible or non-existent in length, the DNA is unable to replicate and the cell dies. Hence there is a limit to the number of times a cell can divide.

Telomerase is an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase( reverse transcriptase) and recognizes the 3' end of the telomere. It helps in the replication of telomeres. In old age, the telomerase activity is lost leading to chromosome instability and cell death.

In stem cells and cancer cells, enzyme telomerase having reverse transcriptase activity (RNA-dependent DNA polymerase) adds telomeres to the chromosome ends, thereby preserving the length. It allows the stem cells and cancer cells to multiply a lot more times than a normal adult cell.

A ribozyme is RNA with catalytic activity. Some examples of ribozymes are:

  • Sn Rna in the spliceosome.
  • Ribonuclease P
  • Peptidyl transferase
  • RNAse H

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the reticulate body of Chlamydia?
questions.solution:
The reticulate body of chlamydia is a growing and replicative form.

Chlamydia is a gram-negative coccobacillus that has the following features-

  • They are obligate intracellular organisms as they lack the enzymes for ATP synthesis, and are hence dependent entirely on the host cell. 
  • They can exist in two states.
    • The extracellular infective form is called the elementary body.
    • The intracellular non-infective form is called the reticulate body. These reticulate bodies are found inside a membrane-bound compartment called the "inclusion body" which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells by iodine or Giemsa stain. The cell of the reticulate body is fragile and pliable, leading to pleomorphism.
  • They are small bacteria about 0.2-0.3 microns in size and are hence filtrable through the pore size of standard bacterial filters.

questions.text: A biochemist performs the cyanide nitroprusside test on a non-essential purely glucogenic amino acid. The test is positive for the same. Identify the amino acid being tested.
questions.solution:
Cysteine is a non-essential, glucogenic amino acid that tests positive for nitroprusside reaction.

Cyanide nitroprusside test

Cyanide nitroprusside breaks the S-S bond (disulfide bond) and releases free sulfhydryl groups which react with sodium nitroprusside to give a reddish color. The test is positive for cysteine.

Sulfur test can also be performed to detect free sulfhydryl groups.

Other options:

Option A: Glycine is a non-essential, purely glucogenic amino acid and tests negative for nitroprusside reaction. It does not contain the sulfhydryl group. 

Option C: Threonine is an essential, purely glucogenic amino acid. It contains a hydroxyl group and hence tests negative for nitroprusside reaction

Option D: Tyrosine is a non-essential, both glucogenic and ketogenic amino acid. It contains a phenol group and hence tests negative for nitroprusside reaction.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child while playing challenges his younger brother to keep on inspiring until he says to stop. Due to intact Hering-Breuer reflex activation, the younger child could not inspire continuously for a longer time. This reflex will not be activated until his tidal volume reaches:
questions.solution:
Hering-Breuer reflex probably is not activated until the tidal volume increases to more than three times normal (>≈1.5 liters per breath). Therefore, this reflex appears to be mainly a protective mechanism for preventing excess lung inflation

In the Hering-Breuer inflation reflex, prolonged inspiration inhibits further inspiration. Hyperinflation of the lungs stimulates slowly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors and the impulses travel in the vagus nerve via large myelinated fibers. This signal inhibits the inspiratory ramp signals of the dorsal respiratory group of neurons (DRG), thus, inspiration is quickly inhibited and expiration follows. It cuts down the inspiration time, and prevents overinflation of the lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the reflex depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the inverse stretch reflex and it can be stimulated by a passive stretch as well as an active contraction (Option D).

When the tension in the muscle increases and surpasses a limit, contraction suddenly ceases and the muscle relaxes. This relaxation in response to an overt stretch is called the inverse stretch reflex.

The receptor involved in this reflex is the Golgi tendon organ (Option B). The Golgi tendon organ consists of a net-like collection of nerve endings that are arranged in series (Option C) within the muscle fibers. This arrangement allows for Golgi tendon organs to be stimulated by both active contraction and passive stretch of the muscle, unlike muscle spindles. One Golgi tendon organ innervates 3-25 muscle fibers. 

The afferents from the Golgi tendon organ are the Ib myelinated nerve fibers. The Ib nerve fibers synapse with inhibitory interneurons present in the spinal cord, which in turn synapse with the motor neurons supplying the muscles. Thus, this is a disynaptic reflex (Option A).

questions.text: A physician visits a patient who is bedridden for the past 5 years. On examination, there is a bedsore in the sacral area with full-thickness skin loss. What is the stage of the pressure sore in this patient?
questions.solution:
Here the patient is having full-thickness skin loss, which is suggestive of stage 3 pressure sore.

Pressure Sores (Bedsores/Pressure ulcers/Decubitus ulcers).

These can be defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. Common sites for pressure sores include ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral>medial), and occiput.

The grading system for the description of pressure sores:

Category 1 - Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
Category 2 - Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
Category 3 - Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
Category 4 - Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon, or joint.

Management:

Pressure sores can be prevented with good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special pressure-dispersion cushions, or foams. Repositioning the patient every two hours can lessen the pressure on the area. 

Ulcers of stages I and II often do not require operative measures. The main aim of treatment for pressure ulcers is:

  • To reduce the pressure exerted on the ulcer.
  • Decrease moisture.
  • To keep it as aseptic or least septic as possible.

The ulcer should be cleaned and drained to remove any dead tissue and debris. Good antibiotic cover and hydrocolloid dressing are useful.

Stage 3 and 4 ulcers may require surgical intervention. Surgical management of pressure sores follows the same principles involved in acute wound treatment. Prior to the operation, the pressure sores should be adequately debrided, and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) can be used to promote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presented to OPD with the lesions as shown in the image below. There is no history of itching or bleeding. Which of the following micronutrient deficiency can result in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows peri-oral and per-genital dermatitis in a 1-year-old boy which is suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica. This results due to a deficiency in zinc.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder where zinc absorption is defective.

It is characterized by anorexia, diarrhea, failure to thrive, humoral and cell-mediated immunodeficiency (poor wound healing, recurrent infections), male hypogonadism, skin lesions (vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and perirectal, peri-genital, and perioral regions, and alopecia), and neurologic abnormalities (tremor, apathy, depression, irritability, nystagmus, photophobia, night blindness, and hypogeusia).

Management includes long-term treatment with elemental zinc at 1 mg/kg/day.

Other options

Option B: Selenium deficiency causes Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy in endemic regions of China); Excess selenium intake leads to selenosis (with hair loss, brittle nails, garlic breath odor, myopathy, and neurologic symptoms).

Option C: Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. The lesion in the neck is characteristic of Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in Pellagra. The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).

Option D: Iron deficiency is the most common micronutrient deficiency globally. It presents with iron-deficiency anemia and neurocognitive impairment. It presents clinically with pallor, fatigue, atrophic glossitis, and pica.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient with chronic kidney disease suddenly develops chest pain and palpitations. ECG of the patient is shown below. What is the immediate management of this condition?

choices.text: Administer intravenous regular Insulin with dextrose

questions.solution:
A chronic kidney disease (CKD) patient with chest pain, palpitations, and ECG showing tall, peaked T waves and loss of P waves indicates that the patient is suffering from hyperkalemia. The immediate management is to administer intravenous calcium gluconate which raises the threshold and reduces excitability.

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium level of more than 5.5 mEq/L. 

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

Serum potassium level ECG change
5.5 - 6.5 mEq/L tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
6.5 - 7.5 mEq/L loss of P waves
7.0 - 8.0 mEq/L widened QRS complex
> 8.0 mEq/L sine wave

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, potassium-sparing diuretics. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Salbutamol nebulization will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

questions.text: A 20-day-old neonate is brought with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. On ocular examination, he has a large and hazy cornea along with Haab's striae in both eyes. This Haab's striae is seen in which of the following corneal layer?
questions.solution:
The given condition is congenital glaucoma and the Haab's striae is seen in Descemet's membrane.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) when intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%) manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma when IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age. This is the least common type.

PCG can present with a corneal haze that occurs due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP. Buphthalmos (large eye) occurs due to elevated IOP and stretching of the eye prior to the age of 3 years. Curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane are known as Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur. Evaluation under general anesthesia is usually required. 

Management is essentially surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy. When these angle surgeries fail other procedures including trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures may be done.

questions.text: A school teacher finds a 7 yr old child to be extremely naughty, unable to sit in a place for a long time, excessively talking, and unable to concentrate on a thing for a long time. Which of the following drug is used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD). The drug of choice for ADHD is Methylphenidate.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuro­ psychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its etiology and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

ADHD can begin during infancy but is usually rec­ognized between 1-3 years of age. ADHD was known as minimal brain dysfunction earlier. The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits.

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may sometimes disappear, but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems usually persist. Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to antisocial behavior, conduct disorder, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.

Pharmacotherapy is the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate, amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (Alpha agonists).

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behavior modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as an adjunct to pharmacotherapy.

Note: Modafinil is used in the management of narcolepsy.

Osteogenesis imperfecta is inherited as a dominant trait. It is the result of a mutation that results in the replacement of a single glycine residue by cysteine in Type I collagen. The result is brittle bones leading to multiple fractures and skeletal deformities.

Ehler-Danlos syndrome is due to defective Type III collagen formation due to defective lysyl oxidase or lysyl hydroxylase. It is characterized by the weakening of collagen, loose skin, and hypermobile and lax joints. Hyperextensibility of skin and joints are the hallmark of this condition.

Alport syndrome is due to a defect in type IV collagen. It is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss, anterior lenticonus, and renal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 26-year-old P1L1  woman is diagnosed with abnormal uterine bleeding. Considering she has not completed her family, which of these treatment methods will be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Mirena will be the most appropriate method of treatment in a young woman with AUB (desirous of preserving fertility) as the rest of the options are ablative procedures.

Ablative procedures are safe, effective with less morbidity, and quicker recovery and the method destroys 2-3 mm of the myometrium. But, fertility is not possible following ablative procedures.

 

Advantages of Mirena IUCD over ablative techniques:

  • Low cost
  • OPD procedure: No hospitalization
  • Preservation of fertility after its removal

Other options:

NovaSure (impedance-controlled endometrial ablation) is the latest and most safe procedure, taking just 90 sec. It uses bipolar radiofrequency and vaporizes endometrium up to myometrium.

Vesta system. This system uses a single-use multi-electrode intrauterine balloon to ablate the endometrium.

questions.text: A researcher conducts a cross sectional study to determine the prevalence of lactose intolerance in a population. Which of the following is true about this type of study?

choices.text: The rate of occurrence of new cases is accounted for
Follow-up examinations need to be done
The natural history of disease can be determined
They are more useful for chronic diseases

questions.solution:
The prevalence of a disease is calculated using cross-sectional studies which are more useful for chronic diseases.

A cross-sectional study is a type of observational study where a cross-section of a population is examined once at one point in time. It is used to calculate a disease's distribution and prevalence. Prevalence helps to estimate the magnitude of health/ disease problems in the community and identify potential high-risk populations. Cross-sectional studies are more useful in studying chronic diseases than acute ones (Option D). These studies do not establish a time sequence and provide no information on the natural history of disease or the rate of occurrence of new cases.

Longitudinal studies are done by repeatedly observing the same population over a prolonged period of time by means of follow-up examinations (Option B). They are useful in studying the natural history of disease and the rate of occurrence of new cases. (Option A and C)

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady comes to the OPD with complaints of fever, abdominal pain and itching over her arms and legs. On examination, there is presence of icterus and mild hepatomegaly. Liver function test shows deranged values. A liver biopsy shows the following findings. The patient also tests positive for anti-nuclear antibodies and an elevated level of serum IgG. Which of the following features is not present in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with a positive ANA test and increased serum IgG levels with histopathology showing interface hepatitis, a cluster of plasma cells and lymphocytes at the interface between the portal tract and liver lobule, indicates Autoimmune hepatitis(AIH). All the features are found in AIH except “ground glass” hepatocytes which are characteristically found in Hepatitis B and is a diagnostic hallmark.

Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. The pathologic features include:

  • Emperipolesis - Lymphocytes and plasma cells within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes.
  • Interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis.
  • Rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration.

Bile duct injury and granulomas are uncommon except in case of overlap with primary biliary cirrhosis.

Based on the types of autoantibodies present, autoimmune hepatitis is subclassified as types 1 and 2 :

  • Type 1 disease (more common overall) -
    • Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) 
    • Anti–smooth muscle actin (SMA) antibodies
    • Antibodies against soluble liver antigen/liver-pancreas antigen (SLA/LPA)
    • Less commonly, anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA, more typical of primary biliary cholangitis) also may be seen. 
  • Type 2 disease (more common in children) - 
    • Anti liver-kidney-microsome-1 (LKM-1) antibodies, which are directed against CYP2D6
    • Anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) antibodies.

The simplified scoring system for the diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis includes four variables. They are:

  1. Autoantibodies
  2. Elevated serum IgG level
  3. Typical compatible histologic features
  4. Absence of viral hepatitis markers

A small number of drugs such as minocycline, nitrofurantoin, and α-methyldopa can trigger the formation of autoantibodies and hepatocellular injury that mimics autoimmune hepatitis.

The different patterns of liver injury:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of refeeding syndrome?

choices.text: Increase in renal excretion of sodium
Sudden lowering of serum potassium, magnesium, and phosphate concentrations

questions.solution:
In the case of refeeding syndrome, there is a  decrease in renal excretion of sodium.

Refeeding syndrome is a complication of the acute nutritional rehabilitation of children who are undernourished from any cause, and it may follow overly aggressive enteral or parenteral alimentation. 

When excessive carbohydrates are administered, the resultant hyperglycemia (Option A) increases serum insulin levels (Option D). Insulin activates the sodium-potassium ATPase symporter which allows potassium to enter the cells. Magnesium and phosphate are also taken up by the cells. This leads to a decrease in the serum levels of phosphate, potassium, and magnesium (Option C) along with a release of sodium from the cells. The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia.

The released sodium and decreased renal excretion of sodium, both contribute to extracellular and plasma volume expansion. The hallmark of refeeding syndrome is the development of severe hypophosphatemia.

questions.text: A 39-year-old morbidly-obese female patient presented with deranged liver function test. Ultrasound showed a grade 2 fatty liver with hepatic fibrosis and inflammation. She is non-diabetic, non-hypertensive, and has no history of smoking or drinking. A diagnosis of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) has been made. Which of the following drugs can be used as the first-line treatment in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is considered the first-line treatment for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) for non-diabetic patients.

Alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is the first-line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). In many studies, vitamin E was well-tolerated, showed modest improvements in AST levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH.

  • Vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic NASH patients.
  • Dose: 800 IU/day.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be caused due to the effect of toxins (including certain medications), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, methotrexate, doxycycline, and l-Asparaginase are other drugs causing hepatic steatosis.

Most of the patients with NAFLD and NASH are asymptomatic. They are usually diagnosed incidentally on routine blood work. Some patients with NASH can present with right upper quadrant pain due to stretching of the liver capsule from hepatomegaly, or acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance or with signs like palmar erythema, spider telangiectasia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and ascites if they have liver cirrhosis. Currently, a biopsy is the gold standard investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH (like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia). Thiazolidinediones help in improving adipocyte insulin sensitivity and preventing inappropriate lipolysis but have side effects like weight gain and osteoporosis. For patients with morbid obesity, bariatric surgery can be done. In patients with decompensated cirrhosis, liver transplantation is can be considered. 

Other options:

Option A- Ursodeoxycholic acid (a bile acid that improves certain cholestatic liver diseases) and omega-3 fatty acids show no histologic benefit in the management of NASH.

Option C- Metformin is not currently recommended as a treatment for NASH as it has not been known to improve liver histology.

Option D- N-acetylcysteine(NAC) is a specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It has maximum efficacy when given within 8 hours and can be given either via the oral or intravenous route.

Note: The FDA in 2024 has approved Resmetirom, a thyroid hormone receptor-beta (THR-beta) agonist for noncirrhotic NASH with moderate to advanced fibrosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy result is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and histological image are suggestive of Barrett’s esophagus.

The histological image above shows the transition between normal squamous epithelium and the mucin-filled glands, indicating intestinal-type metaplasia with plenty of goblet cells.

Barrett’s esophagus, which is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa. It is a premalignant condition that confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Hence, patients diagnosed with Barrett’s esophagus must be subjected to a regular surveillance endoscopy annually or with 2-year intervals, provided no dysplasias have been detected. The presence of dysplasia is associated with prolonged symptoms, longer affected segment length, increased patient age, and caucasian race.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not correct regarding the Schultze method of placental separation?

choices.text: The separation begins at the centre of the placenta.
The fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
The maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
There is a formation of retroplacental clot.

questions.solution:
The below image A shows the Schultze method of placental separation. In this method, the fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

Placental separation occurs during the third stage of labor. There are two mechanisms by which placental separation may occur:

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as Schultze method

B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

Schultze method:

The process of separation begins at the center of the placenta (fetal surface). Consequently, this central part descends first and becomes visible at the vulva. During this phase, blood gathers in a membranous sac located behind the placenta, resulting in the creation of a retroplacental clot. Bleeding does not happen until the placenta is fully expelled

Mathews-Duncan method:

Placental separation begins at the periphery of the placenta, leading to the maternal surface becoming visible first. Blood gathers between the membranes and the uterine wall and is discharged through the vagina. Unlike the previous method, there is no development of a retroplacental clot, resulting in significant bleeding during this type of placental separation. However, it is less frequent compared to the Schultze method.

questions.text: A sexually active male presented with warts on his penis as shown below. Which of these strains of HPV is the most common cause of these lesions?
questions.solution:
Human papillomavirus 6 & 11 (6 >11) are the most common cause of anogenital warts (also known as Condyloma Accuminata).

Giant Anogenital warts are known as Buschke Lowenstein Tumor. It is more common in males than in females.

Most common site:

  • In males: Frenulum, corona, glans penis
  • In females: Posterior fourchette

On histology, koilocytes are seen as shown below.

These are squamous epithelial cells that have nuclear enlargement, irregular nuclear membrane, hyperchromasia, and perinuclear halo.

Most of these warts resolve spontaneously. Persistent warts might transform into malignancy most commonly when infected with HPV 16 and 18.

Treatment:

Provider administered:

  1. Podophyllin (25%) - Antimitotic drug
  2. Trichloroacetic acid
  3. Cryotherapy

Both trichloroacetic acid and cryotherapy are safe in pregnancy.

Patient administered:

  1. Purified podophyllin called podophyllotoxin
  2. Imiquimod - Immunomodulator which acts on toll-like receptors 7 and 8

questions.text: In a person with hearing impairment, brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) was performed. Wave IV in the given image corresponds to the activity of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Wave IV of the given image corresponds to activity in the superior olivary nucleus.

Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is an objective and non-invasive method of hearing assessment that detects electrical activity from the inner ear to the inferior colliculus. 

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: Jersey finger is due to injury of _______

choices.text: Extensor tendon over the DIP joint

questions.solution:
The Jersey finger is caused by the rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus from the distal phalanx.

It occurs when there is hyperextension of the flexed finger trapped in a jersey. On physical examination, the finger lies in slight extension relative to other fingers in the resting position and no active flexion of DIP is possible.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presented with sudden onset headache with 10/10 intensity. She does not have any vision disturbances, photophobia, or watering eyes. A non-contrast CT of the head was performed and found to be normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as she has a sudden onset, intense headache of 10/10 intensity without any visual disturbances, photophobia, or watering eyes. Patients usually describe these headaches as ‘the worst headache they’ve had in their entire life.’ The best next step in management is to perform a lumbar puncture.

Most cases of SAH are usually diagnosed with a non-contrast head CT. However, if high suspicion for SAH remains after an initial negative non-contrast head CT, then a lumbar puncture should be performed. Visual inspection of the CSF will reveal xanthochromia. However, this can only be seen 6-12 hours after the onset of SAH. However, lumbar puncture should only be performed as first-line testing if CT facilities are unavailable. 

If the SAH is due to a ruptured aneurysm, the patient must undergo a 4-vessel x-ray angiography (both carotids and both vertebral arteries) to localize the aneurysm and identify other potential unruptured aneurysms. Alternatively, CT angiography can be performed. Definitive treatment includes endovascular coiling or aneurysmal clipping. 

Other options: 

Option A - A repeat non-contrast head CT is unlikely to reveal new information and will just subject the patient to unnecessary radiation also CT scan is more sensitive in the initial hours for SAH.

Option C - 100% oxygen inhalation is used to treat cluster headaches. This patient is unlikely to have a cluster headache as it is not an episodic retro-orbital headache. Cluster headache is usually associated with conjunctival injection or excessive lacrimation.

Option D- Sumatriptan is a selective 5HT 1B/1D receptor agonist that can be used in combination to treat acute migraine headaches. This patient is unlikely to have a migraine as she does not have any of the accompanying symptoms (aura) of visual disturbances or photophobia and 10/10 intensity is more characteritsic of SAH

questions.text: A patient who has been administered epidural analgesia is found to have a unilateral block. Which of the following measures would you take first?

choices.text: Administer a repeat bolus of drugs as the dose is likely to be insufficient
Position the patient on her side with the unblocked side down and then attempt mild repositioning of catheter
Remove the epidural catheter as it indicates a failed block and convert to spinal anesthesia instead
Make the patient sit erect for 10 more minutes after securing the catheter in place to avoid displacement

questions.solution:
In cases where there is a unilateral block, positioning the patient on her side with the unblocked side down and attempting mild repositioning of the catheter would be the best initial methods.

The patient should be positioned on their side with the unblocked side down before giving a top-up bolus as this helps the local anesthetic spread with gravity to the downward side and improves the effectiveness.

If this proves ineffective then one can withdraw the catheter by 1cm, so as to alter the catheter position within the epidural space in order to allow the anesthetic to spread more effectively.

questions.text: An elderly male patient was found to have hallucinations and vivid dreams following induction with an intravenous anesthetic agent. Which among the following is the most effective drug to reduce the incidence and severity of these post-operative reactions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of emergence reaction or delirium most commonly associated with ketamine. Benzodiazepines are the most effective in reducing the incidence and severity of these postoperative reactions.

Emergence reactions seen with ketamine during emergence from anesthesia are vivid dreaming, hallucinations, extracorporeal experiences, and delusions associated with confusion, euphoria, and fear. These reactions occur in individuals with psychological susceptibility and when large doses of ketamine are rapidly administered. 

Benzodiazepines (BZD) act by facilitating the action of GABA receptors. It acts by increasing the frequency of opening of GABA-mediated chloride channels, thereby hyperpolarizing the neurons and inhibiting their activity.

Uses of Benzodiazepines include

  • Antiepileptics: Lorazepam is the drug of choice for status epilepticus, delirium tremens, catatonia, and patients with liver dysfunction
  • Generalized anxiety disorders, panic disorders
  • Intravenous induction agent - Lorazepam
  • Sedative premedication in children - Midazolam
  • Muscle relaxant 

Other options: 

Phenobarbitone is a barbiturate primarily used in the treatment of generalised tonic-clonic and focal seizures.

Flumazenil is the benzodiazepine antagonist and is used in BZD overdose.

Carbamazepine is an anti-epileptic used in the management of generalised tonic-clonic and focal seizures. It is also used in bipolar disorder and in trigeminal neuralgias.
