questions.text: A young male patient came to the clinic with pigmentation of the mouth as shown in the image below. He also complained of recurrent abdominal pain. After a detailed evaluation, multiple hamartomatous polyps were found in the jejunum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Peutz Jegher's syndrome.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.

The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region.

Germline mutations in the gene STK11 are present in approximately half of the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Complications:

  • Peutz-Jeghers polyps can cause intussusception
  • It is associated with a markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Regular surveillance is recommended from a very young age for sex cord tumors of the testes.
  • During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter. Female patients are encouraged to attend breast and cervical screening.

Surgery is indicated in cases where there is bleeding, obstruction, intussusception, or adenomatous changes of the polyp. If surgery is done for these indications, attempts should be made to remove as much as polyps as possible. 

Other options:

Turcot syndrome (option A) is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis and constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors (including medulloblastoma and glioblastomas)

Lynch syndrome (option B) is also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It is due to defective mismatch repair of DNA.

Cowden disease (option C) is characterized by polyps of the colon or stomach with mucocutaneous lesions, thyroid adenomas and goiter, fibroadenomas and fibrocystic disease of the breast, and uterine leiomyomas.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a confirmatory test for seminal stains?
questions.solution:
Barberio's test is a screening test used to identify seminal stains.

This test detects the presence of spermine, which is one of the constituents of semen. A drop of stain taken in a glass slide is charged with picric acid. Under microscopic examination, the needle-shaped yellowish spermine picrate crystals indicate the presence of semen.

questions.text:
Which of the following MRI imaging techniques produce a bright cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) appearance?
  1. T1 weighted image
  2. T2 weighted image
  3. STIR
  4. FLAIR
questions.solution:
A bright CSF appearance is seen in T2 weighted images and STIR (Short tau inversion recovery).

T1 weighted images:

  • It is one of the basic MRI pulse sequences.
  • The difference in the appearance of various tissues is due to their different T1 relaxation times.
  • CSF has a long T1 time and appears dark.

T2 weighted images:

  • It is also a basic MRI pulse sequence.
  • It is based on the T2 relaxation time of the tissues.
  • CSF appears bright in these images.

 

Short tau inversion recovery(STIR):

  • It is a form of inversion recovery sequence.
  • It is used to selectively null signals from fat.
  • The imaging sequence is identified by observing the fat tissues and fluid-filled spaces.
  • Fluids like CSF appear bright and fat appears dark.

 

Fluid attenuated inversion recovery(FLAIR):

  • It is also a form of inversion recovery sequence.
  • It is used to selectively null signals from fluids.
  • Fluids like CSF appear dark and pathological processes appear bright.
  • It would appear as a fluid suppressed T2 image.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy sustained an injury to the face during a fight at school. A facial examination revealed a small subcutaneous ecchymosis in the left lower eyelid. An X-ray was performed which is shown in the image below.  What is the sign seen on the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The x-ray shows a teardrop sign which is characteristic of an orbital floor fracture.

It is also known as a blowout fracture and results in the herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary antrum. The most useful projection for detecting an orbital floor fracture is Water’s view.

Indications for surgery in a blowout fracture are as follows:

  • Diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma
  • A fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum
  • Incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in globe retraction and increased applanation tension on attempted upward gaze
  • Enophthalmos

Other options:

Option B: Phelp’s sign is seen in a CT scan of the glomus jugulare tumor. It is the erosion of the normal crest of bone between the carotid canal and jugular foramen.

Option C: Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumor mass in the glomus tympanicum when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Options D: Antral or Holman Miller sign is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. It is pathognomic of angiofibroma.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with palpitations and dizziness. On examination, a new onset diastolic murmur is heard in the left third intercostal space, and Traube's sign is positive. A diagnosis of acute severe aortic regurgitation is made. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice in symptomatic acute severe AR is aortic valve replacement. 

Treatment of aortic regurgitation:

  • In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. The symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output can be managed by diuretics and vasodilators.
  • In severe AR, surgery is indicated in the following conditions:
    • The patient is symptomatic
    • The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm.
    • The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.

Aortic regurgitation (AR). 

Aortic regurgitation (AR) is a valvular disease of the aortic valve caused by primary valve disease, aortic root disease, or their combination.

Auscultatory findings in AR are:

  • Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve
  • Diminished or absent A2
  • S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign of impaired LV function.
  • Early diastolic murmur -
    • High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur
    • Best heard in the left-third intercostal space
    • Heard with the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration
    • Duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity
  • Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate.
  • Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

questions.text: An AIDS patient presented with skin lesions as shown in the image below. Skin biopsy revealed proliferating spindle cells in the dermis with slit-like spaces containing the red cells. Identify the causative agent and its subfamily among the herpesviridae.
questions.solution:
The above image shows red-purple macules and plaques together with the clinical features, and the biopsy finding is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, which is caused by Human herpesvirus 8. It belongs to the gamma viruses subfamily of the herpesviridae family.

Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular tumor caused by human herpesvirus 8, also called Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV). It is the most common HIV-related malignancy and is an AIDS-defining illness. The lesions appear as red-purple macules or raised plaques over the skin, and the biopsy shows spindle cells in the dermis.

The Herpesviridae family is divided into 3 subfamilies:

  • Alpha herpesviruses
  • Beta herpes viruses
  • Gamma herpesviruses

questions.text: A patient with bronchial asthma was treated with regular inhaled corticosteroids. He is now commenced on theophylline as an add-on therapy. By which of the following mechanism does this drug enhance the effect of corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
Theophylline enhances the effect of corticosteroids by activation of histone deacetylase.

Theophylline activates histone deacetylase-2. The recruitment of histone deacetylase-2 by glucocorticoid receptors (GRs) switches off inflammatory genes. Through this mechanism, theophylline enhances the anti-inflammatory effects of corticosteroids.

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug used in the management of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Its other mechanisms of action are as follows:

  • Inhibits phosphodiesterase non-selectively, (PDE3, PDE4, and PDE5) thereby, increasing cellular cAMP and cGMP, causing bronchodilation
  • Adenosine causes bronchoconstriction by releasing histamine and leukotrienes. Theophylline antagonizes adenosine receptors causing bronchodilation
  • Increases IL-10 release, which has an anti-inflammatory effect
  • Decreases gene transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines
  • Promotes apoptosis of granulocytes, reducing the inflammatory load in the airways

Theophylline is mainly metabolized by the enzyme CYP1A2 enzyme. Various drug interactions of theophylline include:

  • Increased clearance (CYP1A2 enzyme induction) by smoking, phenytoin, rifampicin, and phenobarbitone.
  • Decreased clearance (CYP1A2 enzyme inhibition) by erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, oral contraceptives, and allopurinol.

Important side effects of this drug due to PDE4 antagonism are nausea, vomiting, and gastric discomfort, and those due to adenosine A1 receptor antagonism are diuresis, cardiac arrhythmias, and seizures.

questions.text:
A newborn is being evaluated for yellowish discoloration of the sclera and elevated bilirubin levels. Which of the following are indications to further evaluate the child to identify the cause of jaundice?
  1. Serum bilirubin of 16 mg/dL in a full-term infant 
  2. Jaundice appearing on the first day of birth
  3. Jaundice persisting after 14 days
  4. Direct bilirubin fraction < 2mg/dL on the 3rd day
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 3 are suggestive of a pathological cause of jaundice and need to be further evaluated for the cause of jaundice. 

Physiological jaundice occurs due to increased bilirubin production due to the destruction of the fetal RBCs along with a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation in the immature neonatal liver. It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd day, usually peaks between 2nd and 4th day at 5–6 mg/dL, and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth.

Risk factors for physiological jaundice include maternal age, maternal diabetes, prematurity, drugs(Vitamin K3, novobiocin), polycythemia, male sex, trisomy 21, cutaneous bruising, blood extravasation as in cephalhematoma, breastfeeding, weight loss, and a family history of physiological jaundice.

Jaundice in the newborn is not always physiological and in some cases, there can be an underlying pathology. Given below are the indications to evaluate a newborn to identify the cause of pathological jaundice:

  • Jaundice that appears in the first 24-36 hours of birth
  • A rise in serum bilirubin faster than 5mg/dL/24hr
  • Serum bilirubin > 12mg/dL in a full-term infant(especially if there are no risk factors)
  • Serum bilirubin > 10-14mg/dL in a preterm infant
  • Persistent jaundice after 10-14 days of birth
  • Direct bilirubin > 2mg/dL at any time

Other features suggestive of a nonphysiological cause of jaundice are a positive family history of any hemolytic disease, pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, poor feeding, apnea, bradycardia, hypothermia, light-colored stools, failure of phototherapy to lower the bilirubin levels, and signs of kernicterus.

If there is persistent indirect hyperbilirubinemia for more than 2 weeks it indicates hemolysis, hereditary glucuronyl transferase deficiency, breastmilk jaundice, hypothyroidism, or intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A young female with a history of renal calculi complains of bone pain and abdominal cramps. On investigation, multiple fractures were discovered and serum calcium and PTH was raised. Phosphate levels were decreased. What is the most common cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given history of renal stones, bone pain, and abdominal cramps with multiple fractures is highly suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary parathyroid adenoma arising sporadically.

It is associated with cyclin D1 gene inversions and mutations in both copies of the MEN1 gene.

Hyperparathyroidism is caused by elevated parathyroid hormone and is classified into primary, secondary, and tertiary types.

Primary hyperparathyroidism Secondary hyperparathyroidism Tertiary hyperparathyroidism

An autonomous overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH)

 Compensatory hypersecretion of PTH in response to prolonged hypocalcemia Persistent hypersecretion of PTH even after the cause of prolonged hypocalcemia is corrected
Parathyroid  adenoma or hyperplasia Seen in chronic renal failure Seen after renal transplant.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is one of the most common endocrine disorders, and it is an important cause of hypercalcemia. It also has reduced phosphate levels.

The clinical manifestations of hyperparathyroidism can be summarized as “painful bones, renal stones, abdominal groans, and psychic moans.”

Skeletal manifestations of hyperparathyroidism include bone resorption, osteitis fibrosa cystica, and brown tumors. Renal changes include nephrolithiasis (stones) and nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea for 3 days. His stools were greasy and foul-smelling. A wet preparation of the stool sample is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child having loose greasy, foul-smelling stools, vomiting, and abdominal pain along with stool examination showing trophozoites that are tennis-racquet shaped is strongly suggestive of Giardiasis caused by Giardia lamblia.

Infection is common in children and occurs through the ingestion of cysts in contaminated water and food. A single cyst can hatch out into two trophozoites, which eventually colonize the duodenum and upper part of the jejunum. It is the only protozoan parasite found in the lumen of the small intestine in humans.

Clinical features include diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, belching, flatus, nausea, and vomiting which last for more than one week.

Wet mount preparation of stool samples may show the presence of a small, oval cyst surrounded by a hyaline cyst wall or a trophozoite that is shaped like a tennis racket and is also referred to as heart-shaped or pyriform-shaped. Trophozoites are convex dorsally and have a sucking disk ventrally, that helps in attachment to the intestinal mucosa. Other tests include the string test/entero test, and serodiagnosis by ELISA kits to detect Giardia-specific antigen, GSA 65.

Metronidazole and tinidazole are the drugs of choice for treatment.

Other options :

Option A: Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebic dysentery. Microscopic examination of a saline wet mount of the stool shows the presence of diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile crystals called Charcot-Leyden crystals along with nuclear masses called pyknotic bodies. Cysts are spherical in shape with a single nucleus while trophozoites have an irregular shape with the presence of pseudopodia. An image of the cyst is shown below.

Option C: Cryptosporidium parvum has the sporulated oocyst as the infective form. The oocyst is acid-fast. Humans are infected by ingestion of contaminated food and water with feces or autoinfection. The patient may be asymptomatic or cause a self-limiting febrile illness, with watery diarrhea in conjunction with abdominal pain, nausea, and weight loss.

Option D: Balantidium coli is the only ciliated protozoan, present in the large intestine, infective form is a binucleate cyst. Clinical manifestations - infection is usually asymptomatic, patient rarely develops intermittent diarrhoea and abdominal cramps.  Diagnosis is by stool microscopy. An image of the trophozoite is shown below.

In interscalene block, the blockade occurs at the level of the superior and middle trunks of brachial plexus. It is performed by injecting a local anesthetic to the nerves of the brachial plexus as it passes through the groove between the anterior and middle scalene muscles, at the level of the cricoid cartilage.

Advantages of this block include rapid blockade of the shoulder region, and relatively easily palpable anatomical landmarks.

Disadvantages of this block include inadequate anesthesia in the distribution of the ulnar nerve, which makes this an unreliable block for operations involving the forearm and hand.

Image below depicts an interscalene block.

Other options:

Option A: Indications for a supraclavicular block are operations on the elbow, forearm, and hand. Blockade occurs at the distal trunk-proximal division level.

Image below depicts a supraclavicular block.

Option B: Infraclavicular block provides anesthesia to the arm and hand. Blockade occurs at the level of the cords.

Image below shows an infraclavicular block.

Option D: Indications for axillary block include surgery to the forearm and hand. Elbow procedures are also performed. Blockade occurs at the level of the terminal nerves. Although blockade of the musculocutaneous nerve is not always produced with this approach, it can be supplemented at the level of the axilla or at the elbow.

Image below depicts an axillary block.

questions.text: On examining a patient with an injury around the elbow, you notice that the three-point bony relationship is disrupted. This finding can be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is disrupted in case of an intercondylar fracture of the humerus.

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: Which among the following does the graph given below depict?
questions.solution:
The graph given above depicts the Haldane effect.

The binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This is known as the Haldane effect. It helps in the transport of CO2 from the tissues to the lungs. The graph shows small portions of two CO2 dissociation curves:

  • When the PO2 is 100 mm Hg, which is the case in the blood capillaries of the lungs.
  • When the PO2 is 40 mm Hg, which is the case in the tissue capillaries.

At the normal PCO2 of 45 mm Hg in the tissues represented by point A, 52 volume percent of CO2 combines with the blood. Upon entering the lungs, the PCO2 falls to 40 mm Hg and the PO2 rises to 100 mm Hg. The increase in PO2 shifts the CO2 dissociation curve from the top curve to the lower curve, so the CO2 content falls to point B.

Thus, the Haldane effect approximately doubles the amount of CO2 released from the blood in the lungs and the amount picked up by the tissues.

(Remember - HaLdane effect occurs in Lungs and causes Left shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve)

Other options:

Option A: Bohr effect: A right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve in response to an increase in blood CO2 and hydrogen ions, enhances the release of O2 from the blood in the tissues. This enhances the oxygenation of the blood in the lungs.

Option B: Henry's Law in Respiration: The amount of oxygen that dissolves into the bloodstream is directly proportional to the partial pressure of oxygen in alveolar air.

Option D: Boyle's Law: The pressure of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to its volume if its temperature is kept constant.

questions.text: Which of the following devices is best used in the management of otosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Device 3 is a picture of a piston, used in patients with otosclerosis. 

The treatment of choice for otosclerosis is surgical management which includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis (piston). The Teflon piston is a frequently used prosthesis in stapes surgery. To position the Teflon loop, it is initially spread out on the shaft of a needle perforator and then placed on the incus. Once in position, it encircles the long process of the incus and closes around it.

The given images are:

  1. Bone Anchored Hearing Aid
  2. Cochlear implant
  3. Stapedectomy piston
  4. Partial ossicular replacement prosthesis

Device 1 is a picture of a Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA), which can be used in a patient with bilateral external auditory canal atresia and conductive deafness not amenable to other treatment procedures. Bilateral aural atresia presents with failed audiological testing and requires early bone conduction hearing aids, one of which is BAHA. It is comprised of a sound processor with a small titanium fixture implanted behind the ear, which allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea rather than via the middle ear. This process is known as direct bone conduction. 

Device 2 is a picture of a cochlear implant. It is an electronic device used in patients with severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and those who cannot benefit from a hearing aid. It works by directly stimulating the auditory nerve and bypassing the cochlear hair cells that are damaged. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the hearing nerve. The principle of the surgery is to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea. An intact 8th nerve and the higher auditory pathway are prerequisites for surgery. It cannot be used in patients with cochlear aplasia or without the VIIIth cranial nerve.

Device 4 is a picture of a partial ossicular replacement prosthesis (PORP) that is designed for situations when the incus and/or malleus are eroded but the stapes are structurally intact and mobile. PORP is placed between the tympanic membrane and the stapes head.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatrics department with poor sucking and difficulty in taking feed. He also had severe foul smelling greasy loose stools. A peripheral smear showed acanthocytosis. A biopsy specimen of the small intestine is shown below. Identify the underlying condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of an infant presenting with failure to thrive, steatorrhea, acanthocytosis in the peripheral smear, and a histopathological image showing lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disease. It is caused due to the mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein which leads to the inability to assemble triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. Thus lipids get accumulate intracellularly. It is predominantly seen in children during their first year of life. They present with failure to thrive and steatorrhea.

Deep tendon reflexes are absent due to peripheral neuropathy and peripheral smear shows acanthocytosis due to lipid membrane defects, which is secondary to marked vitamin E deficiency.

Histopathology shows normal intestinal mucosa except lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium due to triglyceride accumulation. Accumulated lipids disappear after infants stop taking feed.

Low fat, high caloric, vitamin-enriched diet, and vitamin E in large doses should be given. Inadequate supply of vitamin E results in neurological degeneration and the development of retinitis pigmentosa.

 

Diarrhea is defined as an increase in stool mass, frequency, or fluidity, typically greater than 200 gm per day. It can be classified into 4 types:

  • Secretory diarrhea is an isotonic stool and persists during fasting.
  • Osmotic diarrhea is due to the osmotic force exerted by unabsorbed luminal solutes. The diarrheal fluid is greater than 50 mOsm. Diarrhea decreases on fasting.
  • Malabsorptive diarrhea is due to failure of nutrient absorption. It is associated with steatorrhea and it gets relived on fasting.
  • Exudative diarrhea is due to inflammatory diseases which has pus and blood on them, it continues during fasting.

Other options:

Option A- Lactase deficiency is due to the absence of lactase in the villous epithelial cells. Lactose remains in the intestinal lumen and exerts an osmotic force causing osmotic diarrhea. Since the defect is biochemical, histology appears normal.

Option C- Celiac disease is an immune-mediated disorder triggered by gluten-containing foods. Histology shows villous atrophy intraepithelial lymphocytosis and crypt hyperplasia. Plasma cells, mast cells, and eosinophils are seen in lamina propria.

Histopathology image of celiac disease is shown below:

 

Option D- Whipple's disease is a malabsorptive syndrome. Histology shows foamy macrophages in the small intestinal propria. The macrophages are laden with gram-positive, periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positive, diastase resistant granules that have partially digested Tropheryma whipplei within the lysosome.

choices.text: Point A is 2cm above and 5cm lateral to external os.
Point A is 2cm above and 2cm lateral to external os.
Point B is 2cm above and 2cm lateral to external os.
Point B is 5cm above and 2cm lateral to external os.

questions.solution:
The true statement is Point A is 2cm above and 2cm lateral to the external os.

Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumor. It can be either a low-dose or high-dose rate system. High-dose brachytherapy is safe and effective.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with complaints of urinary incontinence. His history is notable for increasing forgetfulness and the physical examination reveals an abnormal gait. His fundus looks normal, he has no tremors.  Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient presents with dementia, ataxia (gait disturbance), and urinary incontinence which is suggestive of Normal pressure hydrocephalus. 

NPH may be caused by obstruction to normal CSF flow over the cerebral convexities and delayed resorption into the venous system. This results in enlarged lateral ventricles with relatively little increase in CSF pressure. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

It presents with the characteristic triad of:

  • Dementia (mostly executive function)
  • Ataxic or apractic gait
  • Urinary incontinence (sometimes urgency too)

On imaging, dilated lateral ventricles are seen. Lumbar puncture opening pressure is in the normal to high range.

Treatment includes ventricular shunting. Gait improves more than cognition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with a painful genital ulcer on the glans penis. Examination reveals regional lymph nodes which are enlarged and painful. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
A painful genital ulcer with enlarged and painful regional lymph nodes is suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Chancroid (soft sore) is an acute STD caused by anaerobic gram-negative coccobacilli Haemophilus ducreyi. Chancroid ulcers are characterized by tender non-indurated irregular ulcers on the genitalia and are associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy.

It is Gram-negative but may often appear Gram-positive and frequently shows bipolar staining. The bacilli may be arranged in small groups or whorls or in parallel chains, giving a 'school of fish' or 'rail road track' appearance. Chocolate agar with isovitaleX is the suitable culture medium for Haemophilus ducreyi. H.ducreyi requires the presence of factor X but not factor V.

Management includes various antibiotics like erythromycin, cotrimoxazole, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone.

questions.text: A child with severe mental retardation was found to have a total absence of myelin in the central nervous system. Laboratory investigations reveal the accumulation of galactosylceramide. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Krabbe’s disease and the enzyme deficient in this disease is β-galactosidase. 

Sphingolipidoses are a group of lysosomal storage disorders characterized by the accumulation of sphingolipids. Krabbe’s disease is an autosomal-recessive sphingolipidosis. It is a neurodegenerative disorder that occurs due to a deficiency in β-galactosidase.

Galactosylceramide is the main content in a myelin sheath. It is synthesized by oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells by galactosylation of ceramide. It is broken down by the enzyme β-galactosidase, a lysosomal hydrolase.

In Krabbe’s disease due to deficiency of the enzyme β-galactosidase, galactosylceramide accumulates in oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells. This accumulation causes the formation of globoid cells (hematogenous often-multinucleated macrophages containing undigested galactosylceramide). This results in the destruction of oligodendroglia and hence total loss of myelin in the central nervous system.

The image given below shows globoid cells seen in Krabbe's disease.

It is characterized by mental retardation, irritability, tonic spasms with light or noise stimulation, seizures, hypertonia, and later flaccidity. Optic atrophy is also present. Investigations reveal increased protein in the CSF.

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation has been found to be effective as a treatment modality for Krabbe's disease.

questions.text: A woman with papillary thyroid cancer of the right lobe comes with a swelling on the right side of the neck as shown below (between the red arrows). Biopsy reveals metastatic tissue from the ipsilateral tumor. What is this metastatic lesion also known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes papillary thyroid carcinoma metastasis to the ipsilateral neck nodes. This is also known as a lateral aberrant thyroid.

Papillary thyroid carcinomas are the most common forms of thyroid carcinoma and present in younger individuals. They are commonly spread by the lymphatic system.

The risk of developing papillary thyroid cancer is high among individuals who:

  • Received external irradiation to the thyroid as children (< 5 years of age)
  • Received radiation for soft tissue malignancies, such as Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Have a history of acute environmental exposure
  • Familial syndromes (Cowden syndrome, Werner syndrome, Carney syndrome, etc)

The patient may present with thyroid swelling, lateral aberrant thyroid(cervical node invasion my metastasis), dysphagia, and hoarseness.

Management of differentiated thyroid cancers (DTC)

Differentiated thyroid cancers include papillary thyroid cancer, follicular thyroid cancer, and hurtle cell cancer.
Hemithyroidectomy is performed for DTCs between 1-4 cm without extrathyroidal extension or evidence of metastatic disease.
However, total thyroidectomy is performed in the following scenarios

  • Tumor at least 4 cm
  • Gross extrathyroidal extension
  • Evidence of metastatic disease
  • Radiation-induced DTC
  • Familial nonmedullary thyroid cancer
  • Multifocal bilateral DTC.

Central neck dissection is done only in case of involvement of level VI nodes.
If level VI plus other lymph nodes are enlarged - then total thyroidectomy + central neck dissection + modified radical neck dissection is done.
In case of tumor size >4cm (T3 &T4), prophylactic central neck dissection is done.

Other options-

Option A: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is also called struma lymphomatosa. It is not a malignant condition.

Option B: Lingual thyroid refers to thyroid tissue that remains attached to the tongue, at its site of origin within the oral cavity. The patient may present with obstructive symptoms such as choking, dysphagia, airway obstruction, or hemorrhage. Some patients develop hypothyroidism. Medical management includes the administration of exogenous thyroid hormone to suppress thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and radioactive iodine (RAI) ablation followed by hormone replacement. Surgical excision is rarely needed.

Option D: Thyroglossal duct cyst refers to a cyst that forms when the descending thyroid remains attached to the cecum of the tongue by a stalk and fails to separate. It is found in the midline, and not laterally like in this patient. It is not malignant in nature.

The below image shows a thyroglossal duct cyst as a midline neck swelling-

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic with liver disease came to the hospital with complaints of distension of the abdomen. On per abdominal examination, shifting dullness was positive. Which of the following is the diuretic of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical feature and the positive shifting dullness indicate ascites, probably due to liver cirrhosis in alcoholic liver disease. The diuretic of choice in a patient with cirrhotic ascites is spironolactone.

Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels. Spironolactone is particularly helpful in edematous states caused or exacerbated by hyperaldosteronism, such as in cirrhotic ascites.

Furosemide may be added, particularly in patients of ascites who have peripheral edema and are nonresponsive to spironolactone.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented with a high fever, muscle aches, and easy fatigability. He gives history of diarrhoea and abdominal pain about 6 weeks ago. Dietary history reveals consumption of raw or undercooked pork. The blood investigations showed eosinophilia. His muscle biopsy shows the following finding. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the causative organism of this disease?

choices.text: Pig acts as an intermediate host

questions.solution:
The given image shows an encysted spiral larvae in the muscle which is characteristic of Trichinella spiralis. The clinical presentation and eosinophilia further support the diagnosis. Neurocysticercosis is caused by Taenia solium ( larval stage known as Cysticercosis cellulose).

Trichinella is viviparous i.e. produces larvae. The larvae enter the intestine and invade the epithelium developing into adult. Clinical features at this stage include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever, myalgia, etc.

Detection of spiral larvae in muscle tissue is done by performing a muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy. About 1 g of muscle tissue preferably near the tendon insertion is biopsied. Safranin staining is done. 

It can be treated using albendazole along with steroids to control inflammation.

Note:

Neurocysticercosis is caused by the CNS infection with the pork "tapeworm", Taenia solium. It typically presents with seizures. Infection leads to extra-intestinal disease (including neurocysticercosis) usually occurs as a result of eating food or drinking water contaminated by human feces containing T. solium eggs.

questions.text: The image shows a graph plotted between rate of reaction (on y axis) and substrate concentration (on x axis). Which of the statements is not true regarding this plot?

choices.text: It is a property of monomeric enzymes
The enzyme may have multiple binding sites

questions.solution:
The image shows a sigmoid-shaped graph which is a property of multimeric enzymes.

Multimeric enzymes have multiple subunits. When the enzyme has many subunits, binding of substrate to one unit enhances the affinity for binding to other subunits. This is called cooperative binding. In such cases, a sigmoid-shaped saturation curve is obtained. This is not seen in monomeric enzymes. They do not follow Michaelis menten kinetics. Hill equation is used to describe the kinetics of positive cooperative binding.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem change shown in the following image.
questions.solution:
The image shows Tache noire.

If the eyelids remain open for a few hours after death, a layer of cell debris and mucus forms a yellow triangle on the sclera at either side adjacent to the iris. The base of the triangle is towards the margin of the cornea and the apex is towards the canthus of the eye. This debris turns brown color when the dust settles on them. It appears within 3-4 hours of death.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Cornea: Dull, and opaque due to the lack of lacrimal moistening.
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to a fall in intraocular pressure.
  • Pupils- Soon after death, pupils are slightly dilated due to the relaxation of the iris muscles. At the onset of rigor, the pupils become constricted.
  • Kevorkian sign- It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour.
  • Increase in potassium concentration in the vitreous. It is helpful in determining the time since death.

Tardieu spots are the petechial hemorrhages seen in the scalp, eyelids, and face. They are commonly found in hanging and strangulation and occur due to acute increase in venous pressure, over distension and rupture of thin walled peripheral vessels and capillaries especially in their lax, unsupported tissues.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a known history of hypothyroidism was brought to the emergency with a reduced level of consciousness, bradycardia, and hypotension. Her temperature was 32 degrees celcius. Her capillary blood glucose level is 106 mg/dl. Which of the following would be most useful in her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests a case of hypothyroidism presenting in myxedema coma. IV liothyronine is useful in its management.

Myxedema coma refers to severe, life-threatening manifestations of hypothyroidism. It is mostly seen in the elderly. It is often precipitated by drugs (sedatives, antidepressants, anesthetics), infections like pneumonia, congestive heart failure, myocardial ischemia, cerebrovascular accidents, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patients present with impaired consciousness, profound hypothermia (which can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension. It is associated with a high mortality rate.

Management of myxedema coma is with levothyroxine (T4) or liothyronine (T3). Levothyroxine is given intravenously, while liothyronine can be given via nasogastric or intravenous route. Parenteral hydrocortisone is used to correct the impaired levels of corticoid hormones. And the precipitating factors are treated symptomatically. Supportive therapy is by correcting the associated metabolic imbalance, external warming(if body temperature is <30 degrees) to prevent circulatory collapse by using space blankets, and ventilatory support if hypercapnia is present.

Other options:

Option A: IV diazepam is used in emergency management of status epilepticus.

Option B: IV 2.5% dextrose is not the most useful drug in this scenario since the patient's capillary blood glucose (CBG) levels are within the normal range

Option D: Slow rewarming with space blankets is used to treat hypothermia of myxedema coma to prevent circulatory collapse.

questions.text: A 30-year-old mother who had prolonged labor delivered a full-term male baby by spontaneous vaginal delivery.  Following this, the patient went into a state of shock due to uterine inversion. Which of the following methods can be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
O’Sullivan's method is used for replacing the uterus in case of uterine inversion.

Uterine inversion is most commonly caused due to mismanagement of 3rd stage of labor. The usual risk factors include an enlarged uterus, prolonged labor, large fetal size (macrosomia), uterine malformations, morbidly adherent placenta, a short umbilical cord, tocolysis (use of medications to stop preterm labor), and manual placenta removal. Women with collagen disorders like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are more susceptible to this condition.

The mother presents with shock immediately after delivery, the degree of the shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding. It is both neurogenic and hemorrhagic. During the abdominal examination, a cup or dimpled appearance is observed on the surface of the fundus. In cases of the complete variety, a pear-shaped mass protrudes from the vulva, with a broad end pointing downward and looking reddish purple in color.

The ideal treatment is an immediate replacement of the uterus. It should be immediately reposited by exerting firm and constant pressure on the inverted uterine fundus. If the placenta is attached to the uterus, it must not be removed until after the replacement has been effected. The best method of replacing the uterus has been described by O’Sullivan. 

O’Sullivan's method:  Here the patient is anesthetized and a gallon of warm sterile water is used for irrigation into the vagina, using an irrigating can raised 3 to 4 feet above the level of the patient. After gently pushing the inverted uterine fundus back into the vagina, the nozzle of the irrigating cannula is inserted into the vagina, and the vaginal orifice is closed by the hands of the operator and an assistant. Around 3-5L of fluid may be required, and the inversion will be slowly corrected by the hydrostatic pressure. If this method fails, manual repositioning may be attempted under deep anesthesia. 

Reposition of the uterus may be done by abdominal operation after trying manual and hydrostatic methods.

Schultze method Duncan's method
Separation begins from the center of the placenta to the periphery. Separation begins from the periphery to the center.
Blood does not escape externally, as the blood pours into the membrane sac. Blood escapes from the vagina as blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall.

 

Brandt Andrew's method is a maneuver of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labor. 

Here, the palmar surface of the left hand is placed on the mother's abdomen approximately at the junction of the upper and lower uterine segment (above the symphysis pubis) and the umbilical cord is grasped with other hand. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backward and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord in a downward and backward direction holding the clamp until the placenta comes outside the introitus. The procedure is used only when the uterus is hard and contracted.

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman was diagnosed with osteoporosis four months back and was started on oral bisphosphonates. Which among the following is a biochemical marker of bone resorption that can be used to monitor her response to treatment?

choices.text: Serum propeptide of type I procollagen

questions.solution:
Serum and urine cross-linked C-telopeptide is a marker of bone resorption while the others are markers of bone formation.

The measurement of bone resorption using markers like serum cross-linked C-telopeptide before initiating therapy and 3–6 months after starting therapy provides an earlier estimate of patient response than bone densitometry evaluations. 

Biochemical markers measure the overall state of bone remodeling at a single point in time. They are primarily used for monitoring the response to treatment. Markers of bone resorption also help in the prediction of fracture risk in older individuals. 

Biochemical Markers of Bone Metabolism include:

Bone formation markers:

  1. Serum propeptide of type I procollagen
  2. Serum osteocalcin 
  3. Serum bone-specific alkaline phosphatase 

Bone resorption markers:

  1. Urine and serum cross-linked N-telopeptide 
  2. Urine and serum cross-linked C-telopeptide.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop:
questions.solution:
The graph shows airflow limitation and flattening in the expiratory limb of the loop seen in variable intrathoracic obstruction.

Variable (nonfixed) intrathoracic obstruction is seen in conditions like bronchogenic cysts, tracheal lesions, etc.

The image below shows air flow limitation and flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. It is seen in nonfixed variable extrathoracic obstruction. eg. vocal cord paralysis, extrathoracic tracheomalacia, polychondritis, etc.

The graph depicts air flow limited during both inspiration and expiration leading to flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is seen in fixed obstruction of the central or upper airway.

The image given below shows a concave upward, pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called the "scooped-out" or "coved" pattern. Eg. asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bronchiectasis, and bronchiolitis.

Saw tooth pattern of the loop consists of small, rapid oscillations in flow during both expiration and inspiration. It is seen in neuromuscular diseases, Parkinson disease, laryngeal dyskinesia, pedunculated tumors of the upper airway, tracheobronchomalacia, upper airway burns, and obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.text: An intern attempts to insert a Foley catheter in an elderly male patient. However, in the first attempt, he meets resistance while advancing the catheter and fails at few more attempts with a smaller size catheter. Which of the following is the next best step?

choices.text: Attempt to pass a larger size catheter

questions.solution:
The next best step would be to examine the urethral anatomy using cystoscopy.

Cystoscopy is used to assess the urethra for size, strictures, false passage, or bladder neck stenosis. This facilitates the placement of a guidewire beyond any identified stricture over which a Councill catheter can be placed.

Other options

Option A: A suprapubic catheter is inserted only if all the attempts at urethral catheterization including flexible cystoscopy guidance are unsuccessful.

Option C: Attempting to pass a larger catheter in a patient who is suspected to have a stricture causes further trauma. However, a smaller bore catheter would be the appropriate choice.

Option D: An internal urethrotomy is a procedure that is done in cases where the urethral stricture is diagnosed. It uses an optical urethrotome to cut the fibrotic stricture under visual control.

questions.text: Pain of acute cholecystitis can be referred to all the following sites except?

choices.text: Inferior angle of the right scapula

questions.solution:
The pain of acute cholecystitis can be referred to the inferior angle of the right scapula, epigastrium, and the right shoulder.

Pain from the gallbladder and other foregut-derived structures can be referred to the following site based on the nerve along which it travels:

  • To the stomach (epigastrium) through the vagus nerve
  • To the inferior angle of the right scapula through sympathetic nerves of the T7 segment
  • To the right shoulder via the phrenic nerve

The pain of structures derived from the midgut such as the caecum and vermiform appendix is referred to the periumbilical region while those of hindgut-derived viscera are to the suprapubic area.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with intermittent upper abdominal pain, episodic hot flushes involving the face and upper chest, and watery stools. Urinalysis was positive for 5-OH indole acetic acid. He was diagnosed to have a carcinoid tumor in the appendix which was 2.5 cm at the tip of the appendix. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Carcinoid tumors measuring >2 cm should be managed with hemicolectomy.

The carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors arising from enterochromaffin cells that can occur anywhere in the GIT. The most common site is the appendix followed by the ileum and rectum.

Abdominal symptoms include Abdominal pain, distension, and Lower GI bleeding.

A carcinoid tumor with metastasis to the liver is likely to produce carcinoid syndrome. Metastasis in these patients can cause increased production of serotonin leading to carcinoid syndrome with features like:

  • Flushing
  • Diarrhea
  • Bronchospasm
  • Cardiac symptoms because of stenosis and insufficiency of the cardiac valves

The diagnosis is made by an assessment of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) in a 24-hour urine sample. It is positive in larger tumors only if metastases are present.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient came with complaints of dyspnea, dysphagia, hoarseness of voice, and cough for a few months.  A mass in the thyroid gland was detected, and a diagnosis of Reidel's thyroiditis was made. Which among the following condition has pathophysiology similar to Reidel's thyroiditis?
questions.solution:
Riedel's thyroiditis is an IgG4 related disease. Among the given options, the condition that has pathophysiology similar to Reidel's thyroiditis is retroperitoneal fibrosis, which is also an IgG4 related disease.

IgG4 related disease is a group of disorders characterized by tissue infiltrates predominantly composed of IgG4 antibody-producing plasma cells and lymphocytes, fibrosis, obliterative phlebitis, and increased serum IgG4. It is predominantly seen in middle-aged men. The IgG4-Related disease spectrum includes:

  • Mikulicz syndrome 
  • Riedel thyroiditis
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis
  • Autoimmune pancreatitis
  • Inflammatory pseudotumors of the orbit, lungs, and kidney

Riedel thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by extensive fibrosis of the thyroid gland and adjacent structures. They present with a nontender, hard-fixed thyroid mass leading to suspicion of malignancy. Diagnosis requires an open biopsy and surgical resection relives compressive symptoms. It may be associated with IgG4 related disease-causing idiopathic fibrosis at other sites. 

Retroperitoneal fibrosis is an IgG4 related disease that presents with backache, low abdominal pain, lower limb edema, hydronephrosis from ureteral involvement.

Other options:

Option A- Hashimoto thyroiditis is autoimmune thyroiditis that destroys the thyroid gland and leads to gradual, progressive thyroid failure. This occurs due to the breakdown in self-tolerance to thyroid autoantigens. 

Option B- De Quervain thyroiditis is also known as granulomatous thyroiditis. It is triggered by a viral infection. A viral upper respiratory tract infection causes host tissue damage that stimulates a cytotoxic T lymphocytes response to one or more thyroid antigens that damages thyroid follicle cells.

Option D- Amyloidosis is a condition associated with inherited and inflammatory disorders in which extracellular deposits of abnormal fibrillar proteins cause tissue damage and functional compromise.

questions.text: A postoperative patient presented with complaints of abdominal distension following laparotomy. He had not yet passed flatus after surgery. On examination, bowel sounds are absent. X-ray shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple air-fluid levels. Which of the following electrolyte abnormality is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of postoperative paralytic ileus. Hypokalemia is most commonly associated with it.

Paralytic ileus is an adynamic obstruction in which there is a failure of transmission of peristaltic waves, secondary to neuromuscular failure in the Auerbach’s and Meissner’s plexuses. Paralytic ileus lasting 24–72 hours usually occurs after any abdominal procedure and is self-limiting. It is of clinical significance if any of the following are observed 72 hours after laparotomy:

  • No return of bowel sounds on auscultation
  • No passage of flatus

Features of paralytic ileus are marked abdominal distension, effortless vomiting, absent bowel sounds, and absolute constipation. Colicky abdominal pain is not a feature.

Hypokalemia and uremia may be seen and are known to contribute to the development of paralytic ileus. On radiology, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple fluid levels (if an erect film is felt necessary).

Paralytic ileus is managed with the use of nasogastric suction and restriction of oral intake until bowel sounds and the passage of flatus return. Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

questions.text: A primigravida presents with sudden onset painless active vaginal bleeding and hypotension at 37 weeks of gestation. Ultrasound reveals a low-lying placenta of type III. Which of the following is the best suited management?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and USG examination of a primigravida presenting with painless active vaginal bleeding points to the diagnosis of type III placenta previa. Since she is at 37 weeks of gestation, the next best step in management is cesarean delivery.

Typically, mothers experiencing active bleeding around the 37-38 weeks of pregnancy undergo definitive management. For cases of placenta previa where the placenta is situated within 2 cm of the internal os, cesarean delivery is advised. However, if the placental edge is confirmed to be 2-3 cm away from the internal os through ultrasound, vaginal delivery could be an option.

Common risk factors for placenta previa include previous cesarian section, myomectomy, advanced maternal age (>35 years), smoking, multiparity, and prior curettage.

Types of placenta previa:

  • Type I- The majority of the placenta is implanted in the upper segment with the lower margin encroaching onto the lower segment but not up to the os.
  • Type II- The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type III- The placenta partially covers the internal os. (partial central /Incomplete)
  • Type IV- The placenta completely covers the internal os and even after full dilatation of the lower uterine segment. (complete/central) 

Clinically, types I and II anterior are graded as mild degree placenta previa whereas types II posterior, III, and IV are categorized as major degree placenta previa.

Management options can be divided into expectant management and active or definite management. 

Expectant management has been described by Macafee and Johnson.

Prerequisites: Blood should be available for transfusion if required, and facilities for cesarean section should be made available 24 hours a day.

The components of expectant treatment include: 

  • Bed rest with bathroom and toilet privilege
  • Investigations like hemoglobin estimation, blood grouping, urine for protein, etc
  • Periodic examination of vulval pads
  • Fetal surveillance with ultrasound at an interval of 2-3 weeks
  • Supplementary hematinics should be provided
  • If the patient is anemic, then the loss of blood is treated with adequate cross-matched blood transfusion
  • 2-3 days after the bleeding stops, the patient is allowed out of bed and examined with a gentle speculum to rule out local causes of bleeding.
  • Tocolysis if bleeding is associated with uterine contractions.
  • Rh immunoglobulin to be given to Rh-negative mothers

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa:

  • Mother in good health (Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%)
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 weeks
  • No active vaginal bleeding
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG and cardiotocography)

Expectant management is continued only up to 37 weeks of gestation. 

Indications of definitive management (delivery) include :

  • Bleeding occurs at or after 37 weeks of pregnancy.
  • The patient is in labor.
  • The patient is in an exsanguinated state on admission.
  • Continuous bleeding of a moderate degree.
  • Baby with nonreassuring cardiac status, dead, or known to be congenitally deformed.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with features of angular stomatitis and a magenta tongue. Deficiency of which of the following vitamin will result in the above features?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of angular stomatitis and magenta tongue is suggestive of vitamin B2 / riboflavin deficiency.

Riboflavin (vitamin B2)

The active form of riboflavin is Flavin mononucleotide(FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD). FMN is present in Complex I of ETC and FAD is present in Complex II in ETC.

FAD-dependent enzymes include succinate dehydrogenase, pyruvate dehydrogenase, alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, xanthine oxidase, and acyl CoA dehydrogenase

Riboflavin is synthesized in the body by intestinal flora. Dietary sources rich in riboflavin are liver, dried yeast, egg, and whole milk. Fish, whole cereals, legumes, and green leafy vegetables are also good sources of riboflavin. Riboflavin is light-sensitive. Hence riboflavin supplementation may be required during phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia 

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include the proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries(the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency) angular stomatitis, circumcorneal vascularization, cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Other options

Option B: Vitamin B3/ niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterized by a pigmented rash in sun-exposed areas, bright red tongue, diarrhea, apathy, memory loss, and disorientation.

Option C: Vitamin B6/ pyridoxine deficiency leads to symptoms such as seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion and microcytic anemia.

Option D: Vitamin E is a fat-soluble vitamin and is not soluble in water. Its deficiency leads to peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar ataxia, skeletal muscle atrophy, and retinopathy.

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 124 population and 20 had the disease. Twenty-two showed positive tests among which 15 had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the sensitivity of the test is 75%.

Out of the 22 positive results, only 15 had the disease and these are true positives. The remaining 7 people are false positives as they got the positive result but have no disease.

Out of the 20 people who had the disease, only 15 tested positive. The remaining 5 people are false negatives as they got a negative result despite having the disease.

The sensitivity of a test is calculated as:

True Positive / (True positives + False Negatives ) × 100

= 15 / (15+5) × 100

= 15 / 20 × 100

= 0.75 × 100

Sensitivity = 75%

  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male from Andhra Pradesh presented with features of cervical stenosis and a strikingly noticeable genu-valgum. The radiograph of his forearms appears as given below. Personal history reveals his staple diet as jowar. How would this diet affect the fluoride levels in his body to cause this presentation?

choices.text: High fluoride levels by inhibiting urinary excretion
Low fluoride levels by promoting urinary excretion
High fluoride levels by increasing ingested fluoride retention
Low fluoride levels by decreasing ingested fluoride retention

questions.solution:
The given history of Genu valgum and the image showing interosseous membrane ossification is characteristic of fluorosis. It is seen in people consuming jawar(sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

Fluorosis is seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: 1.5mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis: >10mg/L

Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.

This leads to impaired mineralization and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

The characteristic pathology involves sub-periosteal new bone formation, osteosclerosis (most commonly seen in vertebrae, ribs, and pelvis), and hyperostosis at the bony attachments of ligaments, tendons, and fascia. 

Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament can also be seen, usually after the age of 50 years. It is associated with various bone-forming conditions such as diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) and fluorosis. It is most commonly seen in the cervical spine.  It can result in spinal stenosis and cervical myelopathy causing pain and weakness in the limbs. X-ray shows dense ossification along the back of the vertebral bodies in the mid-cervical spine. 

Note: Nalgonda technique is used for defluoridation which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy sustained an injury while falling on an outstretched hand and presented with pain and swelling over his left elbow. His X-ray image is shown below. Which among the following classification is used in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the boy presenting with pain and swelling over his left elbow and the X-ray image is suggestive of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Gartland classification is used in this case.

Gartland classification

  • Type I – an undisplaced fracture
  • Type II – an angulated fracture with the posterior cortex still intact.
             IIA: a less severe injury with the distal fragment merely angulated
             IIB: a severe injury; the fragment is both angulated and malrotated
  • Type III–a completely displaced fracture(although the posterior periosteum is usually preserved, which will assist in surgical reduction)
  • Type IV – an anteriorly displaced fracture

Supracondylar fracture of the humerus is most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years. The extension type is seen in 98% of the cases while the rest are flexion type. The mechanism of injury involved is usually a fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension. 

On examination, there may be an S-shaped deformity at the elbow. If the proximal fracture fragment is sharp and has penetrated the muscles and fascia, a dimple may be seen on the skin above the elbow (dimple sign). The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture.

Radiology:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle is the angle between the horizontal line of the elbow and the line drawn through the lateral epiphysis and long axis of the arm. It is normally less than 5 degrees and is checked with the other arm.

The most common nerve to be injured in the extension type is the anterior interosseous nerve while the ulnar nerve is injured in the flexion type. The brachial artery is most likely involved when there is blood vessel involvement. Cubitus varus or gunstock deformity is the most common angular deformity that results from supracondylar fractures in children. It is corrected by closing wedge osteotomy.

Conservative management is attempted with closed reduction using traction and counter-traction. Successful reduction is when the long axis of the arm and forearm lie in parallel. If conservative management fails, skin or skeletal traction is employed but is not used anymore due to better modalities of treatment.

Surgery is by either closed reduction and percutaneous internal fixation with K-wires or open reduction and internal fixation with wires or plates.

On the tongue, there is a loss of the lingual papillae, leaving a smooth area. It can occur after long term corticosteroids or antibiotics usage or those with HIV. Other names for this condition include Acute atrophic oral candidiasis and Antibiotic sore tongue.

Chronic erythematous candidiasis is usually associated with denture wearing.

Geographic tongue, though consistent with the clinical image is not the best fit considering the clinical history. It is usually asymptomatic but can be occasionally associated with a sore tongue. It usually is associated with a history of being not constant in size, shape, or location.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with a scrotal swelling. On examination, one can feel the testis separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling shows a brilliant transillumination. A crystal clear fluid is noticed with aspiration. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an Epididymal cyst. The swelling is palpable separately from the testis. This rules out primary hydrocoele as swelling cannot be palpated separately from the testis. Aspiration of crystal clear fluid rules out spermatocele as it contains barley-colored fluid due to the presence of spermatozoa.

Epididymal cyst occurs due to cystic degeneration of epididymis. They usually occur in middle age and are bilateral. The tense cysts are usually posterior to the testes and feel like clusters of tiny grapes. It is visible on USG as anechoic cysts different from the testes. Treatment involves the excision of the cyst if it is single. Partial or total resection of the epididymis is required in multilocular cysts.

Spermatocele Epididymal cyst
Unilocular retention cyst Multiple, multilocular, bunch of grapes

Present at the epididymal head,

Above and behind the upper pole of the testes

 Posterior to testis
Transillumination+

Transillumination+

(Chinese lantern pattern)
Barley water fluid appearance Crystal clear fluid
Treatment: Excision Treatment: Excision


Other options:

Option C: Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis in the scrotum. It will be brilliantly transilluminating and testes will not be separately palpable. USG will show anechoic (due to fluid) reflection. Treatment involves Jaboulay's operation, in which the eversion of the sac upon itself is done to prevent refilling of the hydrocoele sac.

Option D: Varicocele is an abnormal dilatation and enlargement of the scrotal venous plexus draining the testis. They are more common on the left side. They are usually asymptomatic. First-line treatment is embolization in symptomatic cases. Palomo operation can be done which is the ligation of the testicular vein in the retroperitoneum.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in the back following trivial trauma. She was diagnosed to have a vertebral fracture. Her bone mineral density is measured and her T-score is found to be -2.8. What does this signify?
questions.solution:
A T-score of -2.8 with fragility fracture (vertebral fracture on trivial trauma) indicates severe osteoporosis.

DEXA scan is performed to measure bone mineral density. It helps in the diagnosis of osteoporosis and fracture risk assessment. It is used to measure the T-score.  T-score is the comparison of the bone mineral density of a patient to that of a 30-year-old healthy individual.

  • T-score greater than or equal to -1.0: normal bone density
  • T-score less than -1.0 to greater than -2.5: osteopenia
  • T-score less than or equal to -2.5: osteoporosis
  • T-score less than or equal to -2.5 plus fragility fracture: severe osteoporosis

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of easy bruisiability and hemarthrosis. Investigations revealed normal platelet count and bleeding time, normal PT, and prolonged PTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptom of hemarthrosis and the investigations are suggestive of a coagulation disorder. Among the given options, hemophilia A is a coagulation disorder, while all the other conditions are platelet disorders.

Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) and deep tissues is a feature of coagulation disorders, whereas platelet disorders usually present with mucocutaneous bleeding such as petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, or GI bleed. Prolonged PT/aPTT is a feature of coagulation disorders, while prolonged bleeding time is a feature of platelet disorders.

In the given scenario, normal platelet count and bleeding time exclude platelet disorders. Normal PT indicates normal functioning of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, and prolonged PTT indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway.

Hemophilia is an X-linked (recessive) coagulation disorder associated with mutations in factor VIII, affecting the intrinsic pathway. The patients present with easy bruising, significant hemorrhage following trauma and operative procedures, and hemarthroses, but no petechiae. The diagnosis is confirmed by carrying out factor VIII-specific assays. Infusions of recombinant factor VIII are used for treatment. 

Other options:

Option 1: Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disorder that is associated with qualitative/quantitative defects in the von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is a protein necessary for platelet adhesion, platelet aggregation, and stabilization of factor VIII.

Option 3: Bernard-Soulier disease is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIb receptor necessary for platelet adhesion to the subendothelial collagen. 

Option 4: Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor necessary for platelet aggregation.

questions.text: A patient on multidrug therapy for leprosy for the past 6 months presented with fever and onset of new tender subcutaneous nodules over forearms and elbows. On investigation, tumor necrosis factor-alpha levels were raised. Which of the following statement is true regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction
Clofazimine is the first line drug
It is unrelated to multidrug therapy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the onset of new subcutaneous nodules along with the prevalence of systemic symptoms in a patient with leprosy is suggestive of Type 2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL). It is unrelated to multidrug therapy. 

Type 2 leprosy reaction is seen in multibacillary leprosy (lepromatous leprosy and borderline lepromatous leprosy). It is seen as a development of new, erythematous and tender, subcutaneous, and dermal nodules that are widely distributed over the face and extremities.

It is unrelated to multidrug therapy (MDT) and is commonly associated with systemic symptoms such as fever, myalgia, arthralgia, and orchitis (Option D). Raised tumor necrosis factor-alpha is often seen. It is a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (Option A).

The first-line treatment is oral corticosteroids (Option B). Other drugs used in treatment are clofazimine (steroid-dependent ENL) and thalidomide (most effective but not commonly used due to adverse side effects).

questions.text: A 22-year-old presents to the OPD following the consumption of a chemical. He complained of a hot burning sensation extending from mouth to stomach and had difficulty in breathing. After 48 hours, the patient passed dark, smoky urine which turned olive green in the urobag. Which of the following is most likely to be consumed by this patient?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario history of burning sensation, difficulty in breathing, and passage of olive green color urine (carboluria) is suggestive of Carbolic acid/ phenol poisoning.

Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Local skin effects: Burning, tingling followed by anesthesia and greyish-white sloughing 
  • Headache, giddiness, tinnitus
  • Vomiting, diarrhea, pain abdomen
  • Pulmonary and laryngeal edema, respiratory failure
  • Muscular spasms, convulsions
  • Collapse
  • A clammy, cold sweating body
  • Pupils dilated
  • Methemoglobinemia 

In carbolic acid poisoning if the patient survives for 48 hrs there will be carboluria followed by anuria. The victim will pass dark, smoky urine which soon turns olive green on standing due to the oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrocatechol. 

Management depends on the route of administration.

In case of poisoning through skin absorption

  • Remove the contaminated garments
  • Cleanse the site by mopping with a wet cloth and washing with soap and water
  • Apply olive oil/ methylated spirit/ 10 percent ethyl alcohol, which can prevent further absorption
  • Give normal saline + sodium bicarbonate (I/V- drip)

In case of poisoning through the oral route

  • Perform gastric lavage: Though phenol corrodes the stomach wall, it also hardens it, unlike other corrosive poisons. Hence gastric lavage is performed whenever possible with plenty of lukewarm water containing animal charcoal, olive oil, magnesium or sodium sulfate or saccharated lime, soap solution, 10 percent glycerine, etc. When the lavage is completed, 30 gm of magnesium sulfate or medicinal liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach.
  • Give egg white: Epsom salt/demulcents orally.
