questions.text: A patient with chronic lymphocytic leukemia was started on fludarabine. After 36 hours of starting the therapy, she developed abdominal pain, hematuria, vomiting, and severe muscle cramps. The laboratory investigations reveal hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia. Which of the following is not done in the management of this condition?

choices.text: Aggressive hydration with normal or 1/2 normal saline

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) as the patient developed abdominal pain, hematuria, and muscle cramps with hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia following the administration of fludarabine. Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate is not done in the management of this condition.

Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate increases uric acid solubility, but a high pH decreases the solubility of xanthine, hypoxanthine, and calcium phosphate, and increases the likelihood of intratubular crystallization.

It is caused due to destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating cells. It is seen following treatment of Burkitt's lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, etc. TLS is also caused following the administration of fludarabine, glucocorticoids, hormonal agents such as letrozole and tamoxifen, and monoclonal antibodies such as rituximab and gemtuzumab.

Metabolic abnormalities in tumor lysis syndrome are 

  • Hyperuricemia-It occurs due to the increased turnover of nucleic acids. These may get precipitated in the renal tubules leading to renal failure.
  • Hyperkalemia- occurs due to the release of intracellular potassium ions
  • Hyperphosphatemia- occurs due to the release of intracellular phosphate stores
  • Hypocalcemia- occurs as a result of increased levels of phosphate
  • Acidosis may also develop.

Management of TLS consists of allopurinol and aggressive hydration with normal or 1/2 normal saline. Febuxostat and rasburicase are the other drugs that can be used in the management of high uric acid levels. If the patient develops renal failure, then hemodialysis is necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following findings in the patient's better eye would prompt you to not classify the patient as blind as per the WHO criteria?
questions.solution:
Visual acuity of 3/60 in the better eye is classified as severe visual impairment.

As per WHO's definition, blindness is defined as presenting visual acuity of worse than 3/60 or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10° in the better eye. Presenting visual acuity in the range of worse than 6/18 to 6/60 is defined as moderate visual impairment. Presenting visual acuity of worse than 6/60 to 3/60 (including 3/60) is classified as severe visual impairment.

The other options with visual fields of 4 and 8 degrees and visual acuity of 1/60 in the better eye are all classified as blindness.

questions.text:
Ketosis is common in type 1 DM due to
  1. Decreased beta-oxidation of fatty acids
  2. Increased mobilization of fat from the adipose cell
  3. Decreased acetyl CoA in TCA cycle
  4. Increased beta-hydroxy butyryl synthase
questions.solution:
B, Cand D statements contribute to the increased ketogenesis as seen in type1 DM.

Type1 DM is characterized by an absolute deficiency of insulin production. Since insulin is deficient, GLUT4 (insulin-dependent uptake) mediated glucose uptake is not possible in the heart or skeletal muscles. So adipose tissue mobilizes fat to be used as an energy source. These FFA are oxidized to acetoacetyl CoA which serves as a precursor for ketone bodies (hydroxybutyrate and acetoacetate) synthesis in the liver. Beta-hydroxy butyryl synthase is one of the enzymes used in ketone body synthesis.

When lipolysis occurs at a fast rate, as in starvation or low insulin: glucagon ratio states like diabetes, ketosis occurs. Ketosis is needed in initial states of starvation because it serves as a fuel for extrahepatic tissues, especially the brain. But because ketone bodies are acidic, on long-standing it causes ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A child of age 5 years presents with developmental delay and multiple episodes of seizure which could not be controlled with multiple drugs. A diagnosis of  Lennox–Gastaut syndrome is made. What is the characteristic electroencephalogram finding will you expect?

choices.text: 4-5 Hz spike and a slow background in wakefulness
1-2 Hz spike and slow wave and polyspike bursts in sleep
3 Hz spike and slow-wave with a fast background in wakefulness
Hypsarrhythmia and a slow background in wakefulness

questions.solution:
1-2 Hz spike and slow waves and polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness is the characteristic electroencephalogram findings in Lennox–Gastaut syndrome.

A child with developmental delay, intractable seizures with an electroencephalogram (EEG) showing 1-2 Hz spike, and polyspike bursts in sleep are suggestive of the diagnosis of Lennox–Gastaut syndrome. It typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years. Consists of a triad of

  • Developmental delay
  • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
  • EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness

Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient comes to the emergency department complaining of high fever, chills, and abdominal pain for the past 5 days. Laboratory tests of blood and stool cultures show an oxidase-negative, motile, gram-negative bacillus which is cultured in the media pictured below.  Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism, in this case, is Salmonella typhi. Salmonella is a gram-negative rod that is motile, oxidase negative, and shows large black colonies, with a metallic sheen when cultured in Wilson and Blair bismuth sulfite medium.

Salmonella typhi reduces sulfite to sulfide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on the Wilson and Blair bismuth sulfite medium. It is an example of indicator media. It is also a selective media because inhibiting substances are added to inhibit the growth of unwanted bacteria.

On the Wilson-Blair medium, S. Typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallic sheen and S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

Other options-

Option A - Shigella can cause bloody diarrhea and present similarly to Salmonella species infection. They also are oxidase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods. However, Shigella species are non-motile, while Salmonella species are motile.

Option B - Escherichia coli (EHEC, EIEC) can cause bloody diarrhea. They are also gram-negative rods that are oxidase-negative. However, E. coli does not produce black colonies in a bismuth sulfite medium.

Option D- Pseudomonas aeruginosa does not cause bloody diarrhea. Although it is a gram-negative bacillus, it is oxidase-positive.

questions.text: Hysterosalpingography can be safely done in a patient with
questions.solution:
Uterine synechiae is not a contraindication to the procedure. Hysterosalpingography can be used to detect uterine synechiae.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radioopaque dye, and visualization of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

It is best performed between the end of the menstrual period and ovulation (i.e. 9th or 10th day of the cycle). 10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal Ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used to detect:

  • Tubal block. This can be due to strictures (fibrotic block), inspissated amorphous material, or spasms. The tubal spasm can occur in an apprehensive woman and this is prevented by premedication with atropine and analgesia.
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • The feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology.

Contraindications:

  • Presence of genital tract infection and bleeding
  • Genital tuberculosis, due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Allergy to the dye
  • Premenstrual phase.
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

The instrument in the given image is Leech-Wilkinson canula and is used in hysterosalpingogram recording.

questions.text: A second-year general surgery resident, while studying the surgical anatomy for a laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair,  learns about the triangle of doom as an important surgical landmark. Which of the following is not a content of this triangle?
questions.solution:
The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve is not a content of the triangle of doom.

The triangle of doom is one of the important surgical landmarks in preperitoneal laparoscopic hernia repair. Staples and sutures in mesh hernioplasty should be avoided in this area to prevent injury to important structures such as the external iliac vessels and the femoral nerve.

The boundaries of the triangle of doom are:

  • Medially- ductus deferens
  • Laterally- gonadal vessels in the spermatic cord
  • Posteroinferiorly- peritoneal reflection
  • Apex- deep inguinal ring

The important contents of the triangle of Doom include:

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerve

Other important surgical landmarks in this region are the triangle of pain and the crown of death.

 (NOTE: Triangle of Doom and Triangle of Pain are adjacent to each other and hence share common boundaries. However, the femoral nerve and its course is through both the triangles giving different nerve innervations.)

questions.text: In a negatively skewed distribution, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
In negatively skewed distribution Mean<Median<Mode.

The normal distribution curve is a symmetric curve, also called the Bell curve. In the normal distribution curve, the mean = median = mode. The distribution can be skewed due to either abnormally low or abnormally high values. There are two types of skewing

  • Negative or left skewed: Mean < Median < Mode
  • Positive or right skewed: Mean > Median > Mode

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: A young man presented with right-sided chest pain and paradoxical respiration after he fell off a tree. The chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side suggest flail chest. Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided in the management of a flail chest. Mechanically impairing the chest wall movements along with the underlying lung contusions contribute to hypoxia.

A flail chest occurs when 3 or more ribs are fractured in 2 or more places usually due to blunt trauma. It can increase the risk of developing pneumothorax and hemothorax.

Diagnosis is made clinically by observing the paradoxical motion of the chest wall segment during respiration (paradoxical respiration). On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall gets displaced inwards and moves outwards on expiration. The gold standard investigation is a CT scan with contrast, with a 3-D reconstruction of the chest wall, displaying the vascular structures.

Treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates), epidural analgesia, and physiotherapy. Mechanical ventilation is recommended to treat respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with an increase in the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) except?
questions.solution:
An increase in the filtration fraction is associated with a fall in the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as the concentration of the plasma proteins increases which in turn raises the glomerular colloid osmotic pressure.

Factors that can increase the GFR are as follows:

  • Increase in glomerular capillary filtration coefficient Kf: This coefficient depends on the hydraulic conductivity and surface area of the glomerular capillaries. 
  • Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Conditions with urinary tract obstruction can lead to an increase in this pressure and a fall in GFR.
  • Decrease in glomerular colloid osmotic pressure: Accumulation of plasma proteins that are not filtered from the blood contributes to this pressure and an increase reduces the further filtration and GFR. It is directly proportional to the following factors:
    • Arterial plasma colloid osmotic pressure 
    • Filtration fraction

Thus an increase in filtration fraction concentrates the plasma proteins and raises the glomerular colloid osmotic pressure which in turn decreases the GFR.

questions.text: A family physician noticed that the routine blood test results of his 59-year-old patient show a Hb level of 18 g/dL. He wants to differentiate between absolute polycythemia and relative polycythemia. Which of the following test should be done?
questions.solution:
An increase in the hemoglobin level above normal limits is called polycythemia. RBC mass is measured to differentiate between absolute and relative polycythemia.

Polycythemia is an increase in hemoglobin level > 17 g/dL in males and > 15 g/dL in females. An actual increase in the number of RBCs is seen in absolute polycythemia, whereas, an apparent increase due to decreased plasma volume is seen in relative polycythemia. These two conditions can be differentiated by measuring RBC mass, which is increased in absolute polycythemia and is normal in relative polycythemia. 

Once the diagnosis of absolute polycythemia is made, erythropoietin (EPO) levels are measured to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. Primary polycythemia has low or normal EPO levels, whereas secondary polycythemia has elevated EPO levels.

Other options

Option A: Jak-2 mutation analysis is done if the EPO levels are low and polycythemia vera is suspected.

Option C: Arterial O2 saturation is measured if the EPO levels are elevated. If the O2 saturation is low, further evaluation for COPD, heart disease, or intracardiac shunt is necessary. 

Option D: Carboxy-hemoglobin levels are measured in smokers if O2 saturation is normal, whereas, O2 hemoglobin affinity is measured in non-smokers.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with a history of recurrent abscesses secondary to staphylococcus aureus infection. Primary immunodeficiency was suspected. The nitro-blue tetrazolium test was performed which was negative. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this patient with a suspected primary immunodeficiency, repeated infections with Staphylococcus aureus (catalase-positive organisms) and a negative nitro-blue tetrazolium test is suggestive of Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).

It is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase, the enzyme responsible for the generation of superoxide during the respiratory burst. Defective inherent production of reactive oxygen species leads to increased susceptibility to life-threatening infections- pulmonary, cutaneous, lymphatic, hepatic, and osteomyelitis. These patients are susceptible to catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus and Coliforms.

Nitro blue tetrazolium test can be used for the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease. The leukocytes fail to reduce nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) during phagocytosis in chronic granulomatous disease.

Other options: 

Option A: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is a disorder of T-lymphocytes (cellular immunity) and is characterized by the triad of recurrent severe infections, thrombocytopenia, and eczema. This patient does not present with eczema or symptoms of thrombocytopenia like petechiae, recurrent gum bleeds or nose bleeds.

Option C: Chediak- Higashi syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency due to a disorder of the phagolysosome function of leukocytes, leading to delayed microbial clearance. In addition, there is a disorder of melanin (albinism), nerve defects, and bleeding disorders.

Option D: Severe combined immunodeficiency is a primary immunodeficiency with a disorder of both cellular and humoral immunity. Persons with SCID are susceptible to recurrent severe infections caused by a wide variety of pathogens and usually do not survive beyond the first year of life without a stem cell transplant.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with a history of chronic abdominal pain, diarrhea, low-grade fever, weight loss, and fatigue. She underwent a colonoscopy which revealed a cobble-stone appearance. Which of the following type of renal stones is most commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, cobblestone appearance on colonoscopy is suggestive of Crohn's disease. Calcium oxalate stones are more commonly associated with Crohn's disease. 

In Crohn's disease, fatty acids are not absorbed because of ileal dysfunction. These fatty acids in the gut lumen bind to calcium. Because of this, the dietary oxalates which normally bind to calcium are now left unbound. This leads to increased absorption of dietary oxalates causing hyperoxaluria and oxalate stones.

Clinical features of Crohn's disease:

Cardinal manifestations

  • Crampy abdominal pain may be limited to the right lower quadrant in patients with ileal disease.
  • Intermittent and persistent diarrhea: Fluid secretion/impaired absorption in the inflamed bowel, bile acid malabsorption, steatorrhea due to loss of bile salts, and enteroenteric fistulas.
  • Fatigue
  • Fistulae and abscesses
  • Malabsorption

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Arthritis and arthropathy
  • Uveitis, iritis and episcleritis
  • Erythema nodosum and pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Secondary amyloidosis
  • Renal stones: Calcium oxalate stones
  • Bone loss
  • Pulmonary involvement: Bronchiectasis, chronic bronchitis, ILD, BOOP, sarcoidosis.

 Gross features of Crohn's disease include:

  • Aphthous ulcers
  • Longitudinal ulcers
  • Skip lesions
  • Creeping fat
  • Cobblestone appearance

Microscopically aphthoid ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses are the earliest lesions. There is transmural inflammation. Non-caseating granulomas can be found in all layers of affected organs Other histologic features of CD include submucosal or subserosal lymphoid aggregates, microscopic skip areas, and pseudo pyloric metaplasia

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with seizures. Her parents said this started 15 minutes back and has been continuous. Initial resuscitative measures are taken, and she is given lorazepam. However, her seizures didn’t subside. Which antiepileptic drug is indicated now?
questions.solution:
This patient with seizures for more than 15 minutes has status epilepticus. The treatment algorithm is shown below. According to this, this patient, who did not respond to lorazepam needs phenytoin.

Note: Status epilepticus is defined as continuous seizures or repetitive seizures with impaired consciousness in the interictal period.

The duration of seizure activity to meet the definition of status epilepticus has traditionally been specified as 15–30 min. However, a more practical definition is to consider status epilepticus as a situation in which the duration of seizures prompts the acute use of anticonvulsant therapy, i.e., more than 5 minutes.

questions.text: For effective protection against pregnancy after unprotected intercourse, what is the correct method of taking centchroman?

choices.text: One 30mg tablet taken once within 24 hours
One 30mg tablet taken twice at an interval of 12 hours
Two 30mg tablets taken twice at an interval of 12 hours
Two 30mg tablets taken once within 24 hours

questions.solution:
For emergency contraception, the dosage of centchroman tablets to be taken is 2 tablets each of 30mg (total of 60mg) taken twice at an interval of 12 hours, within 24 hours after unprotected intercourse:

  • 1st dose- 2 tablets of 30 mg each
  • 2nd dose (After 12 hours of the first dose)- 2 tablets of 30 mg each

Centchroman (Ormeloxifene) is the first non-steroidal oral contraceptive pill to be manufactured in the world. It was released in India under the brand name- Saheli. The Govt. of India has included Centchroman in the National Family Planning initiative for its distribution to women free of cost under the brand name Chhaya. 

It offers a combination of weak estrogenic and potent antiestrogenic properties. It is the only contraceptive that neither suppresses ovulation nor interferes with the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

Centchroman can be taken as a regular oral contraceptive pill. The schedule is as follows:

  • First 3 months: One tablet (30mg) has to be taken twice weekly
  • After 3 months: One tablet (30mg) once weekly

It inhibits the implantation of the fertilized ovum and thus prevents pregnancy, but at the same time, it does not appear to disturb the other estrogen effects. Fertility returns about 6 months after stopping centchroman.

Apart from contraception, Centchroman is also used in the management of dysfunctional uterine bleeding, mastalgia, and fibroadenoma and has promising therapeutic efficacy in a variety of cancers including breast cancer.

The side effects of using Centchroman include headache, nausea, weight gain, and endometrial hyperplasia in case of prolonged usage.

The contraindications of using Centchroman are 6 months of lactation, polycystic ovarian disease, hepatic dysfunction, and cervical dysplasia.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman who is a known diabetic comes with frequent urination, and an increased urge to pass the urine, but passes urine in large quantities before reaching the lavatory. What would be your advice to this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient here is suffering from urge incontinence/overactive bladder due to detrusor muscle instability, therefore bladder training is the appropriate management among the given options, as other options are treatment modalities of stress incontinence.

A patient who suffers from urge incontinence might present with:

  • A patient experiences involuntary escape of urine with the urge to urinate
  • This happens many times during the daytime and may also happen during the night
  • It might also happen during intercourse and just by hearing the sound of water     

Detrusor Instability: Incontinence happens when the detrusor muscle contracts on provocation/spontaneously during the filling phase when inhibition of micturition is attempted. It is mostly caused by parasympathetic overactivity, seen most commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity.

Causes of detrusor instability are functional/psychosomatic, diabetic neuropathy, cerebrovascular accidents, multiple sclerosis, spinal injury, parkinsonism, urinary infection, which can occur following surgeries, etc

Treatment involves low caffeine and nonsmoking, bladder training, restricted fluid intake, and weight reduction. Anticholinergic drugs are useful.

Note: Stress incontinence is usually confused with urge incontinence, in stress incontinence, there is no desire/urge to pass the urine, but passes a small amount of urine during a stressful activity like coughing, sneezing, straining, or physical activity. This is managed with pelvic floor exercises or surgical treatments like sling operations or Kelly's repair.

questions.text: The Langerhans cells present in the epidermis develop from:
questions.solution:
The Langerhans cells are macrophage immune cells derived from the bone marrow. These cells first appear in the epidermis by the seventh week and later continue to migrate to the epidermis throughout life. They play a role in immune surveillance against microorganisms and play a role in the pathogenesis of contact sensitivity (allergic skin reaction).

Development of the skin:

The epidermis is derived from the surface ectoderm. These ectodermal cells differentiate into keratinocytes and Merkel cells. The melanocytes present in the epidermis are derived from the neural crest cells while the Langerhans cells are derived from the bone marrow.

The dermis (exception, face) is derived from mesoderm. The ventral dermis develops from the somatic layer of the lateral plate mesoderm, whereas the dorsal dermis develops from the dermamyotome subdivision of the somites. The dermis of the face is derived from neural crest cells.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man died within few days after being diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma. The autopsy revealed a yellowish, spherical neoplasm in one pole of the kidney. The tumor cells invaded the renal vein and extended as a solid column up to the inferior vena cava. Histopathology is shown below. Which of the following subtypes of renal cell carcinoma, is most likely possible?
questions.solution:
The presence of yellow-colored spherical mass associated with tumor cells invading the renal vein is characteristic of clear cell carcinoma. Histopathology shows tumor cells with clear cytoplasm.

Clear-cell carcinoma is the most common type, accounting for 70 to 80% of renal cell cancers. They most likely arise from the proximal tubular epithelium as solitary lesions.

The tumor cells have a rounded or polygonal shape and abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids arranged in a solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular pattern. The lesion appears usually as a solitary, bright yellow-gray-white spherical masses of variable size. The yellow color is due to the prominent lipid accumulations in tumor cells.

Clear-cell RCC has a characteristic tendency to invade the renal vein, where, the tumor may grow as a solid column of cells that can extend up the inferior vena cava, sometimes as far as the right side of the heart.

Image: Microscopy of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A 25-year-old sportsperson presents with pain in the left knee after sustaining an injury while playing football. You observe the resident performing the following test on this patient. The test which is being done is_____
questions.solution:
The test done in the image is Apley's test, it is used to detect injuries to the menisci and it is done with the patient lying in the prone position.

Apley's test: This test is done with the patient prone, the knee is flexed to 90  degrees and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. This reproduces symptoms if a meniscus is torn. Rotation is then repeated while the leg is pulled upwards by the doctor, holding the thigh down, which is called the distraction test. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.

Other options:

McMurray's test: This test is used to detect injuries to the menisci. The patient is positioned in a supine posture with the knee fully flexed. The knee joint is stabilized and palpated using one hand, while the other hand is utilized to internally and externally rotate the leg. Gradual extension of the leg is performed during this examination. If there is any detectable clicking sensation or sound, it may indicate a meniscal injury.

Option C: Lachman test is also done to detect injuries to the anterior cruciate ligament. In this examination, the patient's knee is flexed at a 20-degree angle. The examiner uses one hand to hold the lower thigh and the other to grasp the upper part of the leg. The joint surfaces are then shifted backward and forwards upon each other. Any abnormal movement observed during this test may indicate a potential anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury.

 

Option D: The Thessaly test is done to detect meniscal tears. In this test, the affected knee is flexed at a 20-degree angle, and the patient places the foot flat on the ground. While being supported by the examiner, the patient bears their full weight on that leg. They are then instructed to twist their body to one side and then the other, repeating this movement three times, while maintaining the knee flexed at 20 degrees. Individuals with meniscal tears may feel pain along the medial or lateral joint line and may also sense a locking sensation in the knee.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient who is a known case of diabetes mellitus presents with skin findings as shown in the image below.  On examination, he complained of pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot. On further questioning, the patient revealed that he was started on antidepressants recently. What could be the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of diabetes mellitus, antidepressant intake, with pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot(Positive Homan's sign indicating deep vein thrombosis), and the image showing necrolytic migratory rash is suggestive of glucagonoma.

Glucagonoma is a pancreatic islet cell tumor. It is a rare syndrome, with a classic presentation of the “4 D’s”: diabetes, dermatitis, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and depression. It is a state of severe catabolism. Patients present with loss of weight, depletion of protein and fat stores, and vitamin deficiency.  The characteristic skin lesion seen in this condition is the necrolytic migratory erythema which occurs due to severe amino acid deficiency. Providing parental amino acids may help in the disappearance of skin lesions. 

Diagnosis of this condition is made by measuring fasting glucagon levels. A level of more than 1000pg/ml is diagnostic. (Normal - 100pg/ml) Management involves the correction of nutritional deficiencies with enteral nutrition. Octreotide can help reverse the catabolic state. DVT prophylaxis should be provided as soon as possible. Surgery can be done if the mass is resectable. 

Other options: 

Option A - Gastrinomas are islet cell tumors that produce large amounts of gastrin. This gastrin does not respond to the normal feedback mechanism and is not suppressed by high luminal pH. Patients with gastrinomas present with abdominal pain and diarrhea. 

Option B - Insulinomas are the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. They are characterized by symptoms of hypoglycemia, low plasma glucose at the time of symptoms, and relief of symptoms on glucose consumption. This is known as the Whipple's triad.

Option D - VIPoma is a neuroendocrine tumor that arises from the pancreatic D2 islet cells. It is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. It is also referred to as pancreatic cholera. 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

questions.text: A primigravida gives birth to a term baby. You, as a medical officer, counsel her about breastfeeding. Which of the following is a sign of poor attachment of the baby to the breast?
questions.solution:
Signs of good attachment of baby’s mouth to nipple include

  • The mouth is wide open
  • Most of the nipple and areola are in the mouth and only upper areola is visible
  • The baby’s chin is touching the breast
  • The lower lip everted

Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for 6 months. Complementary foods rich in iron and other micronutrients should be introduced at about 6 months of age. Breastfeeding should continue for at least the first year.

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

  • Colostrum is secret in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains a large number of antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 
  • Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.
  • Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the optimum growth of the baby as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.
  • A mother who delivers before 37 weeks secretes preterm milk that contains proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobulin, and calories as needed by the preterm infant.

questions.text: During the development of the fetal heart, which of the following forms the smooth part of the atrium behind the crista terminalis?
questions.solution:
The crista terminalis is present in the right atrium and the smooth part behind it is formed by the right horn of sinus venosus.

The right atrium is primarily derived from the following three sources:

  • The right half of the primitive atrium gives rise to the rough trabeculated part in front of the crista terminalis. This is also known as the atrium proper.
  • The right horn of the sinus venosus gets absorbed into the primitive atrium to form the smooth part behind the crista terminalis. This is also known as sinus venarum.
  • The right half of the atrioventricular canal gets absorbed and gives rise to the smooth part present most ventrally.

Other options:

Option A: The primitive atrium gives rise to the rough parts of both the right and left atria.

Option B: The proximal parts of the primitive pulmonary vein forms the smooth part of the left atrium.

Option D: Left horn and body of the sinus venosus reduce in size to form the coronary sinus.

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient has been on an antipsychotic for the last 2 years. He presents with stereotypical, repetitive and involuntary tic like movements of the face, eyelid spasm, and slow twisting movements of the tongue. Diagnose and identify the proposed mechanism of action of the condition.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is tardive dyskinesia and the proposed mechanism of action is dopamine receptor supersensitivity.

Tardive dyskinesia is an extrapyramidal side effect (EPSE) of antipsychotic drugs that present after long-term usage. It usually presents after months to years of drug usage. It is more common in the elderly population. It is characterized by orofacial involvement. Stereotypical involuntary, repetitive tic-like movements of the face, eyelid spasm, and slow twisting movements of the tongue are the presenting symptoms. The movements disappear during sleep and may vary in intensity with relation to the degree of emotional distress.

The proposed mechanism of action is dopamine postsynaptic receptor supersensitivity leading to increased nigrostriatal dopaminergic activity. Management of tardive dyskinesia-

  • FDA-approved VMAT2 inhibitors - valbenazine and deutetrabenazine are used as drugs for treatment.
  • Anticholinergics are contraindicated as they worsen the symptoms.
  • Switching patients to clozapine can be effective

Note:

Dystonia - The characteristic symptoms for diagnosis of dystonia are acute onset within 1-5 days of starting treatment. It is more common in the younger population. The proposed mechanism of action is D2 blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway. There is typical involvement of head and neck muscles and presents in a variety of forms, such as torticollis, trismus, “mouth opening” dystonia, grimacing, dysarthria, oculogyric crisis, blepharospasm, and swallowing difficulties.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman at the onset of labor is wheeled into the CHC. On examination, multiple painful vesicles are present on the labia and on probing into history reveals she has had a burning sensation in the genital area for the past few days. The close-up view of the lesions is as in the image below. What is the management protocol to be followed for this patient?

choices.text: Deliver vaginally and administer the newborn with prophylactic acyclovir
Administer IM benzyl-penicillin to the mother and proceed with vaginal delivery
Deliver the baby by caesarean section
Proceed with vacuum or forceps delivery

questions.solution:
The lesions suggest genital herpes and women who present with these lesions at the onset of labor should be delivered by cesarean section to prevent neonatal herpes.

All pregnant women should be asked about the history of genital herpes and looked for herpetic lesions on examination. Pregnant women who have the first episode of genital herpes or severe recurrent herpes can be treated with oral acyclovir.

Pregnant women who do not have any prodrome or signs and symptoms of genital herpes can deliver vaginally.

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: It is the safest in procedures close to vital structures
It can be used for coagulation
It can be used for cutting
There is more thermal dissipation of current

questions.solution:
From the single-tipped electrode in the cautery image shown below, we can identify the instrument is a unipolar cautery. The false statement is option A. Due to a high thermal spread in unipolar cautery, it is not the safest instrument during procedures close to vital structures. The vitals structures are at risk of thermal injury with this instrument. 

Electrosurgery is the use of high-frequency currents to cut or coagulate tissue during surgery. It can be performed using:

  • Monopolar or unipolar cautery: consists of a single electrode tip
  • Bipolar cautery: consists of two electrode tips in the form of scissors, graspers, etc. 

Other options

Option B: It is true that unipolar cautery can be used for coagulating tissue. The two main settings in unipolar and bipolar cautery are:

  • Coagulation mode: Blue button in the image above.
  • Cutting mode: Yellow button in the image above

In the coagulation mode, a high-voltage current is produced that spreads over a greater surface area. This helps to produce a dehydration effect on the tissues and is very useful when trying to stop the bleeding from nicked vessels during surgery. 

Option C: It is true, as mentioned above that unipolar cautery can be used for cutting tissue. Cutting mode produces a low voltage current that acts on a smaller surface area. This makes it more effective in heating the tissue than in the coagulation mode. The thermal spread will also be less than the coagulation mode, making it safer. 

Option D: It is true that monopolar cautery produces more thermal dissipation of current.

questions.text: An obese male patient has been recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease and hypertension. He is started on atorvastatin. Which of the following additional medication can be safely prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Atenolol is a beta-blocker and an anti-hypertensive medication that can be safely prescribed along with statins like atorvastatin because atenolol does not have much interaction with statin metabolism.

Statins are hypolipidemic drugs that act by competitively inhibiting the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase. This allows for a compensatory increase in LDL receptors in the liver and thereby increases LDL catabolism. 

They are well tolerated. However, they can cause notable side effects such as myopathy and liver injury. They occur commonly when statins are concurrently given with nicotinic acid, gemfibrozil, or CYP3A4 inhibitors such as:

  • Macrolide antibiotics (erythromycin/clarithromycin)
  • Ketoconazole
  • Cyclosporine
  • HIV protease inhibitors
  • Warfarin
  • Digoxin
  • Azole antifungals
  • Amiodarone

Other options: 

Option A: Gemfibrozil is a fibrate that inhibits the hepatic uptake of statins by the organic anion transporter OATP1B1 and prevents its metabolism, thereby increasing its bioavailability. Thus, the risk of toxicity of statins increases. Concurrent use of gemfibrozil with statins most commonly causes myopathy (rhabdomyolysis). 

Option C: Digoxin used concurrently with a statin can increase the risk of myopathy.

Option D: Nicotinic acid (Niacin) used concurrently with statins can cause myopathy due to inhibition of skeletal muscle cholesterol synthesis. 

Related Pearl: Metabolism of drugs

Drugs metabolized by cyp3A4 enzymes:

  • Protease inhibitors
  • Statins
  • Benzodiazepines
  • Amiodarone
  • Estrogen
  • Erythromycin

questions.text: A statistical test has a type I error of 0.4 and a type II error of 0.3. What is the power of this test?
questions.solution:
The power of the statistical test is 0.7.

Type I error is a false positive error that occurs when the alternative (or experimental) hypothesis is accepted even though it is false. It is also known as alpha error (α = 0.4). 

Type II error is a false negative error that occurs when the alternative (or experimental) hypothesis is rejected even though it is true. It is also known as beta error (β = 0.3). 

The statistical power of a test is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected. This is calculated as 1-β. Thus the power of the given test is 1 - 0.3 = 0.7 in this case.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with right-sided abdominal pain for the past 3 hours and mild bleeding per vaginum. Her LMP was 5 weeks ago. On examination, tenderness of the right iliac fossa is present. Ultrasound shows a gestational sac in the right fallopian tube. Which of these features, if present, would make you opt for surgical management over methotrexate?

choices.text: A Gestational sac size of 2.9 cm

questions.solution:
A beta HCG of >5000 IU/L would make one opt for surgical management over methotrexate. Although this is not a contraindication to methotrexate use, the chance of successful management is less with higher beta HCG values.

Other factors that would make one opt for surgical management are:

  • Sac >4 cm
  • Fetal heart rate (FHR) present
  • Patient hemodynamically unstable

 

Methotrexate is used in the medical management of ectopic pregnancy. It has certain absolute and relative contraindications. When used in conditions that are relatively contraindicated, the risk of failure is high.      

Absolute contraindications:  

  • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Intrauterine pregnancy
  • Evidence of immunodeficiency
  • Moderate to severe anaemia, leukopenia and thrombocytopenia
  • Active pulmonary disease
  • Active peptic ulcer disease
  • Sensitivity to methotrexate
  • Clinically significant hepatic impairment
  • Clinically significant renal impairment
  • Breastfeeding

Relative contraindications:

  • Embryonic cardiac activity determined by transvaginal ultrasonography
  • High initial HCG concentration
  • Ectopic pregnancy greater than 4cm in size as by TV sonography
  • Refusal to accept a blood transfusion

questions.text: A known case of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency room with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.  She has a fruity odor of breath and is hyperglycemic. Which of the following is the rate-limiting enzyme for the product responsible for the given positive test?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with the image showing positive Rothera's test is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. The positive Rothera's test is given by ketone bodies and the rate-limiting enzyme in ketone bodies synthesis is mitochondrial HMG CoA synthase.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state. There is an increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA which in turn leads to increased ketone body production. The presence of ketosis can be established by the detection of ketone bodies in urine by Rothera's test.

The ketone bodies synthesized in the liver mitochondria are transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues, where they are utilized by the following steps:

  • β-hydroxybutyrate is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  • Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetate CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  • Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

Ketone bodies are utilized by extrahepatic tissue like the cardiac muscle and renal cortex (prefer the ketone bodies to glucose as fuel). Tissues like skeletal muscle and the brain can also utilize the ketone bodies as alternate sources of energy if glucose is not available.

RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria. The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

Rothera's test:

  • Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulfate.
  • Add 3 drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside
  • Add 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube.

The development of a purple ring at the junction of the two liquids (shown in the image below) indicates the presence of acetone or acetoacetic acid in urine. It is not answered by beta-hydroxybutyrate. 

Other options

Option A: HMG CoA lyase is involved in ketone body synthesis

Option B: HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the synthesis of cholesterol.

Option D: Cytoplasmic HMG CoA synthase is involved in cholesterol synthesis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was incidentally diagnosed with a non-functional adrenal tumor of size 3 cm during his routine check-up. Subsequently, in about 3 months, the size of the tumor in MRI increases by about 40%. The next ideal step in the treatment of this patient would be:

choices.text: CT-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the tumor

questions.solution:
From the given description, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is the ideal and definitive management in non-functional adrenal tumors, i.e, incidentalomas more than 4 cm in size. An increase in the size of the tumor by 40% indicates an increase in size by 1.2 cm. Thus, the total size of the tumor here is 4.2 cm. 

An adrenal incidentaloma is defined as a clinically unapparent adrenal lesion that is incidentally detected in imaging studies. The majority of these lesions are non-functional.  Secondary metastasis from breast, lung, and kidneys are seen in 2% of the patients. Functional tumors may present with Cushing's syndrome, phaeochromocytoma, Conn's syndrome, etc. These tumors can become malignant and the incidence increases 4-fold if the size of the lesion crosses 4 cm. 

Management of non-functional incidentalomas < 4cm is conservative with routine MRI surveillance every 3-6 months. If > 4cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is done.

 Other options - 

A. Hormonal assay studies are done in suspected functional tumours or patients presenting with symptoms. If positive, it should be managed accordingly. Observation is not a followed protocol unless they're not functional or benign. 

B. Fine-needle aspiration and biopsy is avoided as it is inconclusive to distinguish adrenal adenomas from carcinomas. It can be considered in suspected extra-adrenal secondary metastasis. Tests for pheochromocytoma should always be done before the procedure to avoid precipitating a hypertensive crisis.

C. Follow-up MRI with 3-6 months surveillance is done for non-functional tumors <4cm size.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented with swelling at the lower end of the thigh. He has severe pain at the swelling during the night which reduces after taking aspirin. X-ray shows peripheral reactive sclerotic rim with central radiolucent nidus.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young man, with painful swelling in the lower end of the thigh which worsens at night, pain relieved on aspirin intake, and an X-ray showing peripheral sclerotic rim with central radiolucent nidus is suggestive of osteoid osteoma. 

Osteoid osteoma is a benign diaphyseal neoplasm most often seen in men between the ages of 5-25 years. Most of the cases appear in the lower extremities commonly in the femur and tibia. A patient typically presents with pain that worsens at night and gets relieved on NSAID intake.

Radiography shows a sclerotic peripheral rim with central radiolucent nidus. A CT scan can be used to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.

Anti-inflammatory medication can be used for long-term medical management. Percutaneous radiofrequency ablation can be used as an outpatient procedure. Removal of the entire nidus can be done by curettage or en-bloc resection.

Other options:

Option A: Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor occurring mainly in the diaphysis of long bones. On X-ray, the cortical destruction and new bone formation in layers are seen as onion peel appearance as shown below.

Option B- Chondroblastoma is a benign cartilaginous tumor occurring mainly in bones around the knee joint. On X-rays, they appear as a well-circumscribed, round, or oval lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of long bones with areas of calcification within the tumor. This is termed a mottled appearance.

The image below shows an X-ray with a well-circumscribed, round lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of the tibia suggestive of chondroblastoma.

Option D: Osteoblastoma is a benign bone tumor composed of vascular osteoid and newly formed bone. It also presents with pain but has a predilection for the jaw and spine. It occurs in patients in their second decade of life. Radiographically, the tumor appears as a well-defined, expansile lesion in the bone with a radiolucent appearance. Minimal formation of reactive new bone is observed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came to the hospital with a history of palpitations and chest pain.ECG of the patient was suggestive of atrial fibrillation. The direct oral factor Xa inhibitor drug was used to prevent stroke in this patient. Identify this drug?
questions.solution:
Rivaroxaban is a direct oral factor Xa inhibitor that is used for stroke prevention in patients with atrial fibrillation. 

Direct factor Xa inhibitors inhibit both the free and clot-associated factor Xa and thus prevent thrombin formation. This in turn suppresses platelet aggregation and fibrin formation. It includes drugs like rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban. These drugs are administered via the oral route. 

Just like other anticoagulants, the major adverse effect is bleeding. Andexanet alfa is recombinant factor Xa used in cases of severe bleeding associated with these drugs as a reversal agent. These drugs are also substrates of the P-glycoprotein pump (Pgp). Inducers or inhibitors of Pgp can thus alter the drug levels of these agents.

Apart from stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, direct Xa inhibitors are also used in the treatment of acute deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. Rivaroxaban and apixaban are indicated for post-operative thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing orthopedic surgery. Low-dose rivaroxaban combined with aspirin is required in cases of coronary or peripheral vascular disease to prevent major cardiac or limb adverse effects.

The need to initiate oral anticoagulation for stroke prevention is based on the CHA2DS2VASc score. It includes risk factors like congenital heart disease, age >75, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, prior stroke, vascular disease, age > 65, and sex category (females). Each of these parameters carries a score of 1 except for prior stroke and age>75 which carries a score of 2. Anticoagulation can be started if the score > 1 unless the female gender is the only risk factor.

Other options:

Options A & C: Bivalirudin, argatroban, and desirudin are parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors.

Option D: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor and can also be used for stroke prevention.

2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)

questions.text: The labor room quality improvement initiative advocates which of the following labor room practices?

choices.text: Immediate clamping and cutting of the umbilical cord
Conventional lithotomy position for the delivery
Separating the baby from the mother for routine care & procedure
Presence of birth companion during the labor

questions.solution:
The labor room quality improvement initiative, LaQshya advocates the presence of a birth companion during labor.

Do’s and Don’ts of Labour Room:

DO’s

  • Providing privacy to pregnant women during the intrapartum period (separate labor room or private cubicle)
  • Presence of birth companion during the labor
  • Freedom to choose a comfortable position during birthing (squatting, standing, etc.) (Option B)
  • Adherence to clinical protocols for the management of labor
  • Use of labour beds instead of tables
  • Placing baby on mother’s abdomen
  • Initiation of breastfeeding within one hour of birth

DON'Ts

  • Induction and augmentation of labour without sound clinical indications
  • Any verbal or physical abuse of pregnant women
  • Insisting on conventional lithotomy position for the delivery
  • Immediate clamping and cutting of the umbilical cord (Option A)
  • Separating the baby from the mother for routine care & procedure (Option C)
  • Out of Pocket Expenditures (OOPE) on drugs, diagnostics, including demand by the staff for gratuitous payment by families for the celebration of the baby’s birth.

questions.text:
A study yields the following result:
An increase in smoking tobacco is associated with a decrease in life expectancy. 
This is an example of________
questions.solution:
An increase in smoking tobacco is associated with a decrease in life expectancy. This is an example of negative correlation (-r).

The correlation coefficient (r) has a value varying from -1 to +1. The number represents the strength of the relationship between the 2 variables while its sign represents the direction of correlation. In the given case, since high values of one variable (such as smoking of tobacco) is associated with low values of the other (life expectancy) it is an example of a negative correlation. When high values of one variable are associated with high values of the other variable it indicates a positive correlation. 

Regression is a technique of predicting the value of a dependent variable from an independent one when the two variables are highly correlated.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

Related Pearl: Regression

When two variables are correlated, the value of one of the variables can be predicted from the value of the other using regression techniques.

  • Independent variable: The variable from which the other variable is calculated.
  • Dependent variable: The variable for which the value is calculated.

Types of regression:

1. Simple linear regression

  • In this, the value of one variable (y) is used to predict the value of another variable (x).
  • The regression equation is used for this purpose. It gives a straight-line relationship between the two variables.
  • It is given by the equation y = a + bx, where, a is a constant called the intercept constant and b is the regression coefficient.
  • The intercept constant is the point where the Y-axis is intercepted by the regression line. 

 2. Multiple linear regression

  • In this, more than one variable is used to predict the expected value of another variable (y).
  • Here, the expected value of y = a + b1x1 + b2x2…..bnxn where b1 and b2…..bn represent different regression coefficients and x1, x2…….xn represents the known variables.

 3. Logistic regression

  •  In some situations, we are not interested in a numerical outcome (like risk, etc) but we want a nominal or categorical one (like death/survival, developing a disease/not developing a disease)
  • Here, the relationship between the variables will not be a linear one as the outcome from survival to death in relationship with the risk factor can change suddenly. Thus these outcomes are represented by 0 and 1.
  • Using a mathematical logistic function we can transform linear regression data, such that the values of a variable y are limited to the range of 0 to 1, which would give us the probability of y occurring for the given values of variable x.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient presented with features of quadriparesis for one year he now presents with dysarthria. On examination,  the deep tendon reflexes were absent. His sensory perceptions and the autonomic system are intact.  Which of the following is the only drug known to improve survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The only known drug to have a positive impact on survival in ALS patients is riluzole.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is the most common progressive motor neuron disease. It occurs due to the death of the affected corticospinal upper motor neurons(UMN) of the motor cortex, lower motor neurons(LMN) of the anterior horn of the spine, and cranial nerves innervating the bulbar muscles.

 Clinically, the patient presents with :

  • LMN findings: fasciculations, muscle cramps, asymmetric distal weakness, atrophy of the muscles 
  • UMN findings: spasticity, increased reflexes.
  • Cranial nerve findings: Difficulty in speaking, chewing, swallowing, breathing, and slurred speech
  • Pseudobulbar affect: degeneration of corticobulbar projections manifested as inappropriate laughing, crying, or yawning which is often mood incongruent or may be triggered by stimuli that would not have elicited such a response.

Interestingly, even during the late stages sensory, bowel and bladder, ocular motility, and cognitive functions are preserved.

Treatment of ALS:

  1. Riluzole (100mg/day) reduces excitotoxicity by diminishing glutamate release and improving survival.
  2. Edaravone is a newer drug approved by the FDA that has the capability of slowing down ALS progression and improving survival.

Other options:

Option A: IV immunoglobulin is the recommended initial therapy for patients in the treatment of Guillain-Barre syndrome(GBS).

Option C: Memantine is used in Alzheimer's disease.

Option D: Ropinirole is a dopaminergic agonist approved for Parkinson's disease and restless leg syndrome.

questions.text: A man presents to the OPD with recurrent attacks of burning micturition and urethral discharge. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is given in the image below. Deficiency of which of the following complement factors increases the risk of development of this infection?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario along with the microscopic findings of Gram‐negative intracellular diplococci indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. A deficiency of membrane attack complex(C5b6789) leads to an increased risk of recurrent Neisseria infections.

Complement factor C5b binds to the late components C6-C9, resulting in the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Neisseria has thin cell walls, hence it is susceptible to lysis to the Membrane attack complex(MAC). Hence, deficiency of this complex leads to an increased risk of recurrent Neisseria infections.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by N. gonorrhea. The major symptoms include urethritis, vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria. In the laboratory diagnosis of N. gonorrhea, the discharge on Gram's stain reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. It acidifies glucose but not maltose in serum sugars. Stuart's medium is used for transport while Thayer-Martin agar is used as a selective medium used to isolate N. gonorrhoeae. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. 

Stuart’s medium is the transport media used for Neisseria gonorrhea and Neisseria meningitides. It is a semisolid, non-nutrient medium. Charcoal present in the medium neutralizes certain bacterial inhibitors while a reducing agent prevents oxidation.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: You manage a patient diagnosed with an early stage of squamous cell carcinoma of  anus with Nigro regimen. This regimen includes the combination of all the following except
questions.solution:
Nigro regimen used in the treatment of squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal includes all the above except epirubicin.

Nigro regimen: It is used as a primary therapy. It includes a combination of chemotherapy and radiation (combined modality therapy).

Treatment of squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal:

  • The primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma is by chemoradiotherapy (Nigro regimen)
  • A combination of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) with mitomycin C/ cisplatin is followed by external beam radiation to the pelvis with a minimum dose of 45 Gy.
  • Patients with a persistent disease which is diagnosed on pathological examination are managed with abdominoperineal resection.

The most common type of anal canal carcinoma is SCC. The patient presents with perianal mass, pain, anal discharge, and bleeding. The most common site of metastasis is the liver. The nodal metastasis is seen in peri-rectal and inguinal lymph nodes. Risk factors for carcinoma anal canal include HPV infection (16, 18, 31, 33), HIV or immunosuppression, and anal receptive intercourse.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought due to complaints of hallucinations, abnormal behavior, hydrophobia, and insomnia. He was bitten by a stray dog 4 weeks ago. The patient dies a couple of days later. An autopsy revealed the presence of the following findings in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. What are these pathognomic microscopic findings called?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of abnormal behavior, hydrophobia, and hallucinations a few weeks after a dog bite is suggestive of rabies. Negri bodies are the pathognomonic microscopic finding in rabies.

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, sites that are usually devoid of inflammation.

The rabies virus can be detected within Negri bodies by ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods.

Image: Characteristic Negri bodies found in the Purkinje cell of the cerebellum.

questions.text: A young boy was noticed to have the following finding on general examination. Which among the following conditions is it most likely associated with?
questions.solution:
The lesion seen in the picture is that of the Shagreen patch. It is seen in Tuberous sclerosis.

Skin lesions in Tuberous sclerosis:

  • Shagreen patches are characteristic of tuberous sclerosis and consist of a roughened, raised lesions. They have an orange-peel consistency and are located primarily in the lumbosacral region
  • The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients (visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp).
  • Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age. They are tiny red nodules present over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. They can enlarge and coalesce to give a fleshy appearance.
  • Periungual fibromas are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients.
  • Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis (confetti=small pieces of paper used to throw at celebrations).

questions.text: The cerebral angiography of a patient is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The cerebral angiogram shows abnormal, dilated, and irregular collateral vessels (puff of smoke appearance) which are characteristic of Moya Moya disease.

Moyamoya represents an idiopathic arteriopathy, which, although primarily involving the supraclinoid ICAs, often progresses to the proximal anterior and middle cerebral arteries, and occasionally the posterior circulation (typically the basilar tip). In advanced cases, there may be extensive dural, leptomeningeal, and pial collateral circulation.

A moyamoya-like pattern may be found in other conditions that result in an occlusive vasculopathy, such as intracranial vasculitis, sickle cell disease, post varicella arteriopathy, previous radiotherapy, down syndrome, congenital heart disease or type 1 neurofibromatosis.

questions.text: Which of the following ultrasonographic findings is seen in a pregnant woman with dichorionic twins?
questions.solution:
Twin peak/Lambda sign is seen in dichorionic pregnancy.

The "twin peak sign" appears as a triangular projection of the chorion extending between the amnion layers. A thick dividing membrane consisting of two amnion and two chorion layers points towards the diagnosis of dichorionic pregnancy.

Note: T sign is the absence of a twin peak sign. There is a lack of chorion extending between the amnion layers and hence, suggestive of a monochorionic pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Overdose of which of the following anti-arrhythmic drugs is correctly paired with its ECG side effects?

choices.text: Diltiazem – Increased PR interval and QRS duration

questions.solution:
Flecainide causes increased QRS duration. All other drugs are matched incorrectly.

The effect of various prototype antiarrhythmic drugs on ECG are as follows:

Group 1 Drugs:

Procainamide, disopyramide, quinidine (Group 1A):

  • PR interval may decrease due to antimuscarinic action or increase due to channel-blocking action.
  • Increase in QRS duration and QT interval.

Lidocaine, mexiletine (Group 1B):

  • There is normally no change in PR interval, QRS duration or QT interval.
  • However, they can slow conduction through ischemic, depolarized ventricular cells.

Flecainide (Group 1C) causes a slight increase in PR interval, increased QRS duration, and no change in QT interval.

Group 2 drugs:

Propranolol and esmolol cause an increased PR interval.

Group 3 drugs:

  • Amiodarone is often classified as group 3 but also has some group 1A properties. It causes increased PR interval, QRS duration, and QT interval.
  • Ibutilide, dofetilide causes increased QT interval.
  • Sotalol causes an increase in PR interval and QT interval.

Group 4 drugs such as verapamil and diltiazem cause an increase in PR interval. The QRS duration and QT interval are unaffected.
