questions.text: You notice the following while exploring your hospital's principal biomedical waste handling facility.  Which of the following statements is correct regarding the equipment used for sterilization in the image shown below?

choices.text: It sterilizes using steam under pressure
Used for destroying biomedical waste such as human anatomical waste
Holding time is at least 15 minutes at 121 °C
Coagulation of proteins occur by this method

questions.solution:
The given image shows an incinerator. Incineration is the terminal sterilization for destroying biomedical waste such as human anatomical waste.

The biomedical waste material is exposed to a very high temperature inside the incinerator converting the material into ash. Incineration is used for the disposal of human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste (contaminated dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs), expired or discarded medicines, chemical waste, etc. 

Other equipment used in sterilization include:

Hot air oven- A holding period of 160 C for two hours is necessary to sterilize glassware, forceps, scissors, scalpels, swabs, and some pharmaceutical products such as liquid paraffin, and dusting powder.

 

UV sterilization: Ultraviolet radiation is used for disinfecting enclosed areas such as biosafety cabinets in laboratories, operation theatres, and laboratories. The given image shows UV sterilization in a biosafety cabinet.

 

Autoclave - Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. Autoclave sterilizes using steam under pressure. It is used to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, cardiac catheters, and implants.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man who is a known hypertensive comes to the hospital with an altered sensorium. His blood pressure is found to be 190/110. CT scan revealed an intraparenchymal haemorrhage. 
What is the commonest site for this haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of hypertensive haemorrhage. The most common site (50-60%)of hypertensive haemorrhage in the brain is the putamen.

Hypertension is the risk factor most commonly associated with deep brain parenchymal haemorrhages. The haemorrhages are typically located in the deep white matter or deep gray structures followed by the brainstem and cerebellum.

questions.text: During radical neck dissection in a case of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx, the oncosurgeon points out the given structure. Which of the following muscles is not supplied by it?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the ansa cervicalis. The geniohyoid is innervated by the first cervical spinal nerve and not ansa cervicalis. 

Ansa cervicalis is a loop of nerves that are a part of the cervical plexus. It is made up of two roots. The upper root has contributions from the first cervical spinal nerve, and the lower root has contributions from the second and third cervical spinal nerves. It innervates the sternohyoid, sternothyroid, and omohyoid muscles.

Thyrohyoid and geniohyoid are not supplied by ansa cervicalis. They are supplied by branches of the first cervical spinal nerve via the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient underwent resection of the gastric antrum. A few weeks later, endoscopy revealed atrophy of the gastric mucosa. Serum levels of which of the following hormone is likely to be decreased?
questions.solution:
Serum levels of the gastrin are most likely to be reduced.

Gastrin is secreted by the G cells in the gastric antrum. Gastrin has two main actions:

  • Stimulates secretion of H+ by gastric parietal cells
  • Promotes growth of the gastric mucosa (trophic action)

Conditions associated with increased gastrin secretions (Ex: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), will cause an increase in H+ secretion and hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa. Conditions associated with reduced gastrin secretion (Ex: Resection of the gastric antrum), will cause a decrease in H+ secretion and atrophy of the gastric mucosa.

Secretin, cholecystokinin, and motilin are released by various cells in different parts of the small intestine and remain unaffected by the atrophy of gastric mucosa.

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Indirect pathway

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: The naked DNA is lysed by the enzyme DNAse. Which of following methods of gene transfer will mostly likely be inhibited when two strains of bacteria are mixed in the presence of DNAse?
questions.solution:
Transformation will most likely be inhibited as it involves the direct uptake of naked DNA by the recipient cell from the environment.

 Transformation is the direct uptake of naked DNA by the bacterial cell from the environment. Several bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria undergo transformation. 

The transfer of genes for diphtheria toxin on a corynebacteriophage occurs by transduction.

Other options

Option A: Conjugation is the method of gene transfer in bacteria that involves physical contact by a male or donor bacterium with a female or recipient bacterium through an extracellular protein extrusion or appendage called the sex pili. The genetic material that is transferred is usually derived from plasmids. The bacteria that possess the ability to form the sex pili contain the F+ plasmid and are designated as F+. The F+ bacteria can transfer a single strand of the F+ plasmid DNA to F- bacteria via the sex pili. 

Option C: Transduction can be defined as the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage. This type of horizontal gene transfer may occur by two mechanisms:

  • Lytic cycle - In the lytic cycle, also known as the virulent cycle, a large number of progeny phages build up inside the host bacterium; eventually, the host cell ruptures, releasing the bacteriophages. Some of the bacteriophages will now contain bacterial DNA, which can then be transferred to other bacteria.
  • Lysogenic cycle - In the temperate or non-lytic cycle, the host bacterium is not lysed. Rather, the phage DNA becomes integrated with the bacterial chromosome. This phage DNA multiplies with the host cell and is transferred to daughter cells. 

Option D: Transposition is a process of gene transfer that involves special segments of DNA called transposons (jumping genes).

questions.text: Following an earthquake that shook the city of Delhi, multiple casualties are expected to arrive at the hospital requiring medical aid. You get a call from the field doctors asking you to clear out as many beds at the hospital for incoming casualties. What is this process called?
questions.solution:
Reverse triage is followed in this situation to discharge existing patients and to increase the surge capacity of the hospital to accommodate for the natural disaster. 

In reverse triage, non-emergent patients currently admitted to the hospital are discharged to allow for the acute increase in incoming patients. It allows for better utilization of resources. This is used in wars and military settings, where soldiers may need to return to the field of battle soon after treatment. It is also done when medical resources are scarce after a disaster.

Triage (Option B) consists of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of the severity of the injury and the likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention. It is carried out at the site of the disaster. Tagging is the identification of patients in a disaster with tags stating their name, age, place of origin, triage category, diagnosis, and initial treatment. Minor or moderate injuries can be treated at home to avoid social dislocation and reduce the resource drain that can occur by transporting them to central facilities. The seriously injured should be transported to specialized treatment facilities and hospitals.

During triage, there should be the highest optimization of resource allocation, and it should neither underestimate the injuries of a critical patient (undertriage) (Option A) nor should it divert unnecessary resources by overstating the patient’s condition (overtriage). Overtriage can actually worsen patient outcomes.

Telephone triage (Option D) is done by a nurse interacting with a caller (patient or caregiver) to identify the nature and urgency of the health care needs and determine an appropriate plan of care and disposition of the call.

questions.text: All of the following methods of removal of hardness of water cause the precipitation of calcium carbonate except?
questions.solution:
Boiling and the addition of soda ash/ lime remove the hardness of water by the precipitation of calcium carbonate. The base exchange process leads to the precipitation of calcium and magnesium permutit.

Option A: Permutit is a complex chemical compound of sodium, aluminum, and silica that is used in the process of base exchange to remove the temporary and permanent hardness of water. It works on the principle of ion exchange to remove calcium and magnesium from water.

Option B: The addition of soda ash or sodium carbonate can remove temporary as well as permanent hardness and causes the precipitation of calcium carbonate. 

Option C: In Clark's method, lime or calcium hydroxide is added to water also to remove temporary hardness. The lime absorbs the carbon dioxide and causes precipitation of calcium carbonate.

Option D: Boiling the water can remove temporary hardness by precipitating calcium carbonate and expelling carbon dioxide. 

Related Pearl: Hardness of Water

  • Hardness is the soap destroying power of water or the amount of dissolved calcium and magnesium in water.
  • It is most commonly caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium, but their nitrates and chlorides can also cause hardness.
  • Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.
  • 1 mEq/L of an ion that produces hardness is equal to 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) in 1 litre of water.
Classification Level of hardness (mEq/l) Amount of ion producing hardness (mg/l)
Soft water Less than 1 Less than 50
Moderately hard 1 – 3 50 – 150
Hard water 3 – 6 150 – 300
Very hard water Over 6 More than 300
  • Drinking water must be moderately hard
  • Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/L (150 mg/litre)
  • Removal of hardness:
    • Boiling: 
      • This removes temporary hardness by expelling carbon dioxide and precipitating insoluble calcium carbonate. It would be expensive to do this on a large scale.
    • Addition of lime: 
      • This removes temporary hardness and also reduces magnesium. Lime absorbs carbon dioxide and precipitates insoluble calcium carbonate. In Clark’s method of softening water, lime is used.
    • Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash): removes both temporary and permanent hardness.
    • Base exchange process:
      • This removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used on a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica. When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman who has completed her family wants to undergo a permanent method of sterilization. She wants to know about the Essure device which is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilisation.  What is the mechanism of action of this form of sterilization?

choices.text: Local growth of fibrous tissue occluding the fallopian tube
Local spermicidal action of titanium alloy

questions.solution:
The Essure permanent device is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilization. The mechanism of action is the local growth of fibrous tissue responsible for the occlusion of the fallopian tube. This is an irreversible and permanent technique. 

Essure is done through the hysteroscopic method and so the abdominal scar is avoided. It involves a dynamically expanding micro-inserter consisting of two coils – an inner coil made of flexible stainless steel and an outer coil made of nickel-titanium alloy (nitinol). The inner coil contains polyethylene terephthalate (PET) fibers, which stimulate the growth of harmless local fibrous tissue, leading to the blockage of the fallopian tube. A guidewire helps to guide the device into the fallopian tube. After three months, a hysterosalpingography is conducted to confirm the blockage of the fallopian tube.

Disadvantages:

  • Hysteroscopy is required
  • Cost and expertise required
  • Permanent method
  • HSG to confirm blockage
  • Bilateral insertion is difficult due to spasms in 15% of cases
  • Tuboplasty for reversal is not possible
  • Perforation of the tube

Advantage:

No abdominal scar and can be done under local anesthesia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the hospital by his wife. She complains that under stressful situations the patient's behaviour completely changes. He believes that he is a 7-year-old boy named "babu" and behaves like a child. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dissociative identity disorder is characterised by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states that assume control of an individual's behavior. It was previously called multiple personality disorder.

The disorder usually begins in childhood, in those who experience overwhelming circumstances, such as physical or sexual abuse.

Patients with dissociative identity disorder initially present with symptoms of emotional and behavioural turmoil. Some patients may have memory gaps and incidents of out-of-character behaviour. The symptoms are characterised by different "alters" or alternate identities, controlling the patient's behaviour for varying lengths of time. The identities of the patient may switch under stressful situations, disputes among alters, and other psychological conflicts.

DSM-5 classification of dissociative disorders includes the following:

  • Dissociative identity disorder (multiple identity disorder)
  • Dissociative amnesia
  • Depersonalisation/derealisation disorder
  • Other specified dissociative disorders include dissociative trance, dissociative reactions to stressful events Etc.
  • Unspecified dissociative disorder

Other options:

Depersonalisation/derealisation disorder (Option A and C): It is characterised by

  • Depersonalization: Experiences of unreality, detachment, or being an outside observer of his/her own thoughts, feelings, sensations, body, or actions.
  • Derealization: Experiences of unreality or detachment with respect to surroundings, where the surrounding individuals or objects are experienced as unreal, dream-like, or foggy.

Dissociative amnesia (Option D): It is characterised by the inability to recall important autobiographical information, which is usually of a traumatic or stressful nature. The information that the patient forgets is too extensive and cannot be forgotten under ordinary circumstances. Some might forget significant personal information or even his/her own name. Although in dissociative identity disorder, there may be memory gaps, the key feature is that the patients switch between two or more identities, while in dissociative amnesia, the patient forgets his/her own identity.

questions.text: A lady with 2 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urine pregnancy test came for medical termination of the pregnancy. Menstrual aspiration is being performed. Which is the instrument used for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Karman’s cannula (image 3) is used for menstrual aspiration.

Menstrual regulation or aspiration is the aspiration of the endometrial cavity 1-3 weeks after a missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle and a positive urine pregnancy test. It is performed using Karman's cannula.

Procedure -

  • Under aseptic precautions, the cervix may be gently dilated using 4-5 mm size dilators.
  • Then 5-6mm Karman’s cannula is inserted and attached to a 50ml syringe for suction.
  • The cannula is rotated, pushed in and out with gentle strokes.

This procedure is contraindicated in advanced pregnancy and in the presence of local pelvic inflammation.

The drawback of the procedure - an implanted zygote can be missed, an ectopic pregnancy can be unrecognized.

Other options:

  • Instrument 1 is Rubins cannula. It is used for hysterosalpingography.
  • Instrument 2 is Leech Wilkinson's cannula. It can be identified by the spiral cone at the tip and is used for hysterosalpingography.
  • Instrument 4 is Simpson's uterine sound. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement and is used to measure the length of the uterus.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the given condition?

choices.text: A broad-based gait may be seen
Upper urinary tracts abnormalities are usually present
There is increased incidence of squamous cell carcinoma of bladder
Posterior displacement of the anus is typically associated

questions.solution:
The above image is suggestive of ectopia vesicae or bladder exstrophy.

Ectopia vesicae/bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality that occurs when the lower abdominal wall does not form properly. The bladder protrudes from the abdominal wall, and its mucosa is exposed.  This is hypothesized to occur due to the failure of the mesoderm to invade the cephalad extension of the cloacal membrane.

The umbilicus is displaced downwards and the rectus muscles are separated. The pubic rami are widely separated and can cause a characteristic broad-based gait (Option A). Males commonly have complete epispadias with dorsal chordee, undescended testes, short penis, and inguinal hernia. Epispadias with separation of the two halves of the clitoris and wide separation of labia is seen in females. Anus is displaced anteriorly in both sexes (Option D). Rectal prolapse may be seen.

Classically the upper urinary tracts are usually normal at birth (Option B) and an increased incidence of adenocarcinoma of the bladder is seen (Option C).

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to the hospital with complaints of chest pain. Heart rate was 160 beats /min and BP was 90/60 mm of Hg and ECG was suggestive of atrial fibrillation. A drug was started which is a funny current inhibitor in the SA node of the heart. Which of the following is a funny current inhibitor in the SA node of the heart?
questions.solution:
Ivabradine is a cardiac pacemaker funny current If inhibitor of SA node indicated in specific chronic congestive heart failure patients.

Ivabradine is used as a therapeutic target to control heart rate. Unlike other heart rate-lowering agents such as β blockers, it reduces heart rate without affecting myocardial contractility, ventricular repolarization, or intracardiac conduction. The antianginal effect is mainly by reduction of heart rate and thereby decreasing O2 demand of the myocardium.

Option A: Trimetazidine is a partial fatty acid oxidation (pFOX) inhibitor. In ischemic myocardium, there is a shift of metabolism to fatty acid oxidation that increases oxygen requirement. Partial inhibition of fatty acid oxidation reduces the oxygen requirement.

Option B: Fasudil is a selective ‘RhoA/rho kinase (ROCK)’ inhibitor.

Option D: Nicorandil is an agonist of KATP channels.

questions.text: A patient presents to OPD with complaints of an assault. On examination, a scab is noted that is brownish-black in color. Which of the following is the most probable time since the injury?
questions.solution:
The presence of a scab that is brownish-black in color indicates that the injury probably occurred 2 to 3 days prior.

Abrasion types:

  • Linear abrasions (scratches): Caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin. It leaves a clean area at the start and tags at the end.
    • e.g. nail, thorn, or the point of a sword or knife.
  • Grazed abrasions (sliding /scrapping/grinding abrasion): Caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin.
    • known as brush burns.
    • e.g. fall, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents.
  • Impact abrasions (imprint abrasions): Caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin, without any movement
    • e.g. fingernails, tires, grills, bicycle chains, or bite marks.
  • Friction abrasions (pressure abrasion): Caused by pressure upon the skin with an agent with a smooth surface, accompanied by movement.
    • e.g. ligature marks around the neck in hanging, strangulation.
  • Patterned abrasion: Caused by impact abrasion or pressure abrasion, reproducing the pattern of the object causing it

Note: Grazed abrasion is the most common type of abrasion.

 

Note: The answer cannot be option D as scab usually falls off by 7th day. So, amongst the given options, the best answer is 2-3 days.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male patient is undergoing a clinical assessment for aphasia. He makes errors in word choice frequently and has obvious difficulty in comprehension. The speech is otherwise effortless and melodic. Other neurological examination findings are within normal limits. Which area of brain damage can result in such a type of aphasia?

choices.text: Posterior temporal and parietal lobes, dominant hemisphere
Frontal and parietal lobes, dominant hemisphere
Posterior parietal and temporal lobes, non-dominant hemisphere
Prefrontal and frontal regions, dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
The patient described above has Wernicke’s aphasia (WA). This usually occurs as a result of damage in the posterior temporal and parietal regions of the dominant hemisphere, which are supplied by the lower division of the middle cerebral artery.

Aphasia is an acquired disorder of language. Wernicke's aphasia is characterized by fluent language output but impaired comprehension. Gestures do not improve communication. The patient may not realize that their language is incomprehensible and may be associated with severe agitation and paranoia.

Many specific aphasic syndromes have been reported. The most common are Broca, Wernicke, conduction, and global aphasias. Other are non-perisylvian aphasias that include anomic, transcortical motor, transcortical sensory, and mixed transcortical.

questions.text: Which of the following pathway is caspase-independent?
questions.solution:
Necroptosis is a caspase-independent pathway.

Necroptosis, as the name suggests has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. This is a caspase-independent programmed cell death. It is also called programmed necrosis.

Mechanism:

  • TNF-α activates TNFR1 and, in turn, induces the recruitment of RIP1 and RIP3 kinase and other proteins to form a complex.
  • This complex includes caspase 8. But, caspase 8 is not activated in this pathway.
  • RIPK3 phosphorylates a cytoplasmic protein called MLKL. On phosphorylation, MLKL monomers assemble into oligomers, translocate from the cytosol to the plasma membrane, and cause plasma membrane disruption.

Other options

Option C: Pyroptosis occurs due to the release of fever-inducing cytokine interleukin-1 (IL-1). Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that entered the infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. Inflammasome activates caspase 1 and helps in the release of the biologically activated forms of IL-1. Along with caspase 1, caspases 4 and 5 also induce cell death. Unlike classical apoptosis, pyroptosis is characterized by the release of inflammatory mediators. 

Options A and B: The intrinsic mitochondrial and extrinsic death receptor-initiated pathways converge to activate a caspase cascade that mediates the final phase of apoptosis. The intrinsic pathway activates caspase 9 whereas the extrinsic pathway activates caspases 8 and 10. These caspases then activate caspase 3, and caspase 6. Activated caspases cause DNA degradation and nuclei fragmentation.
